questions.text: A preterm infant has the following findings: upper chest lag present, minimal lower chest retractions, prominent xiphoid retractions, marked nasal flaring, and no grunting. What is the likely Silverman-Anderson Respiratory Score (SAS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5–6

 

  • The Silverman-Anderson Score (SAS) is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates. 
  • Each of the five components (upper chest movement, lower chest retraction, xiphoid retraction, nasal flaring, and grunting) is scored from 0 to 2.
    • Upper chest lag = 1
    • Minimal lower chest retraction = 1
    • Marked xiphoid retraction = 2
    • Nasal flaring = 2
    • No Grunting = 0
      Total = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAS quantifies neonatal respiratory distress (0 = none, 10 = severe). Moderate scores (5–6) indicate significant distress requiring CPAP and close monitoring.

questions.text: Match the following healthcare schemes with their target populations in India:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

 

  • 1-C. Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY)- Economically weaker sections: PM-JAY provides health insurance coverage to economically weaker sections (bottom 40% families).
  • 2-B. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)- Children from birth to 18 years: RBSK focuses on early identification and management of diseases in children from birth to 18 years.
  • 3-A. Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)- Pregnant women and newborns: JSY promotes institutional deliveries by providing cash assistance to pregnant women.
  • 4-D. Mission Indradhanush- Infants and children for immunization: Mission Indradhanush aims to achieve full immunization coverage for children and pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PM-JAY is the world's largest government-funded healthcare scheme targeting economically disadvantaged families
  • RBSK provides comprehensive healthcare services to children from birth to 18 years through dedicated teams

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with no medical history presents with syncope during urination. The event was witnessed, with no evidence of seizure activity. Orthostatic vitals reveal a 5-mmHg systolic drop and a 20 bpm rise in HR. Physical exam and ECG are normal, and she is currently asymptomatic. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurocardiogenic

 

  • Micturition syncope is a classic example of neurocardiogenic (reflex) syncope, triggered by a transient increase in vagal tone during urination.
  • This produces bradycardia and/or hypotension, causing short-term cerebral hypoperfusion and loss of consciousness.
  • Typical triggers for neurocardiogenic syncope include urination, defecation, coughing, standing after prolonged sitting or lying, and emotional stress.
  • This form of syncope is common in older adults and usually benign, with management focused on avoiding triggers and maintaining good hydration.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Arrhythmogenic: Arrhythmogenic syncope often occurs with underlying cardiac disease, is sudden (often without warning), and would show ECG or structural abnormality; not the case here.


Option C. Neurologic: Neurologic causes (e.g., seizure, TIA) usually have additional neurologic features, abnormal postictal state, or focal deficits - none are reported.


Option D. Orthostatic hypotension: Orthostatic hypotension requires a drop in systolic BP ≥20 mmHg; her 5 mmHg drop is not significant, and symptoms were specifically associated with micturition, not posture alone.

 

Educational Objective:


Neurocardiogenic (vasovagal) syncope occurs in response to characteristic triggers like urination and is due to vagal overactivity; a benign condition best managed by education and avoidance of the precipitating stimulus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a 5-year history of joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, primarily involving the small joints of the hands and wrists. Laboratory tests reveal a positive rheumatoid factor and elevated ESR. She is initiated on methotrexate therapy. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of AICAR transformylase

 

  • Methotrexate is the first-line DMARD used for rheumatoid arthritis. 
  • At low weekly doses used in rheumatoid arthritis, methotrexate primarily inhibits AICAR transformylase, causing accumulation of adenosine, a powerful anti-inflammatory mediator. 
  • Methotrexate's immunomodulatory properties help reduce disease progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of dihydrofolic acid reductase: Incorrect (mechanism at higher anticancer doses). Methotrexate inhibits DHFR in cancer therapy, blocking thymidylate synthesis. In RA, the doses are much lower, and DHFR inhibition is not the primary anti-inflammatory mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocking Janus Kinase (JAK): Incorrect. This is the mechanism of tofacitinib, baricitinib, and other JAK inhibitors (used when MTX fails).

 

Option D. Inhibition of pyrimidine synthesis: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of leflunomide, which inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low-dose methotrexate inhibits AICAR transformylase, causing accumulation of AICAR → increased extracellular adenosine, which:
    • Decreases neutrophil adhesion
    • Inhibits inflammatory cytokines
    • Suppresses immune cell activation
    • Leading to decreased synovial inflammation.

choices.text: It acutely relieves anginal attacks by rapid coronary vasodilation
It increases exercise tolerance without affecting heart rate or blood pressure
It acts through direct β-adrenergic receptor antagonism
It significantly reduces the incidence of myocardial infarction in unstable angina

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic stable angina is unable to tolerate beta blockers due to bradycardia. His physician initiates ranolazine. Which of the following statements about ranolazine is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It increases exercise tolerance without affecting heart rate or blood pressure

 

  • Ranolazine is a unique antianginal medication approved for chronic stable angina. 
  • Unlike traditional antianginal agents (e.g., beta-blockers, nitrates, calcium channel blockers), it does not significantly alter heart rate or blood pressure. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of the late sodium current (late INa) in ischemic myocardial cells. 
  • This leads to a reduction in intracellular calcium via the Na⁺/Ca²⁺ exchanger (NCX), improving diastolic relaxation and reducing myocardial wall tension and oxygen demand.
  • This allows patients to exercise longer and experience fewer angina episodes, both as monotherapy and in combination with standard antianginals.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It acutely relieves anginal attacks by rapid coronary vasodilation: Incorrect. Ranolazine is not effective for acute angina. It does not cause coronary vasodilation like nitrates, and is not used for immediate symptom relief. It is rather used to prevent angina.

 

Option C. It acts through direct β-adrenergic receptor antagonism: Incorrect. Ranolazine does not act on adrenergic receptors. Beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) reduce heart rate and contractility through this pathway, unlike ranolazine.

 

Option D. It significantly reduces the incidence of myocardial infarction in unstable angina: Incorrect. While ranolazine improves exercise tolerance and symptom burden, it has not been shown to significantly reduce MI rates, especially in acute coronary syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ranolazine improves anginal symptoms by inhibiting late sodium current, reducing calcium overload, and improving myocardial relaxation — without affecting hemodynamic parameters like heart rate or blood pressure.

choices.text: Failure of class-switch recombination in B cells
Defective differentiation of pre-B cells into mature B cells
Failure of somatic hypermutation in germinal centers
Defective T-cell activation due to absent CD40L expression

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of sinusitis, otitis media, and pneumonia since childhood. She also reports chronic diarrhea. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly decreased serum levels of IgG, IgA, and IgM. Flow cytometric analysis shows a marked reduction in the number of mature B cells (CD19⁺), while T-cell numbers (CD3⁺) are normal. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene located on the X chromosome. Which of the following immune mechanisms is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective differentiation of pre-B cells into mature B cells

 

  • This clinical presentation - recurrent bacterial infections, diarrhea, and absent immunoglobulins with low B cells in a male child - is characteristic of X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.
  • It results from a mutation in the BTK gene (on Xq21.3–Xq22), which is essential for maturation of pre-B cells into mature B cells in the bone marrow.
  • Hence, B-cell development is arrested at the pre-B cell stage, leading to absent mature B cells (CD19⁺) and very low immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of class-switch recombination in B cells:

 

  • Seen in Hyper-IgM syndrome, due to CD40L (on T cells) or CD40 (on B cells) defect.
  • In that case, IgM is high while IgG, IgA, IgE are low, but B-cell numbers are normal.
  • Not consistent with the present case.

 

Option C. Failure of somatic hypermutation in germinal centers:

 

  • Also occurs in Hyper-IgM syndrome and some common variable immunodeficiencies.
  • Here, B-cell differentiation occurs but antibody affinity maturation is impaired.
  • This patient has no mature B cells, so somatic hypermutation cannot even occur.

 

Option D. Defective T-cell activation due to absent CD40L expression: 

 

  • Describes X-linked Hyper-IgM syndrome.
  • Patients have recurrent opportunistic infections (Pneumocystis, Cryptosporidium) due to impaired macrophage activation.
  • Immunoglobulin pattern: ↑ IgM, ↓ IgG, IgA, IgE.
  • Not seen here (all Ig low, not just switched classes).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Categorize the statements below regarding trauma patients as true (T) or false (F): 

 

  1. Arterial blood gas is a useful indicator of shock in patients of trauma, and trending these values can reflect improvements with resuscitation.
  2. In patients with suspected fracture of the cribriform plate, a Ryles tube is inserted nasally.
  3. It is essential to catheterize the patient transurethrally before you can proceed to examine the perineum and genitalia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T, F, F

 

  • Statement 1. True. Arterial blood gas (ABG) is indeed a useful indicator of shock in trauma patients and can reflect changes in response to resuscitation efforts.
  • Statement 2. False. If a cribriform plate fracture is suspected, inserting a gastric tube nasally is contraindicated due to the risk of entering the cranial vault.
  • Statement 3. False. Catheterization should not be done trans-urethrally before examining the perineum and genitalia, particularly if there is evidence of potential urethral injury.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Arterial blood gases are valuable for assessing shock and response to resuscitation. 
  • Gastric tubes should be inserted orally in the context of potential cribriform plate fractures to avoid intracranial passage. 
  • Lastly, a careful examination of the perineum and genitalia is necessary before catheterization to avoid exacerbating any potential urethral injuries.

questions.text: A chronic smoker gets cramping pain in his calf after walking about 500 m. What is the likely pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial femoral arterial block

 

  • The symptoms described, especially calf pain after walking a specific distance (claudication), suggest peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
  •  In PAD, atherosclerotic blockages in arteries cause reduced blood flow to the lower extremities, leading to pain in the muscles during exertion. 
  • A superficial femoral arterial block specifically causes calf claudication, as this artery supplies the muscles in the calf region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorto-iliac block: While an aorto-iliac blockage can also cause claudication, the pain from this blockage typically manifests in the thigh, buttocks, or hip region rather than the calf.

 

Option C. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): DVT usually presents with swelling, warmth, and pain that is constant, rather than claudication-like pain that occurs after a certain distance of walking. DVT pain does not typically have a "distance threshold" as described here.

 

Option D. Hip osteoarthritis: Hip osteoarthritis can cause pain with walking, but the pain is generally located in the hip or groin, not specifically in the calf. It is also not typically cramping in nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent claudication, characterized by cramping pain in the leg muscles during exercise, is a hallmark symptom of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). 
  • The location of pain can help localize the site of arterial blockage.
  • Calf pain suggests a blockage in the superficial femoral artery, while thigh or buttock pain suggests a more proximal blockage such as an aorto-iliac obstruction.

choices.text: Reducing repetitive motions and force requirements
Increasing productivity by avoiding breaks during work
Designing workstations to fit individual worker dimensions

questions.text: All of the following are ergonomic principles for preventing work-related musculoskeletal disorders except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increasing productivity by avoiding breaks during work

 

  • Ergonomic principles focus on designing work environments and practices that reduce physical stress and prevent musculoskeletal disorders. 
  • Key principles include maintaining neutral postures, minimizing repetitive motions and excessive force, and ensuring proper workstation design.
  • However, increasing work duration without breaks contradicts ergonomic principles as it increases fatigue and risk of injury. 
  • Regular breaks are essential for muscle recovery and preventing overuse injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maintaining neutral postures during work: Maintaining neutral postures is a fundamental ergonomic principle that reduces stress on joints and muscles.

 

Option B. Reducing repetitive motions and force requirements: Reducing repetitive motions and force requirements is a core ergonomic strategy to prevent musculoskeletal disorders.

 

Option D. Designing workstations to fit individual worker dimensions: Proper workstation design that fits worker dimensions is essential for maintaining good posture and preventing injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ergonomic principles aim to reduce physical stress and prevent work-related musculoskeletal disorders
  • Regular breaks and rest periods are crucial components of ergonomic workplace design
  • Proper workstation design should accommodate individual worker characteristics and promote neutral postures

questions.text: A drug company is developing a medication similar in structure and mechanism of action to an existing drug, with slight differences in pharmacokinetics like volume of distribution (Vd) and half-life (t½). What type of drug is this classified as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Me-too drug

 

Me-too drugs are structurally similar to existing drugs with minor differences, primarily in pharmacokinetics like volume of distribution (Vd) and half-life (t½). Examples include ACE inhibitors like enalapril and ramipril.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orphan drug: Incorrect. Orphan drugs treat rare conditions and are developed under specific laws.

 

Option C. Essential drug: Incorrect. Essential drugs address priority healthcare needs based on safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness.

 

Option D. Adulterated drug: Incorrect. Adulterated drugs are compromised in quality due to harmful substances.

 

Educational Objective:


Me-too drugs are structurally and mechanistically similar to existing drugs but may differ slightly in pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: A 16 French size of Foley's catheter refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Outer diameter of 5.3 mm

 

  • French is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter.
  • It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings.
  • The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter.
  •  For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

choices.text: Use of bed nets during daytime

questions.text: The image shows the life cycle of a vector responsible for transmission of chikungunya. What is the most effective method to control this vector based on its breeding pattern shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elimination of stagnant water collections

 

  • The image shows the life cycle of Aedes aegypti mosquito, which requires stagnant water for breeding.
  • The most effective control measure is source reduction by eliminating stagnant water collections where the mosquito lays eggs and larvae develop.
  • This targets the aquatic stages of the vector's life cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indoor residual spraying with insecticides: Indoor residual spraying is less effective for Aedes as they are primarily outdoor breeders and day-biters

 

Option B. Use of bed nets during daytime: Bed nets are ineffective as Aedes mosquitoes bite during daytime hours

 

Option D. Mass administration of prophylactic antibiotics: Antibiotics have no role in viral disease prevention or vector control

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aedes aegypti breeds in clean stagnant water collections around human habitations
  • Source reduction (eliminating breeding sites) is the most effective control strategy
  • Community participation in removing water storage sites is crucial for vector control

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with flushing, headaches, and occasional dizziness. Laboratory studies reveal elevated levels of a vasodilatory compound in his blood. This compound is known to be produced by the decarboxylation of an amino acid. Which of the following amino acids is the precursor for this compound?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histidine

 

  • The vasodilatory compound described in this question is histamine, which is derived from the decarboxylation of the amino acid histidine. 
  • Histidine is converted into histamine through the action of the enzyme histidine decarboxylase.
  • Histamine is a biogenic amine that plays multiple roles in the body, including:
    • Vasodilation: By acting on H1 and H2 receptors, histamine causes smooth muscle relaxation in blood vessels, leading to increased blood flow and redness (flushing).
    • Immune response: Released by mast cells and basophils during allergic reactions.
    • Regulation of gastric acid: Stimulates acid secretion in the stomach.
  • The clinical presentation of flushing, dizziness, and elevated levels of a vasodilatory compound are consistent with excess histamine activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine is a precursor for nitric oxide (NO), another vasodilator. However, nitric oxide production involves the enzyme nitric oxide synthase and does not involve decarboxylation.

 

Option C. Aspartic acid: Aspartic acid is involved in the urea cycle and neurotransmitter synthesis but does not lead to the production of vasodilatory compounds through decarboxylation.

 

Option D. Glutamine: Glutamine serves as a nitrogen donor in various metabolic processes, including nucleotide synthesis, but it does not directly produce vasodilatory compounds via decarboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Histamine is a vasodilatory compound derived from the decarboxylation of the amino acid histidine. 
  • This reaction is catalyzed by histidine decarboxylase and is crucial in mediating processes such as allergic reactions, gastric acid secretion, and vascular regulation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man develops pain, swelling, and redness at the site of an intramuscular injection after 24 hours. Examination shows warmth and tenderness with no pus formation. A biopsy from the site reveals dilated blood vessels, edema, and a predominant infiltration of neutrophils in the interstitial tissue. Which of the following mediators is primarily responsible for the neutrophil chemotaxis observed in this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leukotriene B4 (LTB4)

 

  • This case describes an acute inflammatory response (onset within 24 hours, neutrophil predominant).
  • Key steps in acute inflammation include vasodilation, increased permeability, and leukocyte recruitment (chemotaxis).
  • LTB4, derived from arachidonic acid via the 5-lipoxygenase pathway, is one of the most potent chemo attractants for neutrophils.
  • It enhances adhesion to endothelium, chemotaxis, and activation of neutrophils (increasing ROS and lysosomal enzyme release).
  • Hence, LTB4 is the principal mediator responsible for the neutrophil infiltration in early acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histamine: 

 

  • Released by mast cells, basophils, platelets.
  • Causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, but does not attract neutrophils.

 

Option B. Interleukin-1 (IL-1):

 

  • Produced by macrophages; acts as a pyrogen and endothelial activator (increases adhesion molecules).
  • Promotes fever and systemic inflammation, but not direct chemotaxis.

 

Option D. Platelet-activating factor (PAF): 

 

  • Causes platelet aggregation, vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and increased permeability.
  • It may enhance leukocyte adhesion, but LTB4 is far more specific and potent for chemotaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key inflammatory mediators:

choices.text: VHND sessions are conducted monthly on a mutually decided date targeting children (0-6 years) and pregnant women only.
VHND sessions are conducted weekly targeting all children under 5 years, pregnant and lactating mothers, and adolescent girls.
VHND sessions are conducted monthly on a mutually decided date by the village health team, targeting children 0-6 years, pregnant and lactating mothers, and eligible couples for family planning.
VHND sessions are conducted twice a month with mandatory medical officer supervision, targeting only malnourished children and high-risk pregnant women.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the timing and target beneficiaries of Village Health and Nutrition Day (VHND) is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VHND sessions are conducted monthly on a mutually decided date by the village health team, targeting children 0-6 years, pregnant and lactating mothers, and eligible couples for family planning

 

  • Village Health and Nutrition Day (VHND) is conducted monthly preferably on Wednesdays or on a date mutually decided by ANM, ASHA, and Anganwadi Worker based on local convenience. 
  • The target beneficiaries include children 0-6 years for immunization and nutrition services, pregnant and lactating mothers for antenatal/postnatal care, and eligible couples for family planning counseling and services. 
  • The flexibility in scheduling and comprehensive target population coverage are key features of VHND implementation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VHND sessions are conducted monthly on a mutually decided date targeting children (0-6 years) and pregnant women only: VHND does not have a mandatory fixed date, and target beneficiaries include more than just children 0-6 years and pregnant women. This is a distractor option, if the word “target” is missed in the question, Option A would most likely be chosen as the answer.

 

Option B. VHND sessions are conducted weekly targeting all children under 5 years, pregnant and lactating mothers, and adolescent girls: VHND is not conducted weekly.

 

Option D. VHND sessions are conducted twice a month with mandatory medical officer supervision, targeting only malnourished children and high-risk pregnant women: VHND is conducted monthly, not twice a month, and targets all eligible beneficiaries, not just malnourished children and high-risk cases

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • VHND provides integrated health and nutrition services through sessions conducted monthly on mutually convenient dates with flexible scheduling
  • Target beneficiaries include children 0-6 years, pregnant/lactating mothers, and eligible couples for comprehensive care

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications has been associated with the development of lens opacities requiring periodic eye examinations during long-term therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quetiapine

 

  • Quetiapine, an atypical antipsychotic, has been linked in animal studies and early human reports to cataract formation with chronic use. 
  • This prompted recommendations for patients on prolonged therapy to undergo baseline and routine ophthalmologic monitoring, although conclusive human data remains limited. 
  • This adverse effect is unique among second-generation antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: While it may cause extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia, it is not associated with cataract development.

 

Option B. Chlorpromazine: Known to cause pigment deposits in the cornea, but not cataracts.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: No known link to cataract formation; its adverse effects are mainly neurologic (EPS, tardive dyskinesia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quetiapine is the only atypical antipsychotic associated with lens changes in animal models, prompting eye exams during long-term use.

choices.text: Confidentiality must be maintained between the healthcare provider and the adolescent
Parental consent is mandatory for providing contraceptive counseling to unmarried minors below 18 years
Healthcare providers should assess the adolescent's capacity for informed decision-making
Emergency contraception can be provided to adolescents without parental involvement in cases of sexual assault

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried girl approaches a community health center seeking contraceptive advice without parental consent. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act 2021 and current Indian medical ethics guidelines, all of the following are correct principles regarding adolescent reproductive health services except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parental consent is mandatory for providing contraceptive counseling to unmarried minors below 18 years

 

  • According to current Indian medical ethics and the MTP Amendment Act 2021, parental consent is not mandatory for providing contraceptive counseling to unmarried minors. 
  • The principle of adolescent autonomy in reproductive health decisions recognizes that mature minors can make informed decisions about their reproductive health.
  •  Healthcare providers should prioritize the adolescent's best interests, maintain confidentiality, and assess their decision-making capacity rather than requiring automatic parental consent for contraceptive services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confidentiality must be maintained between the healthcare provider and the adolescent: Confidentiality is a fundamental principle in adolescent reproductive health services to encourage help-seeking behavior

 

Option C. Healthcare providers should assess the adolescent's capacity for informed decision-making: Assessment of decision-making capacity is essential to ensure informed consent in adolescent healthcare

 

Option D. Emergency contraception can be provided to adolescents without parental involvement in cases of sexual assault: Emergency contraception provision without parental involvement is ethically justified in sexual assault cases to protect the victim's immediate health needs

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adolescent reproductive health services prioritize the minor's autonomy and best interests over automatic parental consent requirements
  • Confidentiality is crucial for encouraging adolescents to seek reproductive health services

questions.text: A patient with severe asthma was intubated and ventilated. The same night he has a ventilator alarm for high airway pressures. Ventilator readings show a Peak inspiratory pressure of 50 mmHg and a Plateau pressure of 35 mmHg. Ventilator tubing is intact, and the patient is already on appropriate bronchodilators and steroids. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Disconnect the ventilator

 

  • The simultaneous rise in peak (50 mmHg) and plateau (35 mmHg) pressures suggests dynamic hyperinflation (auto-PEEP) or alveolar overdistention rather than isolated airway resistance.
  • This can occur in severe asthma due to air-trapping from incomplete exhalation, leading to dangerously high intrathoracic pressures and risk of barotrauma or hemodynamic compromise.
  • The immediate step is to disconnect the ventilator circuit and manually ventilate the patient with slow, controlled breaths, allowing sufficient time for exhalation.
  • This releases trapped gas and helps confirm whether the problem lies in the ventilator circuit or within the patient (air-trapping, bronchospasm, or tension pneumothorax).
  • Once stabilized, adjust ventilator settings to prevent recurrence:
    • Low respiratory rate (8–10/min)
    • Low tidal volume (4–6 mL/kg ideal body weight)
    • High inspiratory flow (short inspiratory time → prolonged expiratory time)
    • Permissive hypercapnia (acceptable pH > 7.15)
    • Minimal or zero PEEP

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP): While excessive PEEP can raise pressures, this patient’s problem is auto-PEEP from air-trapping, not excessive applied PEEP. Decreasing PEEP does not immediately correct the issue.

 

Option C. Increase FiO₂: Addresses oxygenation but not the life-threatening cause of high pressures (air-trapping/overdistention).

 

Option D. Increase RR: Would worsen air-trapping by further shortening expiratory time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In mechanically ventilated asthma, concurrent elevation of peak and plateau pressures signifies dynamic hyperinflation (auto-PEEP) and risk of barotrauma.
  • Immediate disconnection of the ventilator allows trapped air to escape and helps assess the airway before ventilator adjustments are made.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling, bloody vaginal discharge mixed with mucus. On examination, there is a necrotic cervical growth with lateral parametrium involvement. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemoradiation

 

  • This patient has findings consistent with locally advanced cervical cancer — characterized by:
    • Necrotic, ulcerative cervical mass
    • Parametrial involvement (extension to the connective tissue around the cervix)
    • Absence of distant metastasis
  • FIGO Staging Correlation:
    • Parametrial involvement without extension to pelvic wall → Stage IIB
    • Extension to the pelvic wall → Stage IIIB
  • For Stage IIB–IVA (locally advanced) cervical cancer, surgery is no longer feasible due to extensive local spread.

 

Standard of Care:

 

  • The treatment of choice for locally advanced cervical cancer (Stage IIB–IVA) is: Concurrent chemoradiation therapy (CCRT)
    • External Beam Radiotherapy (EBRT): To the pelvis (for primary and nodal disease)
    • Concurrent weekly Cisplatin chemotherapy (40 mg/m²): Acts as a radiosensitizer
    • Intracavitary brachytherapy: Delivers a high local dose to the cervix
  • This combined approach improves local control and overall survival compared to radiation alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brachytherapy: Incorrect.

 

  • Used as a part of chemoradiation, not as a standalone therapy in advanced disease.
  • Alone, it is insufficient for parametrial involvement.

 

Option B. Chemotherapy: Incorrect. Chemotherapy alone is not curative in cervical cancer; it is used for palliative or metastatic disease.

 

Option C. Surgery: Incorrect.

 

  • Radical hysterectomy is indicated only in early stages (IA–IB1).
  • Parametrial involvement makes the disease inoperable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In locally advanced cervical cancer (Stage IIB–IVA) with parametrial involvement, the treatment of choice is concurrent chemoradiation — combining external beam radiotherapy, cisplatin-based chemotherapy, and brachytherapy for optimal disease control.

choices.text: Contains sphingosine as the backbone alcohol
Has four fatty acid chains attached to three glycerol molecules
Is composed of ceramide and glucose

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with recurrent pregnancy losses tests positive for anticardiolipin antibodies. Her laboratory results also show a false-positive VDRL test. What is the unique structural feature of cardiolipin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Has four fatty acid chains attached to three glycerol molecules

 

  • Cardiolipin (also called diphosphatidylglycerol) is a unique phospholipid found almost exclusively in the inner mitochondrial membrane. 
  • It plays a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity and optimal function of the electron transport chain.

 

Structural Features:

 

  • Cardiolipin consists of:
    • Three glycerol molecules
    • Four fatty acid chains
    • Two phosphate groups
  • It can be described as two phosphatidic acid molecules linked by a glycerol bridge.
  • This unusual structure (four fatty acid tails and three glycerol backbones) distinguishes cardiolipin from all other membrane phospholipids.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Anticardiolipin antibodies are a type of antiphospholipid antibody, seen in Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), which causes:
    • Recurrent pregnancy loss
    • Thrombosis (arterial or venous)
  • These antibodies also cross-react with antigens used in syphilis tests, resulting in false-positive VDRL/RPR tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contains sphingosine as the backbone alcohol:

 

  • This describes sphingolipids, not cardiolipin.
  • Example: Sphingomyelin, which has sphingosine + fatty acid = ceramide backbone.

 

Option C. Contains a choline head group:

 

  • This describes phosphatidylcholine (lecithin), not cardiolipin.
  • Found abundantly in cell membranes and lung surfactant.

 

Option D. Is composed of ceramide and glucose: This describes cerebrosides, a type of glycosphingolipid found in the myelin sheath of neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiolipin is a unique mitochondrial phospholipid composed of three glycerol molecules and four fatty acid chains. 
  • It serves as an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, and antibodies against it (anticardiolipin antibodies) are associated with Antiphospholipid Syndrome and false-positive VDRL tests.

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion 

 

  • This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion.
  •  Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. 
  • Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.
  • Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:
    • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

questions.text:
A 3-week-old infant presents with unresolving fever and associated hepatosplenomegaly, with  microcephaly. Blood investigations and neuroimaging was done which is shown below. After detailed observation, the pediatrician advised urine examination.

Complete blood report

Patient Name: Master Aarav

Age / Sex: 3 years / Male

Date: 01-Apr-2024

Hemoglobin: 11.2 g/dL

WBC (TLC): 2,100 /mm³

Neutrophils: 42%

Lymphocytes: 50%

Platelet Count: 2.3 lakh /mm³

Peripheral Smear: Normocytic normochromic RBCs

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

  • This infant presents with the classic triad of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection: hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and microcephaly. 
  • CMV is the most common congenital infection worldwide, affecting approximately 0.5-2% of all live births. 
  • Urine PCR is the gold standard diagnostic test for CMV, offering high sensitivity (>90%) and specificity. 
  • The virus is shed in large quantities in the urine for months to years after congenital infection, making urine PCR an ideal non-invasive diagnostic method.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Is diagnosed primarily through detection of rubella-specific IgM antibodies in the infant's serum, not through urine PCR. Congenital rubella typically presents with cataracts, congenital heart defects (particularly PDA), and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option B. Toxoplasmosis: Diagnosis relies on detection of Toxoplasma-specific IgM in serum or demonstration of the organism in body fluids or tissues. Urine PCR is not the test of choice. Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Is best diagnosed through PCR or viral culture from vesicular lesions, CSF, or blood, depending on the clinical presentation. Urine PCR is not routinely used for HSV diagnosis. Congenital HSV typically presents with vesicular skin lesions, seizures, and CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • When evaluating a neonate with suspected congenital infection, the diagnostic approach varies by pathogen. 
  • For CMV (the most common congenital infection), urine PCR is the preferred diagnostic test due to high viral shedding in urine. 
  • The most common long-term sequelae of congenital CMV is sensorineural hearing loss, which may be progressive and not apparent at birth.

questions.text: A forensic investigator examines the dentition of decomposed remains in which the following temporary tooth are present- 1st Molars, central incisors, and lateral incisors. The upper canines and 2nd molar have not yet erupted. There is no permanent teeth. Based on this dental development, what is the most likely age range of the deceased individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12-16 months

 

  • Since the 1st molars have erupted (requiring at least ~12 months) but the canines have not yet erupted (less than ~18months), the most accurate age bracket is 12-16 months. 
  • This represents the developmental window after incisors and 1st molars have emerged but before canine eruption begins.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Age Estimation from Dentition:

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with hypertension, obesity, and sleep apnea presents with exertional dyspnea, high blood pressure, elevated JVP, crackles, lower extremity edema. Her echo shows an LVEF of 60%. She improves with diuresis and antihypertensive therapy. Which medication does not reduce the risk of rehospitalization for heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enalapril

 

  • In HFpEF (heart failure with preserved ejection fraction), the cornerstone of therapy to reduce hospitalization is an SGLT2 inhibitor, such as empagliflozin. 
  • These have demonstrated a modest reduction in the risk of heart failure hospitalization and improvement in quality of life, and are supported as first-line therapy by both American and European guidelines. 
  • Finerenone (a nonsteroidal mineralocorticoid antagonist) also reduces the risk of heart failure hospitalization in HFpEF and is beneficial as secondary therapy, while GLP-1 agonists such as tirzepatide can reduce HF hospitalizations and improve outcomes in patients with HFpEF and obesity, supported by recent trials and meta-analyses.
  • ACE inhibitors (such as enalapril), once considered mainstays, do not reduce rehospitalization risk for HFpEF, although they may be used for other comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension, CKD). 
  • Multiple randomized trials have not shown a reduction in all-cause mortality or HF hospitalizations for ACE inhibitors in this population, though there may be mild improvement in functional status.
  • As a result, among these options, only enalapril does not have evidence to reduce risk of rehospitalization in HFpEF, while SGLT2 inhibitors, MRAs, and GLP-1 agonists are all effective in lowering this risk through distinct mechanisms.​

 

Other Options:


Option A. Finerenone: Has demonstrated benefit in reducing HF hospitalization rates in clinical trials for HFpEF and in those with CKD.


Option C. Tirzepatide: A GLP-1/glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) receptor agonist, has shown to lower risk of HF hospitalization (especially in those with obesity and diabetes).


Option D. Empagliflozin: Is an SGLT2 inhibitor and is guideline-recommended to reduce risk of HF hospitalization in HFpEF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In HFpEF, therapies with clear evidence for reducing heart failure rehospitalization include SGLT2 inhibitors, certain MRAs, and GLP-1 agonists. 
  • ACE inhibitors, including enalapril, have not shown similar benefit for this endpoint and are not preferred solely for this indication.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 10-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance over the past few months. He is a former smoker and has been compliant with dual bronchodilator therapy consisting of tiotropium and formoterol. On evaluation, his post-bronchodilator FEV₁ is 71% of predicted, and his blood eosinophil count is 74 cells/µL. There is no history of frequent exacerbations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacologic management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ensifentrine

 

  • This patient remains symptomatic despite optimized LAMA + LABA therapy. His low eosinophil count (< 100 cells/µL) and absence of frequent exacerbations make the addition of inhaled corticosteroids inappropriate.
  • Ensifentrine is a novel dual phosphodiesterase-3 and phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor that provides both bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory activity.
  • It has shown improvement in FEV₁, dyspnea scores, and exacerbation rates when added to standard bronchodilator therapy, without an increased pneumonia risk, and its benefit is independent of eosinophil count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roflumilast: Indicated for severe COPD with recurrent exacerbations due to chronic bronchitis and FEV₁ < 50%, not for this patient with mild obstruction.

 

Option B. Ipratropium: A short-acting muscarinic antagonist; redundant when the patient is already on tiotropium (LAMA). 

 

Option C. Fluticasone: It is an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) which is reserved for patients with eosinophils ≥ 300 cells/µL or ≥ 2 exacerbations/year – criteria not met here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD patients with persistent dyspnea on LAMA + LABA and low eosinophil counts, consider adding ensifentrine, a dual PDE-3/4 inhibitor that enhances bronchodilation and reduces exacerbations without the risks associated with inhaled corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with carpal tunnel syndrome. She also suffers from urinary incontinence and neuropathic pain for the last 2 months. On examination, she has hepatosplenomegaly and bruises near the eyes. Lab tests reveal proteinuria. Which is the next best step in diagnosis? (Key: EMG – Electromyography, SPEP – Serum Protein Electrophoresis)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SPEP

 

  • Amyloidosis often presents with multisystem involvement: proteinuria (renal), neuropathy (peripheral), carpal tunnel syndrome, hepatosplenomegaly, autonomic dysfunction (orthostasis, bladder and bowel disorders), restrictive cardiomyopathy, and easy bruising.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) and urine protein electrophoresis (UPEP) with immunofixation are initial tests to detect abnormal monoclonal proteins or light chains (M-proteins), which are seen in AL (light-chain) amyloidosis and other monoclonal gammopathies.​
  • These tests are sensitive for diagnosing systemic amyloidosis and identifying candidates for further targeted biopsy or therapy.

 

Other Options:


Option A. EMG: EMG is useful for neuropathy characterization, but does not detect or confirm systemic monoclonal protein disorders.


Option  C. Hepatitis B testing: Hepatitis B testing may be indicated in some cases of abnormal liver or renal function, but does not fit the multisystem, proteinuria-focused symptoms seen in amyloidosis.


Option  D. Liver biopsy: Liver biopsy may be helpful for organ-specific diagnosis but is higher risk and not first-line; SPEP/UPEP are less invasive and more appropriate for systemic workup.

 

Educational Objective:


For possible amyloidosis with proteinuria and multisystem findings, initial diagnostic work-up should include serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation to screen for monoclonal proteins and direct further investigation.

questions.text: Identify the structures highlighted in green in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebral peduncle

 

  • The structures highlighted in green are the cerebral peduncles, which are large bundles of descending white matter tracts located on the ventral surface of the midbrain.
  • They contain fibers of the corticospinal, corticobulbar, and corticopontine tracts, which carry motor information from the cerebral cortex to the brainstem and spinal cord.
  • The cerebral peduncles connect the cerebrum to the pons, forming an essential pathway for voluntary motor control.
  • They lie anterior to the tegmentum and posterior to the optic tracts and crus cerebri.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellar peduncle: Incorrect. These are three pairs of tracts (superior, middle, and inferior) connecting the cerebellum to the brainstem, located posteriorly, not anteriorly as in the image.

 

Option C. Medullary pyramids: Incorrect. These are located on the ventral medulla, containing descending corticospinal tracts, and are not part of the midbrain.

 

Option D. Inferior colliculus: Incorrect. These are dorsal midbrain structures involved in the auditory pathway, not seen in the ventral view shown here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cerebral peduncles are paired structures on the ventral midbrain that contain descending motor tracts (corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine fibers) connecting the cerebral cortex to the brainstem and spinal cord.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 38 weeks of gestation is undergoing induction of labor with oxytocin. After 4 hours of infusion, she develops 7 contractions in 10 minutes, accompanied by fetal heart rate decelerations. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine hyperstimulation

 

  • This scenario describes excessive uterine activity resulting from oxytocin infusion, leading to fetal distress (decelerations on FHR tracing).
  • The term uterine hyperstimulation (also known as uterine hypertonus) is used when increased contraction frequency or intensity is associated with abnormal fetal heart rate patterns.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Oxytocin overdose can cause uterine contractions to become too frequent or prolonged, leading to reduced uteroplacental blood flow and fetal hypoxia.
  • The combination of tachysystole + FHR decelerations defines uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Management:

 

  1. Stop oxytocin infusion immediately.
  2. Place the patient in left lateral position to improve uteroplacental perfusion.
  3. Administer oxygen via face mask.
  4. If contractions persist, give a tocolytic agent (e.g., terbutaline 0.25 mg SC) to relax the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine inertia: Incorrect. Refers to ineffective contractions causing prolonged labor, not excessive ones.

 

Option B. Uterine tachysystole: Incorrect.

 

  • Refers to >5 contractions in 10 minutes without fetal heart rate changes.
  • In this case, FHR decelerations are present → hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Uterine tetany: Incorrect. Continuous, sustained contraction without relaxation (no rhythmic pattern), often leading to fetal hypoxia or uterine rupture — not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine hyperstimulation is defined as excessive uterine contractions associated with fetal heart rate decelerations, typically due to oxytocin overuse.
  • Immediate management involves stopping oxytocin, maternal repositioning, oxygen, and if necessary, tocolysis to restore adequate uteroplacental perfusion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with an itchy, circular lesion on his thigh. The lesion has central clearing and a raised, erythematous, scaly margin. A KOH mount of skin scrapings reveals a picture as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea corporis

 

  • Tinea corporis (ringworm of the body) is a superficial dermatophyte infection caused by Trichophyton, Microsporum, or Epidermophyton species.
  • The infection typically presents as an annular (ring-shaped) lesion with central clearing and an active scaly, erythematous border that spreads peripherally.
  • KOH mount of scrapings confirms the diagnosis by showing branching, septate fungal hyphae in the stratum corneum.
  • The term “ringworm” is a misnomer since the causative organism is a fungus, not a worm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Targetoid lesions with concentric color zones; no fungal hyphae on KOH.
  • Typically associated with HSV infection or drugs.

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor:

 

  • Caused by Malassezia furfur; presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented scaly macules on trunk.
  • KOH shows “spaghetti and meatballs” appearance (hyphae and spores), not just septate hyphae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Chronic papulosquamous disorder with silvery white scales on extensor surfaces.
  • KOH negative and lacks annular pattern or central clearing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea corporis is a dermatophyte infection of the body presenting with annular scaly lesions having central clearing and raised margins, confirmed by branching septate hyphae on KOH mount.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with concerns about delayed motor development. His mother had pregnancy-induced hypertension and the baby required stimulation at birth. He has difficulty sitting without support and shows an unusual presentation of legs. On examination, he has increased tone in all limbs with upper limbs and lower limbs affected equally with hyperreflexia. Which of the following best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy based on several characteristic features. 
  • First, there are clear risk factors in the history, including pregnancy-induced hypertension in the mother and birth asphyxia requiring stimulation. 
  • Spastic quadriplegia is the most severe form of cerebral palsy and is often associated with perinatal hypoxic-ischemic injury.
  • The physical examination findings are classic for spastic quadriplegia, including increased tone in all four limbs (both upper and lower extremities), hyperreflexia, and scissoring of the legs when held upright (indicative of lower limb spasticity). 
  • The developmental delay with inability to sit independently at age 2 years indicates severe motor impairment affecting the whole body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonic cerebral palsy: This presentation would involve decreased muscle tone (floppiness) rather than the increased tone and hyperreflexia described in the case. While hypotonia can be an early presentation of cerebral palsy in some infants, by age 2, this child clearly demonstrates spasticity.

 

Option C. Ataxic cerebral palsy: This type is characterized by problems with balance, coordination, and depth perception. Tremors and intentional movements would be disrupted, but there would not be the significant spasticity, scissoring, and hyperreflexia described in this case.

 

Option D. Dyskinetic cerebral palsy: This form is characterized by involuntary, uncontrolled, recurring, occasionally stereotyped movements. The child would demonstrate slow, writhing movements (athetosis) or rapid, jerky movements (chorea) rather than the sustained increased tone described in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy presents with increased tone in all four limbs, hyperreflexia, and severe motor delays. 
  • Key risk factors include perinatal asphyxia and maternal conditions like pregnancy-induced hypertension that compromise fetal blood flow

choices.text: Admission to the hospital for IV heparin
Admission to the hospital for monitoring of clot progression and pain
Discharge home with repeat CT of the abdomen in 1 month
EGD screening for varices and initiation of anticoagulation

questions.text: A 50-year-old male veteran with HCV-related cirrhosis, hypertension, and diabetes presents with 5 days of abdominal pain. He is stable and CT reveals a heterogeneous liver, moderate ascites, no focal liver lesions, and acute portal vein thrombosis. Labs are unchanged from baseline. He feels well and requests discharge. What is the most appropriate management plan?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) EGD screening for varices and initiation of anticoagulation

 

  • In cirrhotic patients found to have acute portal vein thrombosis (PVT), the risk of portal hypertension and variceal bleeding must be addressed before starting anticoagulation.
  • EGD (Esophagogastroduodenoscopy) should be performed to screen for esophageal varices.
  • If varices are present, steps to reduce bleeding risk (e.g., banding, nonselective beta-blockers) are indicated prior to anticoagulation.
  • Once varices are ruled out or treated, anticoagulation is recommended for acute PVT to prevent clot propagation and worsening portal hypertension.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Admission to the hospital for IV heparin: Admission solely for IV heparin is inappropriate before variceal assessment; bleeding risk must be evaluated first.


Option B. Admission to the hospital for monitoring of clot progression and pain: Admission for monitoring is not needed in stable patients with no signs of worsening pain or systemic instability.


Option C. Discharge home with repeat CT of the abdomen in 1 month: Repeat CT without addressing portal hypertension misses the need for variceal evaluation and definitive management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For cirrhosis with acute portal vein thrombosis, initial management requires EGD screening for varices, with anticoagulation only after bleeding risk is evaluated and mitigated. 
  • Outpatient follow-up is suitable in stable patients after completing urgent variceal assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most commonly associated with pseudolymphoma syndrome on long-term use?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

  • Pseudolymphoma syndrome is a rare but notable hypersensitivity reaction that mimics malignant lymphoma both clinically and histologically, but is benign and reversible upon withdrawal of the offending drug.
  • Among antiepileptics, phenytoin is the most commonly implicated drug. The syndrome is characterized by:
    • Fever
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Rash
    • Eosinophilia
  • Histologically, it may resemble T-cell lymphoma, hence the term “pseudo-lymphoma.”
  • It is part of the broader anticonvulsant hypersensitivity syndrome, and may also include elevated liver enzymes and multiorgan involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Though it can also cause drug rash and systemic symptoms (DRESS), pseudolymphoma is not its classical adverse effect.

 

Option C. Sodium valproate: It has hepatotoxicity and weight gain, but not associated with pseudolymphoma.

 

Option D. Phenobarbital: Can cause rash and sedation, but pseudolymphoma is not a typical side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenytoin is the drug most classically associated with pseudolymphoma syndrome, a benign condition that mimics lymphoma and reverses upon drug withdrawal.

questions.text: A young, otherwise healthy woman presents with acute uncomplicated cystitis and requires empiric antibiotic therapy. Which of the following agents is not considered appropriate for empiric treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Norfloxacin

 

  • Fosfomycin, nitrofurantoin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) are all considered first-line empiric agents for acute uncomplicated cystitis in otherwise healthy women.​
  • Each offers effective coverage for common uropathogens, especially Escherichia coli.
  • Fosfomycin: 3 gm single-dose agent, broad coverage, limited resistance.
  • Nitrofurantoin: Well tolerated, given in a dose of 100 mg BD for 5 to 7 days, safe unless advanced renal disease.
  • TMP-SMX: Preferred where E. coli resistance rates are <20%, avoided in sulfa-allergic patients, 1 double-strength tablet given twice a day for 3 days
  • Norfloxacin is a fluoroquinolone. 
  • While once used for lower urinary tract infections, current guidelines do not recommend fluoroquinolones (including norfloxacin) as first-line empiric therapy for uncomplicated cystitis due to rising resistance, adverse effects, and concerns about collateral damage. 
  • They are reserved for more complicated or resistant cases when other options are contraindicated.​

 

Other Options:


Option A. Fosfomycin: Is a recommended first-line agent.


Option B. Nitrofurantoin: Is a recommended first-line agent for acute cystitis.


Option C. TMP-SMX: Is a first-line agent when local resistance rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:


First-line empiric treatment for uncomplicated cystitis includes fosfomycin, nitrofurantoin, and TMP-SMX, but fluoroquinolones like norfloxacin should be avoided as initial therapy due to resistance and safety concerns.

choices.text: Septum primum derived from atrial mesoderm
Conotruncal ridges derived from neural crest cells

questions.text: A newborn presents with central cyanosis, a harsh systolic murmur, and a boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray. Abnormal development of which embryologic structure is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conotruncal ridges derived from neural crest cells

 

  • The infant has Tetralogy of Fallot, evidenced by cyanosis (right-to-left shunt) and boot-shaped heart (Coeur en Sabot). 
  • This condition results from abnormal development of the conotruncal ridges, which are derived from neural crest cells (NCCs). 
  • When the spiral septum fails to develop properly in the midline and shifts, it causes: pulmonary stenosis (narrowed pulmonary valve), overriding aorta (aorta covering both ventricles), ventricular septal defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy. 
  • The NCCs are crucial for proper partitioning of the outflow tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocardial cushions derived from endoderm: Endocardial cushions are not derived from endoderm but from mesenchyme, and they primarily form the atrioventricular valves and portions of the atrial and ventricular septa. Their defects cause atrioventricular septal defects, not TOF.

 

Option B. Septum primum derived from atrial mesoderm: Septum primum forms part of the interatrial septum. Its defects lead to atrial septal defects (ASD), which cause left-to-right shunts and acyanotic heart disease, not the cyanotic presentation seen here.

 

Option D. Interventricular septum derived from ventricular myocardium: While the interventricular septum is involved in TOF with a VSD, the primary problem is the malalignment of the conotruncal septum, not the muscular interventricular septum itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot results from abnormal neural crest cell-derived conotruncal septum development, causing four defects that produce cyanotic congenital heart disease with a characteristic boot-shaped cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with long-standing hypertension is admitted with acute shortness of breath. An arterial blood gas shows a mildly elevated lactate level. The ICU team explains to a medical student that during oxidative phosphorylation, one key mitochondrial enzyme is responsible for reducing molecular oxygen to water as the final step of the electron transport chain. Which enzyme performs this function?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytochrome c oxidase 

 

  • This is Complex IV of the electron transport chain.
  • It performs the final step of oxidative phosphorylation:
    • Accepts electrons from cytochrome c
    • Transfers them to molecular oxygen (O₂)
    • Reduces O₂ to water (H₂O)
  • This enzyme is essential for aerobic metabolism and is inhibited by toxins like cyanide and carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I): Transfers electrons from NADH to ubiquinone. It does not directly act on O₂ and does not produce water.

 

Option C. Succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II): Involved in both the TCA cycle and ETC. Transfers electrons from FADH₂ to ubiquinone. Again, does not reduce oxygen.

 

Option D. ATP synthase: Uses the proton gradient to produce ATP from ADP + Pi. It plays no role in handling molecular oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) is the terminal enzyme of the electron transport chain, responsible for reducing molecular oxygen to water.
  • Inhibition of this enzyme (e.g., by cyanide or carbon monoxide) leads to cellular hypoxia, impaired oxidative phosphorylation, and lactate accumulation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a smoking history is incidentally found to have a thoracic aortic aneurysm measuring 4 cm on chest CT. When should the next imaging assessment of aneurysm size be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 - 12 months

 

  • Thoracic aortic aneurysms measuring 3.5-4.4 cm fall into a surveillance category recommending repeat imaging every 12 months to monitor for growth or progression, but first imaging should be done in 6 months and later every 12 months.​
  • Aneurysms 4.5–5.4 cm require more frequent monitoring, typically every 6 months, and ≥5.5 cm or rapid expansion (≥0.5 cm/year) prompt surgical consideration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracic aortic aneurysms measuring 3.5–4.4 cm, current guidelines recommend follow-up imaging at 6-12 months to ensure stability, with intervals adjusted based on growth rate and aneurysm size to optimize timing of surgical referral.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the type of antigenic determinant of immunoglobulins with its defining feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1–B, 2–A, 3–C

 

  • 1–B. Isotypes refer to the major classes and subclasses of immunoglobulins—IgG, IgA, IgM, IgD, and IgE—which differ in the constant regions of their heavy chains. These constant-region differences define each antibody’s biological role and effector function (e.g., complement activation, placental transfer). All members of a species share the same set of isotypes. Hence, isotypic variation distinguishes antibody classes, not individuals.
  • 2–A. Allotypes represent allelic variations within the constant region of immunoglobulin genes among individuals of the same species. These genetic differences do not alter antibody function but can elicit immune reactions if transferred between individuals (e.g., after transfusion or pregnancy).
  • 3–C. Idiotypes are the unique antigenic determinants located in the variable region (VH and VL), particularly in or near the paratope. Each idiotype reflects a specific antigen-binding structure generated through somatic recombination and hypermutation, making every antibody molecule distinct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotypes differ between antibody classes (IgG, IgA, etc.), Allotypes differ between individuals within the same species due to allelic variation in the constant region, and Idiotypes differ between antibodies within an individual, defined by the unique amino acid sequences of their variable regions.

choices.text: Conservative management with ultrasound follow-up every 4 months
Immediate staging laparotomy with total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman undergoes a routine pelvic ultrasound that reveals a 4 cm unilateral, unilocular ovarian cyst with no solid areas or septations. Her CA-125 level is 18 U/mL (normal <35 U/mL), and her Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) is 20. She is asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conservative management with ultrasound follow-up every 4 months

 

  • In postmenopausal women, the management of an ovarian cyst depends on several key factors — cyst morphology (simple vs complex), tumor marker levels (CA-125), and Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI).

 

Step 1: Understanding the RMI (Risk of Malignancy Index)

The RMI = U × M × CA-125, where:

  • U (Ultrasound score):
    • 0 = no suspicious features
    • 1 = one feature (e.g., multilocular cyst, solid areas, metastases, ascites, bilateral lesions)
    • 3 = two or more features
  • M (Menopausal status):
    • 1 = premenopausal
    • 3 = postmenopausal
  • CA-125 = measured value (U/mL)

For this patient:

  • U = 1 (simple cyst, unilocular, no solid components)
  • M = 3 (postmenopausal)
  • CA-125 = 18

RMI = 1 × 3 × 18 = 54, but as per the question, RMI = 20, still <200, which is low risk for malignancy.

 

Step 2: Management of a Low-Risk Ovarian Cyst in Postmenopausal Women

 

  • Simple cyst, <5 cm,normal CA-125, and low RMI (<200) can be managed conservatively.
  • Such women should undergo repeat ultrasound every 4–6 months to monitor cyst size and morphology.
  • If the cyst remains stable or regresses, the interval can be increased to annual follow-up or discontinued after 1 year of stability.
  • Surgery is not indicated unless the cyst grows, develops solid components, or the CA-125 rises.
  • Thus, this patient—asymptomatic, unilocular cyst, normal CA-125, RMI 20—should be managed conservatively with ultrasound surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyst aspiration for cytologic examination: Incorrect.

 

  • Aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of tumor spillage if malignant.
  • Cytology has low sensitivity and cannot reliably exclude malignancy.
  • It is only used for palliative purposes in inoperable malignancies causing ascites.

 

Option C. Immediate staging laparotomy with total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy: Incorrect.

 

  • Indicated when RMI >200 or when the cyst is complex or CA-125 is elevated.
  • This patient is low risk, so major surgery is unnecessary.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic oophorectomy with frozen section: Incorrect.

 

  • Considered for intermediate-risk lesions (RMI 25–200) or symptomatic cysts>7 cm.
  • Not indicated here, as the cyst is small, simple, and the patient is asymptomatic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In postmenopausal women, a simple ovarian cyst <7 cm, with normal CA-125 and low RMI (<200), should be managed conservatively with repeat ultrasound monitoring every 4–6 months.
  • Surgical intervention is reserved for complex, enlarging, or high-risk cysts.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with known Tetralogy of Fallot develops sudden cyanosis and breathlessness after crying. What is the immediate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give oxygen and morphine

 

“Tet spell” (hypercyanotic spell) management includes oxygen, knee-chest position, morphine, and beta-blockers to reduce infundibular spasm and increase SVR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer IV fluids and digitalis: Digitalis worsens obstruction.

 

Option C. Start furosemide: Furosemide reduces preload, worsening spell.

 

Option D. Place the child supine: Supine position decreases venous return.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypercyanotic spells (Tet spells), treatment aims to reduce right-to-left shunting with oxygen, morphine, and postural modification (knee-chest).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with pancytopenia and splenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy confirms hairy cell leukemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

  • Hairy cell leukemia (HCL) is a rare B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder that typically presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia. 
  • The disease is characterized morphologically by "hairy" projections on leukemic cells seen under microscopy.
  • Cladribine is the drug of choice for HCL. 
  • It is a purine analog (adenosine analog) that is resistant to degradation by adenosine deaminase, allowing it to accumulate in cells and cause DNA strand breaks. 
  • It is highly effective, leading to prolonged remission in most patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant used in autoimmune conditions and organ transplantation. It has no role in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is an antifolate agent used in cancers (e.g., ALL, lymphoma) and autoimmune diseases (e.g., RA, psoriasis). It is not effective for HCL.

 

Option D. Fludarabine: Fludarabine is a purine analog used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), not hairy cell leukemia. While it is effective in B-cell malignancies, cladribine is superior and specifically indicated for HCL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine is the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its potent activity and resistance to adenosine deaminase degradation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a history of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Otoscopic examination shows in the following image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glomus tumor

 

  • A glomus tumor (also called paraganglioma) is the most common vascular tumor of the middle ear. It typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus due to the tumor's vascular nature and hearing loss, often conductive in type. 
  • The presence of a red reflex behind an intact tympanic membrane (referred to as the "rising sun" sign) is characteristic and suggests a highly vascular lesion in the middle ear.

 

Key features:

 

  • Pulsatile tinnitus suggests a vascular origin.
  • Hearing loss is due to interference with the ossicular chain or middle ear function.
  • Red reflex indicates the vascularity of the tumor visible through the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesteatoma: Cholesteatoma presents with foul-smelling ear discharge, conductive hearing loss, and a retraction pocket or whitish mass in the middle ear on examination. It is not associated with pulsatile tinnitus or a red reflex.

 

 

Option B. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma is a vestibular schwannoma that causes sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus (non-pulsatile), and balance issues. It does not present with a red reflex or pulsatile tinnitus.

 

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis causes progressive conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation. It does not cause pulsatile tinnitus or a red reflex behind the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A glomus tumor is a vascular middle ear tumor that presents with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss, and a red reflex behind an intact tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent nephrolithiasis. Laboratory studies reveal increased urinary solute excretion. As filtrate passes through the PCT, the concentrations of most solutes decrease due to reabsorption. Which of the following solutes does not decrease in concentration within the proximal tubule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

  • In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), solutes such as glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate are reabsorbed very efficiently in the early segment.
  • Chloride will be absorbed 60-70% in PCT
  • As a result, their concentration in tubular fluid decreases rapidly.
  • Chloride, however, is reabsorbed less rapidly in the early PCT compared with water.
  • Since water is reabsorbed in proportion to sodium, chloride becomes relatively concentrated in the tubular fluid as it progresses down the PCT.
  • Later in the PCT, chloride is reabsorbed along with sodium, but its concentration does not decrease initially.
  • Thus, the solute that does not decrease in concentration within the proximal tubule is chloride.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bicarbonate:

 

  • Bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the early PCT through Na⁺/H⁺ exchange and carbonic anhydrase activity.
  • This reduces its concentration in tubular fluid as it moves along the PCT.
  • Bicarbonate will be absorbed 80-85% in PCT 
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option B. Glucose:

 

  • Glucose is almost completely reabsorbed in the early PCT via sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLT).
  • Its concentration in tubular fluid falls quickly and significantly.
  • Glucose will be absorbed 100% in PCT 
  • Thus, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Amino acids:

 

  • Amino acids are also actively reabsorbed in the early PCT along with sodium.
  • Their concentration in tubular fluid decreases rapidly.
  • Amino acid will be absorbed 100% in PCT
  • Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the proximal convoluted tubule, glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate are rapidly reabsorbed, leading to decreased concentrations in tubular fluid. 
  • Chloride is reabsorbed more slowly, so its relative concentration does not decrease initially.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought for orthopedic evaluation due to progressive shortening and bowing of her left leg, along with multiple pathological fractures since the age of 5. She has noticeable lumps under the skin of her hands, chest, and arms that feel like soft, compressible, dark bluish-red masses. The bony lesions with unilateral distribution are seen. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maffucci Syndrome

 

  •  This rare, non-hereditary condition is defined by the triad of multiple enchondromas (benign cartilage tumors) and multiple soft tissue hemangiomas (vascular malformations), often with a predominantly unilateral distribution.
  • Clinical Correlation:
    • Progressive shortening, bowing, pathological fractures, and unilateral bony lesions are caused by the enchondromas.
    • Soft, compressible, dark bluish-red masses under the skin are the hemangiomas.
  • Patients are at a high risk (up to 50%) for malignant transformation of the enchondromas into chondrosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ollier Disease:

 

  • Characterized by the presence of multiple enchondromas, like Maffucci syndrome, resulting in skeletal deformities and pathological fractures.
  • Ollier disease lacks the associated hemangiomas (vascular lesions). 
  • The presence of both bony and soft-tissue vascular tumors in the case rules out pure Ollier disease.

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1):

 

  • A common neurocutaneous disorder involving the skin, nervous system, and bones.
  • NF1 is defined by café-au-lait macules, cutaneous and plexiform neurofibromas, Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas), and frequently causes skeletal abnormalities like pseudarthrosis of the tibia or scoliosis. 
  • It does not typically cause the combination of multiple widespread enchondromas and hemangiomas described.

 

Option C. Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome:

 

  • A congenital condition characterized by a triad of port-wine stain (capillary malformation), venous malformations (often varicose veins), and limb hypertrophy (overgrowth of the limb).
  • While it involves vascular lesions, it presents primarily as limb overgrowth and a distinct skin stain and does not involve multiple enchondromas or lead to the severe skeletal bowing and fractures characteristic of the enchondromatosis syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary educational objective is to differentiate between the enchondromatosis syndromes, specifically by recognizing that Maffucci Syndrome is defined by the unique combination of multiple enchondromas (bony lesions) and multiple hemangiomas (vascular lesions), a combination not found in the other common differential diagnoses like Ollier disease.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a barking cough, stridor and hoarseness. A neck X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Croup 

 

  • The clinical presentation of barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness, along with the X-ray finding of the steeple sign (narrowing of the subglottic trachea), is highly characteristic of croup.
  • Croup, or laryngotracheobronchitis, is a viral infection (commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus) that leads to inflammation and edema of the upper airway, particularly in the subglottic region.
  • The steeple sign on X-ray represents the narrowing of the subglottic airway due to inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis: Epiglottitis presents with a sudden onset of high fever, drooling, severe distress, and a "tripod position." The lateral neck X-ray shows a thumbprint sign, not the steeple sign.

 

 

Option C. Foreign body aspiration: Foreign body aspiration can cause stridor but typically presents with sudden onset and focal airway obstruction. Radiographs may show a visible foreign body or air trapping, but the steeple sign is not seen.

 

Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess: Retropharyngeal abscess is characterized by fever, dysphagia, and neck stiffness. The lateral neck X-ray shows widening of the prevertebral space, not the steeple sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steeple sign on an X-ray, along with barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness, is diagnostic of croup, a viral infection causing subglottic airway inflammation.

questions.text: When placed in a saturated salt solution, the egg shown in the image below behaves in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sinks to the bottom

 

  • The image shows an unfertilized egg of Ascaris lumbricoides.
  • Key identifying features include:
    • Elongated shape (approx. 90 µm × 45 µm)
    • Thin or absent albuminous coat
    • Bile-stained brown color
    • Irregular refractile granules filling the interior

 

Diagnostic Property:
