  • Unlike fertilized eggs, the unfertilized eggs are heavier and do not float in saturated salt or zinc sulfate solutions used in stool concentration techniques.

 

 

  • Hence, in a flotation test, unfertilized eggs sink to the bottom of the solution.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Floats on the surface: Seen with fertilized Ascaris eggs, which are lighter due to the thick mammillated coat.

 

Option C. Hatches into a larva: Unfertilized eggs contain disorganized cytoplasmic material and cannot develop into larvae.

 

Option D. Loses its bile staining: Bile staining persists; it does not fade upon suspension in salt solution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are elongated, bile-stained, and contain refractile granules with a thin or absent albuminous coat.
  • They are non-infective and sink in saturated salt solution — a key laboratory differentiator from fertilized eggs.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Chronic Myeloid Leukemia are correct?

 

  1. CML is characterized by a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 leading to formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  2. The BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase increases apoptosis and decreases proliferation of myeloid cells.
  3. The accelerated phase is defined by increasing basophils, rising WBC counts, and 10–19% blasts in bone marrow or blood.
  4. The blast crisis resembles acute leukemia and is diagnosed when blasts exceed 20%.
  5. Imatinib and other tyrosine kinase inhibitors target the ATP-binding site of the BCR-ABL fusion protein.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1, 3, 4 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. CML is characterized by a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 leading to formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene: Correct. CML is caused by a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, known as the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)(q34;q11)).

 

  • This translocation fuses the BCR gene (on chromosome 22) with the ABL gene (on chromosome 9), forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • The resulting BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase promotes uncontrolled myeloid proliferation.

 

Statement 3. The accelerated phase is defined by increasing basophils, rising WBC counts, and 10–19% blasts in bone marrow or blood: Correct. The accelerated phase of CML is characterized by:

 

  • 10–19% blasts in blood or bone marrow,
  • Increasing basophils, and
  • Rising WBC counts despite therapy.

 

Statement 4. The blast crisis resembles acute leukemia and is diagnosed when blasts exceed 20%: Correct. The blast crisis phase represents transformation to an acute leukemia-like state, defined by ≥20% blasts in blood or bone marrow. This marks the terminal stage of the disease with poor prognosis.

 

Statement 5.Imatinib and other tyrosine kinase inhibitors target the ATP-binding site of the BCR-ABL fusion protein → no phosphorylation → no downstream signaling: Correct. Imatinib (a tyrosine kinase inhibitor) specifically binds to the ATP-binding site of the BCR-ABL fusion protein, preventing phosphorylation and downstream signaling. This inhibits uncontrolled myeloid proliferation and induces apoptosis in leukemic cells.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. The BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase increases apoptosis and decreases proliferation of myeloid cells: Incorrect. The BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase causes increased proliferation, reduced apoptosis, and enhanced survival of myeloid cells. It does not increase apoptosis; rather, it inhibits normal cell death mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is characterized by a BCR-ABL fusion gene resulting from a t(9;22) translocation, producing a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that increases myeloid proliferation and inhibits apoptosis.
  • The blast crisis phase occurs when blasts exceed 20%, and Imatinib acts by blocking the ATP-binding site of the BCR-ABL protein to inhibit downstream signaling.

choices.text: Perinephric collection (pus in the perinephric space)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever, chills, right flank pain, and dysuria for the past two days. Urinalysis shows pyuria and positive leukocyte esterase. Ultrasound of the abdomen is performed to assess for renal involvement. Which of the following findings is least likely to be observed on renal ultrasound in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased vascularity

 

  • In acute pyelonephritis, ultrasound findings primarily reflect inflammation and edema of the renal parenchyma rather than increased blood flow. 
  • The typical sonographic features include:
    • Enlarged kidney due to edema and inflammation
    • Focal areas of hypoechogenicity representing focal inflammation or abscess formation
    • Perinephric fluid collections may be seen if infection extends beyond the renal capsule
  • However, increased vascularity is not a typical feature, as infection and edema actually decrease perfusion, often leading to areas of reduced or absent vascular flow on Doppler imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grossly enlarged kidney: Seen due to acute inflammatory swelling.

 

Option B. Focal area of hypoechogenicity: Common finding caused by focal inflammation or edema.

 

Option C. Perinephric collection (pus in the perinephric space): Indicates extension of infection outside the renal capsule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ultrasound in acute pyelonephritis helps identify renal enlargement, focal inflammation, and perinephric extension.
  • Key point: Reduced — not increased — vascularity is typical, helping differentiate infection from hypervascular tumors.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man complains of burning pain during urination. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse four days ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus causing gonococcal urethritis. 
  • It typically presents with burning micturition and thick, purulent urethral discharge 2–7 days after unprotected sexual contact. 
  • Gram stain of urethral discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci inside polymorphonuclear leukocytes. 
  • It is a highly contagious sexually transmitted infection, often coexisting with Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes nongonococcal urethritis with a thinner, mucoid discharge and longer incubation period (1–3 weeks). It does not show diplococci on Gram stain.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma genitalium: Also causes nongonococcal urethritis but produces milder symptoms and is less purulent. It lacks a cell wall, so Gram staining is ineffective.

 

Option C. Trichomonas vaginalis: A protozoal infection leading to frothy, greenish discharge in women and may cause mild urethritis in men, but not a thick purulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gonococcal urethritis presents with an acute onset of painful urination and thick purulent discharge after unprotected sexual exposure, typically caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 
  • Gram-negative diplococci seen on smear confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with decompensated congestive heart failure is admitted after failed outpatient diuresis, rapid weight gain, and persistent dyspnea. Despite significant diuresis with high-dose IV loop diuretics, he remains volume overloaded and his ABG shows the following - pH 7.51, PaCO2 52 mmHg and HCO3 45 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add acetazolamide

 

  • This patient developed metabolic alkalosis due to prolonged, high-dose loop diuretic therapy, which promotes sodium, chloride, and water loss, increased distal sodium delivery, and H⁺ secretion.
  • Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, increases urinary bicarbonate excretion and can correct alkalosis while continuing diuresis—a key goal in patients who remain fluid overloaded.
  • Acetazolamide is particularly useful for correcting metabolic alkalosis while maintaining effective volume control, and is appropriate for patients who cannot tolerate volume repletion with saline.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Add amiloride: A potassium-sparing diuretic, helpful for preventing hypokalemia, but not for correcting diuretic-induced alkalosis.


Option C. Add spironolactone: Useful for heart failure management, but does not directly correct metabolic alkalosis.


Option D. Infuse normal saline: This can reverse diuretic-induced alkalosis by restoring sodium/chloride and volume, but is inappropriate here due to ongoing hypervolemia (persistent volume overload and supplemental oxygen requirement); fluid would worsen his heart failure status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acetazolamide is the preferred therapy for diuretic-induced metabolic alkalosis when fluid overload precludes volume repletion. 
  • It enables correction of alkalosis while maintaining diuretic effect and limiting additional fluid accumulation.

questions.text: What is the operating temperature of the cold chain equipment shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) +2 to +8 degrees

 

  • The image above is of an Ice-Lined-Refrigerator which is the primary cold chain equipment used at PHCs.
  • An ILR maintains the temperature between +2°C and +8°C. An ILR is used to store all Universal Immunization Program vaccines at the Public Health Centre (PHC) level.
  • An ILR can maintain a temperature from +2°C to +8°C with as little as 8 hours of power supply in 24 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ice-Lined Refrigerators (ILR) are used for storing the majority of routine vaccines (e.g., DPT, Measles). The mandatory operating range is +2 to +8 degrees
  • Maintaining the correct, narrow temperature range is essential to prevent vaccine or product degradation due to freezing (damage to most vaccines) or overheating (loss of potency).

questions.text: A molecular biologist compares gene activity in normal and cancerous cells using a DNA microarray. Labeled complementary DNA (cDNA) from both samples is applied to a chip containing thousands of DNA probes, and the resulting fluorescence pattern is analyzed. Which fundamental molecular principle enables this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hybridization

 

  • DNA microarrays (gene chips) work on the principle of nucleic acid hybridization—the ability of complementary DNA strands to base-pair with each other.
  • In this method, DNA probes corresponding to thousands of genes are fixed on a solid surface. 
  • Labeled cDNA (derived from the mRNA of the sample) is applied to the chip. 
  • If a gene in the sample is expressed, its cDNA will hybridize (bind) to its complementary probe on the chip. 
  • The amount of hybridization is measured by detecting the fluorescence intensity at each spot, reflecting the level of gene expression.
  • Hybridization allows parallel detection of thousands of gene sequences simultaneously, enabling comparison between normal and diseased tissues, identification of mutations, or assessment of gene expression profiles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR amplifies DNA sequences exponentially using primers and DNA polymerase. It is highly sensitive for detecting and quantifying specific genes but does not involve large-scale, parallel hybridization as in microarrays.

 

Option B. Cloning: Cloning involves inserting DNA fragments into vectors to propagate identical copies within host cells. It is used for gene manipulation and protein expression, not for high-throughput detection of gene mutations.

 

Option C. Southern blotting: Southern blotting is used to detect specific DNA fragments after electrophoresis via hybridization with a labeled probe. Although it also uses hybridization, it analyzes one or few genes at a time, unlike microarrays which assess thousands simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA microarrays detect gene mutations and expression changes through nucleic acid hybridization between sample cDNA and complementary DNA probes fixed on a chip.

choices.text: PAS stain showing hyphae within hair follicles and dermis
Broad aseptate hyphae in necrotic tissue

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic findings best confirms the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PAS stain showing hyphae within hair follicles and dermis

 

  • The image depicts Majocchi’s granuloma, a deep follicular dermatophytosis caused most commonly by Trichophyton rubrum.
  • The infection occurs when dermatophytes invade the dermis through damaged hair follicles, often following shaving or misuse of potent topical corticosteroids on tinea lesions.

 

Diagnostic finding:

 

  • On histopathology, Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) or Grocott’s methenamine silver (GMS) stain demonstrates fungal hyphae within hair follicles and extending into the dermis, confirming the diagnosis.
  • A granulomatous inflammatory response with lymphocytes, macrophages, and giant cells is characteristic.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acid-fast bacilli in Ziehl–Neelsen stain: Seen in Mycobacterium infections (e.g., lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma), not in dermatophyte infections.

 

Option C. Broad aseptate hyphae in necrotic tissue: Characteristic of mucormycosis, not Majocchi’s granuloma.

 

Option D. Sclerotic bodies on KOH mount: Diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis, where brown, thick-walled “Medlar bodies” are seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Majocchi’s granuloma is a deep folliculitis caused by dermatophytes, typically Trichophyton rubrum.
  • It is confirmed histologically by PAS or GMS stains showing fungal hyphae within hair follicles and dermis, especially in patients with steroid-modified or recurrent tinea infections.

choices.text: Excessive endolymph in the inner ear

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, aural fullness, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. She is diagnosed with Meniere's disease. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Excessive endolymph in the inner ear

 

  • Meniere's disease is characterized by endolymphatic hydrops, a condition where excessive endolymph accumulates in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear. 
  • This increased volume and pressure within the inner ear disrupt normal cochlear and vestibular function, leading to the classic triad of symptoms:
    1. Recurrent episodes of vertigo.
    2. Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss (initially unilateral).
    3. Tinnitus and/or aural fullness.
  • The excessive endolymph affects both auditory (cochlear) and vestibular structures, causing the described symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive production of perilymph: Perilymph is the fluid located in the bony labyrinth, surrounding the membranous labyrinth. Excess perilymph is not associated with the pathogenesis of Meniere’s disease.

 

Option B. Atrophy of the cochlear nerve: Atrophy of the cochlear nerve could lead to sensorineural hearing loss but does not explain the episodic vertigo or the fluctuating nature of the hearing loss seen in Meniere’s disease.

 

Option D. Blockage of the Eustachian tube: Blockage of the Eustachian tube is associated with middle ear pathologies, such as otitis media or barotrauma. It does not cause the inner ear dysfunction seen in Meniere’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meniere's disease is caused by endolymphatic hydrops, where excessive endolymph in the inner ear disrupts auditory and vestibular function, resulting in vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of COPD and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and progressive dyspnea. He recently recovered from an influenza-like illness treated with oseltamivir. On examination, he is tachypneic, BP = 92/56 mmHg, HR = 118/min, and SpO₂ = 86% on room air. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral multilobar infiltrates. ABG shows - pH 7.29, PaCO₂ 48 mmHg, PaO₂ 56 mmHg on 6 L O₂. Labs: WBC 19,000/µL, BUN 32 mg/dL, Na⁺ 129 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin + Levofloxacin

 

  • This patient meets major criteria for severe community-acquired pneumonia (CAP):
    • Hypotension (SBP < 90 mmHg)
    • Hypoxemia (PaO₂ < 60 mmHg)
    • Multilobar infiltrates
  • The recent influenza infection is a key clue — post-influenza severe pneumonia is classically associated with Staphylococcus aureus, including MRSA.
  • Hence, empiric coverage must include:
    • A β-lactam (e.g., ceftriaxone) for Streptococcus pneumoniae and H. influenzae
    • A fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin) or macrolide for atypical pathogens (Legionella, Mycoplasma, Chlamydia)
    • An anti-MRSA agent (vancomycin or linezolid) to cover post-influenza S. aureus infection
  • Thus, the optimal empiric regimen is Ceftriaxone + Levofloxacin + Vancomycin.
  • Once cultures and nasal PCR are negative for MRSA, vancomycin can be de-escalated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin: Suitable for non-severe inpatient CAP, but lacks MRSA coverage in post-influenza pneumonia.

 

Option B. Piperacillin–tazobactam + Doxycycline: Pseudomonal coverage is unnecessary here (no structural lung disease or recent hospitalization). Misses MRSA as well. 

 

Option D. Linezolid alone: Provides MRSA coverage but no activity against Gram-negatives or atypicals; inadequate as monotherapy for CAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-influenza severe community-acquired pneumonia is strongly associated with MRSA.
  • Empiric therapy should include:
    • β-lactam (ceftriaxone/ampicillin-sulbactam)
    • Fluoroquinolone or macrolide
    • MRSA coverage (vancomycin or linezolid)
  • Broad antipseudomonal therapy is reserved for patients with specific risk factors such as prior colonization, recent hospitalization, or structural lung disease.

questions.text: In India, the largest share of current health expenditure comes from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Out-of-pocket expenditure by households

 

  • In India, out-of-pocket expenditure by households constitutes approximately 50% of current health expenditure, making it the largest source. 
  • This high proportion of direct payments by families creates significant financial barriers, often leading to catastrophic health expenditure and impoverishment. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central government expenditure: Central government expenditure contributes only about 15% of current health expenditure in India.

 

Option B. State government expenditure: State government expenditure accounts for approximately 22% of current health expenditure, less than out-of-pocket payments.

 

Option D. International aid and donor funding: International aid and donor funding constitute less than 5% of total healthcare financing in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Out-of-pocket expenditure is the predominant source of healthcare financing in India (50%)
  • High out-of-pocket payments lead to financial hardship and limited access to healthcare services

choices.text: Reassure patient with no change in medical therapy

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with hypertension presents with exertional chest pain relieved by rest. He is on aspirin and lisinopril. His exercise treadmill test shows he reached 90% of max HR, had chest pain at peak exercise, and nonspecific ECG changes. Perfusion imaging reveals mild lateral wall ischemia and a preserved LVEF (65%). What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate β-blocker and statin

 

  • This patient has stable angina confirmed by exercise-induced ischemia in a single coronary territory with preserved LV function.
  • The recommended next step is to start optimal medical therapy (OMT): β-blocker (reduces heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand), statin (reduces LDL and stabilizes plaques), continuation of aspirin (antiplatelet), and as-needed nitroglycerin for symptom relief.
  • Coronary angiography is reserved for high-risk stress findings (extensive ischemia, reduced EF, hypotensive response), refractory symptoms, or failed OMT.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Perform a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): TTE is not needed when LVEF is already documented as normal and there’s no sign of heart failure.


Option C. Reassure patient with no change in medical therapy: Reassurance alone is inadequate; stress testing confirmed ischemia, necessitating intensification of therapy to prevent CAD progression.


Option D. Refer for coronary angiography: Coronary angiography is unnecessary unless symptoms persist despite OMT, or if stress testing demonstrates multiple high-risk features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with stable angina and mild ischemia should be started on a β-blocker and statin as part of OMT before considering invasive evaluation.
  • Symptom and risk-factor control are key for long-term outcomes.

questions.text: A microbiologist inoculates a CSF sample on non-nutrient agar seeded with E. coli and observes a trail sign. The causative organism fails to grow when NaCl concentration exceeds 0.4%. Which organism is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naegleria fowleri

 

  • The described culture findings — growth on non-nutrient agar with E. coli lawn, formation of a trail sign, and failure to grow in >0.4% NaCl — are diagnostic of Naegleria fowleri, the causative agent of Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • Culture feature: Naegleria trophozoites move along the E. coli lawn, producing a clear trail (path of feeding).
  • NaCl sensitivity: It cannot tolerate saline concentration above 0.4%, helping to differentiate it from Acanthamoeba spp.
  • Infective form: The trophozoite (amoeboid form) is the infective stage, entering via nasal mucosa during swimming in warm freshwater.
  • Clinical course: Rapidly progressive, acute and fatal meningoencephalitis, with neutrophilic CSF resembling bacterial meningitis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acanthamoeba spp: Causes Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE) and Amoebic keratitis; more chronic course, grows despite high NaCl, and contains both cyst and trophozoite stages.

 

Option C. Balamuthia mandrillaris: Causes GAE similar to Acanthamoeba but does not grow on E. coli-seeded agar and requires cell culture for isolation.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Pathogenic amoeba causing intestinal amebiasis and liver abscess, not CNS infection; grows on Robinson’s or Locke–Egg medium, not non-nutrient agar.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Naegleria fowleri causes Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis, typically in healthy individuals exposed to warm freshwater.
  • It grows on non-nutrient agar with E. coli lawn, produces a trail sign, and is inhibited by >0.4% NaCl, distinguishing it from Acanthamoeba.

questions.text: Which of the following medications exhibits gametocidal activity against all species of Plasmodium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primaquine

 

  • Primaquine is unique among antimalarial drugs because it targets the sexual stages (gametocytes) of all Plasmodium species, including P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. ovale, and P. malariae.
  • Additionally, primaquine is the only drug that can eradicate hypnozoites (dormant liver forms) of P. vivax and P. ovale, making it essential for preventing relapses.
  • This dual action—against both liver forms and gametocytes—makes primaquine especially valuable in interrupting malaria transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Acts on erythrocytic schizonts, not gametocytes of P. falciparum. It does not have gametocidal action against all species. It acts only against the gametocytes of P. vivax species. 

 

Option C. Quinine: Primarily targets blood schizonts, and has limited or no gametocidal activity. Not effective in clearing gametocytes across all species. It acts only against the gametocytes of P. vivax species. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primaquine is the only antimalarial with gametocidal activity across all Plasmodium species and is used to prevent relapse in infections caused by P. vivax and P. ovale.

choices.text: Eosin - causes liver toxicity and is carcinogenic
Metanil yellow - causes gastric irritation and is potentially carcinogenic
Rhodamine B - causes thyroid dysfunction and reproductive toxicity
Malachite green - causes respiratory irritation and skin sensitization

questions.text: The image shows a laboratory test result for detecting adulteration in a commonly used lentil. The pink coloration observed indicates the presence of a specific adulterant. What is the most likely adulterant detected and the health hazard it poses?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metanil yellow - causes gastric irritation and is potentially carcinogenic

 

  • The pink coloration in the chemical test indicates the presence of metanil yellow, a commonly used adulterant in lentils. 
  • Metanil yellow is an industrial dye that is added to enhance the yellow color of lentils. 
  • The concentrated HCl test produces a characteristic pink color when metanil yellow is present. 
  • This adulterant can cause gastric irritation, diarrhea, and has potential carcinogenic properties, making it a significant public health concern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eosin - causes liver toxicity and is carcinogenic: Eosin is a fluorescent red dye used in histology, most notably as a counterstain with hematoxylin. This is a distractor option, if the “adulterant” word is missed, Eosin might be selected because of the pink color.

 

Option C. Rhodamine B - causes thyroid dysfunction and reproductive toxicity: Rhodamine B detection involves different testing methods and shows fluorescent properties under UV light.

 

Option D. Malachite green - causes respiratory irritation and skin sensitization: Malachite green is typically found in fish and poultry products and requires different detection methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metanil yellow is a common adulterant in lentils and turmeric that can be detected by the characteristic pink color reaction with concentrated HCl
  • Food adulteration poses significant health risks including gastric irritation and potential carcinogenic effects

questions.text: In health planning, the step that involves determining the order of precedence for various health problems based on magnitude, severity, and available resources is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Priority setting

 

  • Priority setting is a crucial step in health planning that involves determining which health problems should be addressed first based on specific criteria such as magnitude of the problem, severity, feasibility of intervention, and availability of resources. 
  • This systematic approach ensures optimal utilization of limited resources and maximum health impact. 
  • Priority setting typically follows situation analysis and precedes resource allocation in the health planning cycle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Situation analysis: Situation analysis is the initial step that involves assessing the current health status and identifying health problems but does not involve prioritizing them.

 

Option C. Resource allocation: Resource allocation comes after priority setting and involves distributing available resources according to the established priorities.

 

Option D. Implementation planning: Implementation planning is a later step that involves developing specific strategies and timelines for executing the planned interventions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Health planning follows a systematic sequence: situation analysis → priority setting → resource allocation → implementation
  • Priority setting uses criteria like magnitude, severity, feasibility, and resource availability
  • Proper priority setting ensures efficient use of limited healthcare resources for maximum population benefit

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with malignant hypertension is found to have linear hyperpigmented streaks along the choroidal vessels on fundoscopic examination. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Siegrist streaks

 

  • Siegrist streaks are linear hyperpigmentation along the choroidal vessels seen in malignant hypertension due to fibrinoid necrosis of the choroidal arterioles. 
  • This occurs due to severe, uncontrolled hypertension, which leads to ischemic damage in the choroid, followed by hyperpigmentation along the affected vessels.

 

Pathophysiology of Siegrist Streaks:

 

  1. Hypertension-induced vascular damage → Choroidal arteriole fibrinoid necrosis.
  2. Ischemia and subsequent RPE damage → Hyperpigmentation along the choroidal vessels.
  3. Fundoscopic appearance: Linear streaks following the course of the choroidal vessels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elsching’s spots:

 

  • These are focal infarcts of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to choroidal ischemia in malignant hypertension.
  • They appear as discrete, small, white lesions in the posterior pole of the fundus.
  • Unlike Siegrist streaks, which are linear, Elsching’s spots are round and focal.

 

 

Option B. Bonnet sign:

 

  • Seen in Grade III hypertensive retinopathy.
  • It refers to banking of veins distal to the arteriovenous (AV) crossing due to arteriolar narrowing and compression of the vein.
  • It is not associated with choroidal damage.

 

Option D. Salu’s sign:

 

  • Seen in Grade II hypertensive retinopathy.
  • It describes the deflection of veins at AV crossings due to arteriosclerosis.
  • Unlike Siegrist streaks, it does not indicate choroidal ischemia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Siegrist streaks are a characteristic feature of malignant hypertension, representing hyperpigmented linear streaks along the choroidal vessels due to fibrinoid necrosis of the choroidal arterioles. 
  • This differentiates them from Elsching’s spots, which are focal RPE infarcts, and Bonnet and Salu’s signs, which are features of hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Note: Hypertensive Retinopathy

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman presents at 28 weeks gestation. Her first-trimester TSH level was 3.2 mIU/L. Based on pregnancy-specific reference ranges, how should this result be interpreted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subclinical hypothyroidism

 

  • During pregnancy, thyroid physiology changes due to the effects of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and estrogen:
    • hCG has a TSH-like effect, leading to a physiologic decrease in TSH, especially in the first trimester.
    • Therefore, pregnancy-specific reference ranges for TSH are lower than those for non-pregnant women.
  • Trimester-Specific TSH Reference Ranges (approximate WHO/ATA values):
    • First trimester: 0.1 – 2.5 mIU/L
    • Second trimester: 0.2 – 3.0 mIU/L
    • Third trimester: 0.3 – 3.0 mIU/L
  • Since this woman’s first-trimester TSH is 3.2 mIU/L, it is above the upper limit (2.5 mIU/L) for that trimester.
  • If her free T4 (FT4) levels are normal, this represents subclinical hypothyroidism (elevated TSH with normal FT4).
  • If FT4 were low, it would indicate overt hypothyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal for first trimester: Incorrect. The upper limit of normal for TSH in the first trimester is 2.5 mIU/L; 3.2 is above that.

 

Option C. Overt hypothyroidism: Incorrect. Would require elevated TSH with low free T4, which is not described here.

 

Option D. Gestational thyrotoxicosis: Incorrect. Characterized by low TSH due to high hCG, not elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During the first trimester, normal TSH levels are lower due to the stimulatory effect of hCG on the thyroid.
  • A TSH >2.5 mIU/L with normal free T4 during early pregnancy indicates subclinical hypothyroidism, which should be monitored and treated if persistent, especially in women with anti-TPO antibodies or a history of infertility or miscarriage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who is breastfeeding her child presents with symptoms of mild depression. What is the management of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

 

  • In mild depression, both SSRIs and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) have been found to be equally effective.
  • However, in a breastfeeding patient, where there is a need to avoid pharmacological exposure to the infant, CBT is preferred as the first-line management option.
  • If the symptoms do not improve or worsen, pharmacotherapy (preferably Sertraline, due to its safety in lactation) can be considered later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sertraline: Safest SSRI in lactating women; preferred if symptoms are moderate or persistent, but not first choice in mild depression when therapy can suffice.

 

Option C. Sertraline plus CBT: Indicated when depression is moderate to severe or when a single modality fails.

 

Option D. Venlafaxine: SNRI with higher excretion in breast milk; not preferred during lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In mild depression, SSRIs and CBT are equally effective, but in a breastfeeding woman, CBT is preferred initially to avoid infant drug exposure.
  • If pharmacotherapy becomes necessary, Sertraline is the safest antidepressant option during lactation.

choices.text: Stop sacubitril/valsartan and give IV fluids
Begin continuous renal replacement therapy immediately

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (LVEF 25%) and stage 3b chronic kidney disease (baseline creatinine 1.8 mg/dL) is admitted with worsening dyspnea, orthopnea, and peripheral edema. His BP = 94/60 mmHg, JVP = 14 cm H₂O, and chest radiograph shows pulmonary congestion. After IV furosemide 80 mg twice daily, his urine output remains 20ml per hour. S. Na is 130 mEq/L and S. K is 4.2 mEq/L. He is already on carvedilol 12.5 mg BID, sacubitril/valsartan 49/51 mg BID, and empagliflozin 10 mg daily. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate Metolazone 

 

  • This patient has acute decompensated heart failure with cardiorenal syndrome (type 1) - acute kidney injury precipitated by venous congestion and reduced renal perfusion.
  • Despite adequate IV loop diuretics, he remains oliguric with volume overload, suggesting diuretic resistance due to distal nephron sodium reabsorption.
  • Next step: Add a thiazide-type diuretic (metolazone or chlorothiazide) for sequential nephron blockade.
    • Enhances natriuresis, overcomes loop diuretic resistance.
    • Must monitor closely for hyponatremia and hypokalemia.
  • Continue guideline-directed medical therapy (ARNI, β-blocker, SGLT2 inhibitor) unless there is symptomatic hypotension or severe renal dysfunction (eGFR < 20).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low-dose dopamine infusion: No proven renal or mortality benefit (ROSE-AHF, DAD-HF trials); increases arrhythmia risk.

 

Option C. Stop sacubitril/valsartan and give IV fluids: Contraindicated patient is volume overloaded; worsening congestion would further reduce renal function.

 

Option D. Begin continuous renal replacement therapy immediately: Reserved for refractory volume overload, severe hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, or uremic symptoms; not indicated before trying combination diuretic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cardiorenal syndrome (type 1), when loop diuretics alone are ineffective, sequential nephron blockade with a thiazide-type diuretic (e.g., metolazone) is the evidence-based next step before considering ultrafiltration or CRRT.
  • Avoid dopamine or fluid loading, which worsen outcomes in congestive cardiorenal states.

questions.text: A patient with complete unilateral blindness is examined in a dark room. When a light is directed into the blind eye, no response is observed in either eye. However, when light is directed into the normal eye, both pupils constrict. Which of the following best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complete optic nerve lesion

 

  • A complete optic nerve lesion causes unilateral blindness and eliminates the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex, known as Total Afferent Pupillary Defect (TAPD).
  • Light in the blind eye produces no response, but light in the normal eye elicits a normal direct and consensual response because the efferent pathway remains intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Afferent pupillary defect (Marcus Gunn pupil): Causes paradoxical dilation of both pupils when light is swung to the affected eye, but not complete loss of response.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve palsy: Causes a dilated, non-reactive pupil but does not explain the findings in this scenario.

 

Option D. Adie’s tonic pupil: Causes a sluggish pupil reaction, but not complete loss of response in one eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In unilateral blindness, light directed into the blind eye produces no response, but light directed into the normal eye elicits normal pupillary constriction. 
  • This indicates a complete optic nerve lesion.

 

Pupillary Abnormalities:

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is evaluated for fatigue and muscle wasting during a prolonged illness. During periods of fasting, some amino acids can generate intermediates for the TCA cycle (supporting glucose production) while also forming acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate (supporting ketone formation). Which of the following amino acids is both glucogenic and ketogenic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isoleucine

 

  • Isoleucine is one of the few amino acids that is both glucogenic and ketogenic.
  • It forms succinyl-CoA → supports gluconeogenesis
  • It forms acetyl-CoA → supports ketogenesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Incorrect. Valine is purely glucogenic, forming succinyl-CoA. No role in ketone production.

 

Option C. Histidine: Incorrect. Histidine is purely glucogenic, forming α-ketoglutarate.

 

Option D. Lysine: Incorrect. Lysine is purely ketogenic. It produces acetoacetyl-CoA but cannot be converted to glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoleucine is one of the amino acids that is both glucogenic and ketogenic, producing succinyl-CoA (for glucose synthesis) and acetyl-CoA (for ketone synthesis) during catabolism.

 

Note: 

 

  • Pure Ketogenic AA: Leucine and Lysine 
  • Both Ketogenic and Glucogenic AA: Tyrosine, Tryptophan, Isoleucine and Phenylalanine

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with osteoporosis is prescribed a drug that decreases bone resorption by inhibiting RANKL activity. Which of the following drugs corresponds to this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Denosumab

 

  • Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor Kappa-Β Ligand), a key inhibitor of osteoclast formation and activity.  
  • By inhibiting RANKL, denosumab reduces bone resorption and is commonly used to treat osteoporosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alendronate: A bisphosphonate that reduces bone resorption by binding hydroxyapatite in bone and inhibiting osteoclast activity. It inhibits the osteoclast activity by inhibiting the phospholipid pathway.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: A recombinant parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates bone formation (osteoblasts) rather than inhibiting resorption.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: A selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that reduces bone turnover by mimicking estrogen's effects on bone and inhibiting osteoclasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Denosumab inhibits RANKL activity, reducing osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and is used in osteoporosis management.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being reviewed for adjustment of his medications. Which of the following statements are correct?

 

  1. Metformin acts by increasing hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  2. Pramlintide is approved for type 1 diabetes mellitus
  3. Thiazolidinediones are contraindicated in heart failure.
  4. Bromocriptine acts via dopamine receptor agonism to reduce blood glucose.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 2. Pramlintide is approved for type 1 diabetes mellitus: Correct. Pramlintide is a synthetic analog of amylin, a hormone co-secreted with insulin. It delays gastric emptying, suppresses glucagon, and enhances satiety, leading to reduction in postprandial glucose levels. It's FDA-approved for adjunct use with mealtime insulin in type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

 

Statement 3. Thiazolidinediones are contraindicated in heart failure: Correct. Thiazolidinediones like pioglitazone and rosiglitazone activate PPAR-γ, improving insulin sensitivity. However, they can cause fluid retention, leading to worsening of congestive heart failure. Hence, they are contraindicated in NYHA Class III-IV HF.

 

Statement 4. Bromocriptine acts via dopamine receptor agonism to reduce blood glucose: Correct. Bromocriptine is a D₂-receptor agonist, and its antidiabetic effect is believed to stem from resetting circadian dopamine activity, which improves insulin sensitivity and lowers blood glucose. It's approved for type 2 diabetes.

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

Statement 1. Metformin acts by increasing hepatic gluconeogenesis: This is incorrect. Metformin decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis (glucose production by the liver), which is one of its primary mechanisms. It also improves peripheral glucose uptake and insulin sensitivity, without increasing insulin secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metformin inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis — not stimulates it.
  • Pramlintide is an amylin analog used with insulin to reduce post-meal glucose spikes.
  • TZDs are contraindicated in patients with heart failure due to risk of fluid retention.
  • Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, has a novel role in glycemic control in T2DM.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man believes that his wife is having an affair with one of the neighbours. He has installed extensive surveillance equipment to confirm his suspicion. Despite having no evidence to support his belief, he continues to repeatedly question his wife about the alleged affair. There are no hallucinations, and he remains well adjusted in his professional life. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delusional Disorder

 

  • Delusional Disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more non-bizarre delusions lasting at least one month, without other prominent psychotic features such as hallucinations, disorganized speech, or behavior.
  • Apart from the delusion, the individual’s functioning remains relatively preserved.
  • In this case, the patient’s fixed false belief of infidelity without supporting evidence and preserved occupational functioning is characteristic of a delusional disorder, jealous type (Othello syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: Incorrect. Schizophrenia involves multiple psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganization, negative symptoms) with social and occupational dysfunction, which are absent here.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective Disorder: Incorrect. Requires the presence of mood symptoms (mania or depression) concurrent with schizophrenia-like symptoms.

 

Option D. Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder: Incorrect. This psychotic disorder has an acute onset (within 2 weeks) and a brief duration (<1 month).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delusional Disorder involves persistent, systematized delusions with otherwise normal functioning and no prominent hallucinations or disorganization; the jealous type (Othello syndrome) features delusions of a partner’s infidelity.

questions.text: All of the following components are required for a Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dideoxyribonucleotides (ddNTPs)

 

  • PCR requires:
    • Template DNA – to provide the sequence to be amplified.
    • Primers – short DNA sequences that flank the region of interest.
    • dNTPs – building blocks for new DNA strand synthesis.
    • Thermostable DNA polymerase (e.g., Taq polymerase) – to withstand repeated heating and cooling cycles.
    • Magnesium ions (Mg²⁺) – act as cofactors for the polymerase enzyme.
  • Dideoxyribonucleotides (ddNTPs) are not used in PCR. 
  • They lack a 3'-OH group, which terminates DNA chain elongation. 
  • These are used instead in Sanger DNA sequencing, not in PCR amplification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCR uses dNTPs for DNA synthesis, while ddNTPs are specific to Sanger sequencing because they terminate DNA chain elongation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with acute abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. He had an open appendectomy 2 years back via the Rutherford Morrison incision. After evaluating and performing imaging, a decision for exploratory laparotomy is made, suspecting intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caecum

 

  • The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. 
  • Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The caecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • Distension of the caecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed caecum implies small bowel obstruction. 
  • Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly lists the drugs in ascending order of their biological half-life?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenosine < Esmolol < Omeprazole < Amiodarone

 

  • The correct sequence from shortest to longest half-life is:

Adenosine (<10 seconds) → Esmolol (<5 minutes) → Omeprazole (1–2 hours) → Amiodarone (>3 weeks)

  • Adenosine: The shortest-acting antiarrhythmic drug. It has a plasma half-life of <10 seconds due to rapid uptake by erythrocytes and endothelial cells.
  • Esmolol: An ultra-short-acting β₁-blocker, metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase, giving it a half-life of about 5-10 minutes.
  • Omeprazole: Despite a short plasma half-life (30 mins), its irreversible inhibition of the H⁺/K⁺-ATPase gives a 24-hour effect.
  • Amiodarone: The longest-acting antiarrhythmic, with a half-life of over 3 weeks due to high lipid solubility and tissue accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of half-life in ascending order:

 

Adenosine (<10 seconds) → Esmolol (<5 minutes) → Omeprazole (1–2 hours) → Amiodarone (>3 weeks)

choices.text: Coverage extends to pre-existing conditions from day one of policy inception
Beneficiaries can avail cashless treatment at both public and private empaneled hospitals
The scheme provides coverage for major surgeries, critical illnesses, and medical procedures that require inpatient admission
Routine out-patient consultations are fully covered under the scheme

questions.text: Under the Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (AB-PMJAY), all the following are features of the scheme except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Routine out-patient consultations are fully covered under the scheme

 

  • AB-PMJAY does not cover routine Outpatient Department (OPD) consultations and services.
  • However, the scheme does cover medical examination, treatment, and consultation expenses incurred during the covered pre-hospitalization (up to 3 days) and post-hospitalization (up to 15 days) periods.
  • The scheme automatically covers eligible families based on Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) 2011 data and state-specific criteria. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coverage extends to pre-existing conditions from day one of policy inception: This is correct - AB-PMJAY covers pre-existing conditions from day one without any waiting period

 

Option B. Beneficiaries can avail cashless treatment at both public and private empaneled hospitals: This is correct - beneficiaries can access cashless treatment at both government and private empaneled hospitals

 

Option C. The scheme provides coverage for major surgeries, critical illnesses, and medical procedures that require inpatient admission: This is correct - the scheme includes coverage for major surgeries, critical illnesses, and medical procedures that require inpatient admission

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scheme provides comprehensive coverage including pre-existing conditions and mental health services
  • Treatment is available on cashless basis at both public and private empaneled healthcare facilities

 

Note – 

 

Ayushman Bharat adopts a continuum of care approach, comprising of two inter-related components, which are -

 

  • Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs)
  • Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY): It provides a cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization across public and private empanelled hospitals in India. It covers up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days post-hospitalization expenses such as diagnostics and medicines. There is no restriction on the family size, age or gender. All pre–existing conditions are covered from day one. Benefits of the scheme are portable across the country i.e. a beneficiary can visit any empanelled public or private hospital in India to avail cashless treatment.

questions.text: A patient on prolonged mechanical ventilation develops fever and purulent endotracheal secretions after 6 days of intubation. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acinetobacter baumannii

 

  • Acinetobacter baumannii is a major cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), particularly in ICU patients receiving prolonged mechanical ventilation.
  • It is a non-fermenting, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacillus that thrives in moist environments, such as ventilator circuits, catheters, and hospital surfaces.
  • Acinetobacter species are notorious for multidrug resistance (MDR), including resistance to carbapenems.
  • VAP caused by Acinetobacter typically presents with fever, purulent tracheal secretions, leukocytosis, and new infiltrates on chest imaging.
  • Risk factors include:
    • Prolonged intubation or ICU stay
    • Prior broad-spectrum antibiotic use
    • Mechanical ventilation >48 hours

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: 

 

  • Also a known cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia but less commonly associated with VAP compared to Acinetobacter or Pseudomonas.
  • Classically causes lobar pneumonia with “currant jelly” sputum, especially in alcoholics and diabetics.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens:

 

  • An anaerobic, spore-forming, Gram-positive bacillus causing gas gangrene and food poisoning.
  • It does not colonize ventilator circuits or cause pneumonia in ventilated patients.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: 

 

  • Causes chronic, community-acquired pulmonary infection, not VAP.
  • VAP is typically due to nosocomial, fast-growing, Gram-negative bacteria, not slow-growing mycobacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) most often involves multidrug-resistant, aerobic Gram-negative bacilli, particularly Acinetobacter baumannii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • These pathogens colonize the endotracheal tube and respiratory equipment, leading to infection after ≥48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old marathon runner experiences a sudden “pop” sound in the posterior ankle during a sprint, followed by severe pain and inability to plantar flex the foot. On examination, the Thompson test is positive. Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tendo calcaneus 

 

  • The Achilles tendon (tendo calcaneus) is the strongest tendon in the body, connecting the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles to the posterior aspect of the calcaneus. 
  • It enables plantar flexion of the foot and propulsion during running or jumping.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Rupture typically occurs during sudden, forceful dorsiflexion (e.g., sprinting, jumping).
  • Risk factors include overuse, fluoroquinolone or corticosteroid use, and age-related tendon degeneration.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Audible “pop” or “snap” at the time of injury.
  • Severe posterior ankle pain.
  • Loss of plantar flexion (cannot stand on toes).
  • Palpable gap over the tendon.
  • Positive Thompson test: When the calf is squeezed, no plantar flexion occurs → diagnostic of Achilles tendon rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis posterior tendon: Incorrect. Injury causes loss of medial arch support and valgus deformity, not loss of plantar flexion.

 

Option B. Flexor hallucis longus tendon: Incorrect. Flexes the great toe; its rupture affects toe movement, not ankle plantar flexion.

 

Option D. Plantaris tendon: Incorrect. A small, vestigial muscle; rupture may cause pain but does not impair plantar flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive Thompson test following a sudden posterior ankle injury is diagnostic of Achilles tendon rupture.
  • It results in loss of plantar flexion and requires prompt surgical or conservative repair depending on the patient’s activity level.

questions.text: In a community health survey, the ages of 100 participants were recorded. The mean age was 45 years, median age was 42 years, and mode was 40 years. What type of distribution does this data represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positively skewed distribution

 

  • When mean > median > mode (45 > 42 > 40), the distribution is positively skewed (right-skewed). 
  • In a positively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward higher values, pulling the mean toward the right of the median and mode. 
  • This is commonly seen in age distributions, income data, and many health-related variables in community surveys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal distribution: In a normal distribution, mean = median = mode, which is not the case here.

 

 

Option C. Negatively skewed distribution: In negatively skewed distribution, mean < median < mode, which is opposite to the given scenario.

 

 

Option D. Bimodal distribution: Bimodal distribution has two modes, but only one mode (40 years) is mentioned in the question.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When mean > median > mode, the distribution is positively skewed
  • Positively skewed distributions are common in community health data

choices.text: Primary radiation therapy with concurrent cisplatin chemotherapy
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radical surgery

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed with Stage IIIB cervical cancer. Imaging reveals bilateral parametrial involvement extending to the pelvic sidewall, but no distant metastasis. What is the most appropriate primary treatment approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary radiation therapy with concurrent cisplatin chemotherapy

 

  • According to FIGO staging, Stage IIIB cervical cancer indicates:
    • Tumor extension to the pelvic sidewall and/or
    • Hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to tumor obstruction.
  • In this stage, the disease has spread beyond the cervix and parametria, making surgical management (hysterectomy) technically unfeasible and non-curative.

 

Standard Treatment:

 

  • The gold-standard primary treatment for locally advanced cervical cancer (Stage IIB–IVA) is concurrent chemoradiation therapy (CCRT).
  • This involves:
    1. External beam radiotherapy (EBRT) to the pelvis
    2. Intracavitary brachytherapy to deliver targeted radiation to the cervix
    3. Weekly cisplatin chemotherapy (40 mg/m²) as a radiosensitizer
  • This combined approach offers the best local control and survival rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy: Incorrect.

 

  • Surgical treatment is reserved for early-stage disease (IA–IB1).
  • In Stage IIIB, parametrial extension and pelvic sidewall involvement make the tumor non-resectable.

 

Option C. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radical surgery: Incorrect.

 

  • Neoadjuvant therapy has limited benefit in advanced cervical cancer and is not superior to concurrent chemoradiation.
  • Surgery post-chemotherapy is technically difficult due to tissue fibrosis.

 

Option D. Palliative radiation therapy only: Incorrect.

 

  • Palliative radiation is used for metastatic (Stage IVB) or symptom control (e.g., bleeding, pain).
  • This patient has potentially curable, locally advanced disease, requiring definitive concurrent chemoradiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For Stage IIIB cervical cancer, the treatment of choice is primary concurrent chemoradiation using external beam radiation, brachytherapy, and cisplatin-based chemotherapy.
  • Surgery is contraindicated due to parametrial and pelvic sidewall involvement.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by his family after being found confused and in distress. He had a recent episode of binge drinking. On examination, his BP is 72/48 mmHg, HR is 120/min, RR is 28/min, and SpO₂ is 88% on room air. He complains of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. Serum amylase, lipase, and BUN levels are markedly elevated. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

 

  • Severe acute pancreatitis is characterized by persistent organ failure lasting more than 48 hours. 
  • In this case, the patient has multi-organ dysfunction: renal impairment (elevated creatinine), respiratory compromise (hypoxia), and hypotension. 
  • The CT scan shows non-enhancing areas of the pancreas, indicating necrosis. These findings fulfil the criteria for severe acute pancreatitis per the Modified Atlanta Classification. 
  • His BISAP score (raised BUN, impaired GCS, SIRS, age > 60 years) is at least 4/5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver abscess: Presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and liver imaging abnormalities. The CT here shows pancreatic involvement, not liver pathology.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Though likely initially, the presence of persistent organ failure and necrosis shifts the diagnosis to severe acute pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Acute pyelonephritis: Typically presents with flank pain, fever, and urinary symptoms. Renal imaging would show renal enlargement or wedge-shaped hypodensities, not pancreatic necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute pancreatitis is diagnosed when acute pancreatitis is accompanied by persistent (>48 hours) organ failure, and imaging often reveals pancreatic necrosis or non-enhancing areas on contrast-enhanced CT.

choices.text: The presence of multiple fracture lines
A clean, curved line without radiating fractures
A linear groove with beveled edges
Compression fractures at the base of the skull

questions.text: In the evaluation of a skull fracture depicted in an image, what characteristic feature differentiates a gutter fracture caused by a bullet from other types of skull fractures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A linear groove with beveled edges

 

  • A gutter fracture, typically caused by a bullet grazing the skull, is characterized by a linear groove with beveled edges. 
  • This unique feature arises as the bullet skims along the surface of the skull, displacing bone in its trajectory. 
  • The beveling occurs on the side where the bullet enters, sloping inwards, and is an indication of the bullet's direction.
  • This characteristic helps forensic experts to differentiate it from other types of skull fractures that might not exhibit such specific directional features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of multiple fracture lines: This option generally relates to comminuted fractures where the bone is broken into several pieces, often due to high-impact trauma from a blunt object. It does not specifically indicate a grazing bullet.

 

Option B. A clean, curved line without radiating fractures: While this might describe some non-penetrating blunt force trauma or even a parietal skull fracture from a curved object, it does not feature the beveled edges typical of a gutter fracture.

 

Option D. Compression fractures at the base of the skull: These fractures are associated with high-energy trauma that compresses the skull vertically, commonly seen in falls or blows to the head where the force is transmitted to the base of the skull. They do not involve linear grooves or beveling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific morphological features of gutter fractures, notably the linear groove with beveled edges, which help in forensic contexts to ascertain the direction and nature of the force involved, specifically identifying gunshot wounds to the head.

choices.text: Reassurance; observe for spontaneous resolution over weeks
Immediate CT head to exclude skull fracture

questions.text: A term newborn with a prolonged second stage of labor develops a fluctuant swelling over the right parietal bone that does not cross sutures. The skin is intact, and hemoglobin is normal. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassurance; observe for spontaneous resolution over weeks

 

  • Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage confined by cranial sutures, typically over a parietal bone. 
  • It is benign and resolves spontaneously within weeks. 
  • Monitoring for jaundice is recommended due to bilirubin load from resorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Needle aspiration and pressure dressing: Aspiration is contraindicated due to risk of infection.

 

Option C. Immediate CT head to exclude skull fracture: Skull fractures are rare and usually clinically insignificant unless neurological signs appear; imaging is not routinely needed.

 

Option D. Start prophylactic antibiotics: Antibiotics are not indicated unless infection develops (rare).

 

Educational Objective:


Cephalhematomas are subperiosteal hemorrhages that do not cross sutures and usually resolve spontaneously; observation and monitoring for jaundice are the mainstays of care.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic stenosis

 

  • A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop indicates that the heart is working at a lower end-diastolic volume and higher pressures, consistent with aortic stenosis. 
  • In aortic stenosis, the left ventricle must generate significantly higher pressures to overcome the narrowed aortic valve, resulting in a taller and narrower loop. 
  • The ventricle's ability to fill may also be reduced, leading to a smaller end-diastolic volume, causing the loop to shift leftward. 
  • The narrowed aortic valve increases afterload, which is the hallmark of aortic stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect. Aortic regurgitation results in an increase in left ventricular volume due to the backflow of blood into the ventricle during diastole, leading to a rightward and widened loop, not a leftward shift. The loop also shows increased stroke volume due to the extra volume regurgitated back into the ventricle.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect. Mitral regurgitation is characterized by an increase in left ventricular volume due to backflow of blood from the ventricle into the left atrium during systole, causing a rightward shift in the loop. The loop becomes wider due to the increased volume in the ventricle, but there is no leftward shift.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure: Incorrect. Congestive cardiac failure typically leads to a downward and rightward shift of the loop due to reduced contractility and higher end-diastolic volumes, not a leftward shift. The loop reflects impaired systolic function and reduced ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop is indicative of aortic stenosis, where the heart generates higher pressures at lower volumes due to increased afterload from the stenotic aortic valve. 
  • The ventricle must work harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve, leading to this characteristic change in the loop.

choices.text: Lung collapse with compensatory hyperinflation of the opposite lung

questions.text: A 4‑year‑old child is brought to the emergency department with acute onset of severe respiratory distress and cyanosis following a bout of coughing. The chest X‑ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tension pneumothorax

 

The X‑ray demonstrates a hyperlucent left hemithorax with absence of lung markings and mediastinal shift to the right, classic for a tension pneumothorax — a life‑threatening emergency requiring immediate decompression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydropneumothorax: Would show both air–fluid levels and horizontal fluid line, which are absent here.

 

Option B. Simple pneumothorax: Shows lung collapse without mediastinal shift — hence less severe.

 

Option D. Lung collapse with contralateral hyperinflation of the opposite lung: Mediastinum shifts toward the affected side (not away), opposite of what’s seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when intrapleural pressure exceeds atmospheric pressure, collapsing the ipsilateral lung and shifting mediastinal structures — leading to impaired venous return and cardiac output.

choices.text: Administer oral amoxicillin and advise follow-up in 2 days
Refer immediately for injectable antibiotics and prompt vaccination for missed dose
Give supportive care with paracetamol and advise home management
Administer oral cotrimoxazole and schedule follow-up in 3 days

questions.text: A 15-month-old child presents with fever, cough, and fast breathing. The mother reports that the child received all vaccines as per schedule but missed the recent booster dose. According to IMNCI guidelines, what is the most appropriate immediate intervention for this child presenting with pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer oral amoxicillin and advise follow-up in 2 days

 

  • According to IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) guidelines, pneumonia in children aged 2-59 months should be treated with oral amoxicillin as first-line therapy. 
  • The child shows signs of pneumonia (fever, cough, fast breathing) but no danger signs requiring immediate referral. 
  • Oral amoxicillin 90mg/kg/day divided into two doses for 5 days is the standard treatment, with follow-up in 2 days to assess improvement.

  

Other Options:

 

Option B. Refer immediately for injectable antibiotics and prompt vaccination for missed dose: Immediate hospital referral is indicated only when danger signs are present (unable to drink/breastfeed, vomits everything, convulsions, lethargic or unconscious). This is a distractor option as the mention of missed booster vaccination might mislead candidates to think about prevention rather than treatment, or that the child might be more susceptible and require hospital referral. However, vaccination status doesn't change the immediate management of pneumonia according to IMNCI protocols.

 

Option C. Give supportive care with paracetamol and advise home management: Supportive care alone is inadequate for pneumonia; specific antibiotic treatment is required

 

Option D. Administer oral cotrimoxazole and schedule follow-up in 3 days: Cotrimoxazole is second-line therapy and follow-up should be in 2 days, not 3 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMNCI guidelines recommend oral amoxicillin as first-line treatment for pneumonia in children 2-59 months with follow-up should be scheduled in 2 days to assess treatment response

choices.text: To examine the condition of the uterine endometrium
To assess sperm motility and interaction with cervical mucus
To confirm ovulation has taken place
To analyze the consistency and viscosity of cervical mucus alone

questions.text: A couple undergoing evaluation for infertility is advised to undergo a postcoital test (PCT) as part of their diagnostic workup. What is the primary purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess sperm motility and interaction with cervical mucus

 

  • The postcoital test (PCT), also known as the Sims-Huhner test, is performed during infertility evaluation to assess the interaction between sperm and cervical mucus in the peri-ovulatory period.
  • The cervical mucus, under the influence of estrogen, becomes thin and receptive to sperm penetration around ovulation. 
  • The test is conducted within 8–12 hours after intercourse, and a sample of cervical mucus is examined microscopically for:
    • Presence of motile sperm
    • Number of motile sperm per high-power field
    • Sperm motility pattern (progressive vs. sluggish)
  • The purpose of this test is to assess whether the sperm can survive and migrate through the cervical mucus, which is critical for natural conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To examine the condition of the uterine endometrium: Incorrect. The uterine lining is assessed by endometrial biopsy, not the postcoital test. The PCT does not provide information about endometrial health.

 

Option C. To confirm ovulation has taken place: Incorrect. The occurrence of ovulation is typically confirmed through methods such as mid-luteal serum progesterone measurement, ultrasound follicular monitoring, or basal body temperature tracking, not via the postcoital test.

 

Option D. To analyze the consistency and viscosity of cervical mucus alone: Incorrect. Although the postcoital test includes an assessment of cervical mucus properties, its primary aim is to evaluate sperm survival and motility within the mucus after intercourse, not just the mucus characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postcoital test is performed during infertility evaluation to assess sperm motility and survival within the cervical mucus, providing information on the sperm-cervical mucus interaction critical for natural conception.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with WHO Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension is started on an oral endothelin receptor antagonist that selectively blocks the endothelin-A (ETA) receptor, minimizing hepatotoxicity. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ambrisentan

 

  • Ambrisentan is a selective endothelin-A receptor antagonist (ERA) approved for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
  • By blocking the ETA receptor, it reduces vasoconstriction and smooth muscle proliferation in pulmonary vessels, improving symptoms and exercise capacity.
  • Importantly, unlike bosentan (which blocks both ETA and ETB), ambrisentan has a lower risk of hepatotoxicity and does not require monthly liver function monitoring.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bosentan: A dual ETA/ETB antagonist associated with significant risk of hepatotoxicity via inhibition of the bile salt export pump (BSEP). Requires monthly LFTs.

 

Option C. Macitentan: A dual ERA, but with improved tissue selectivity and pharmacokinetics. Though better tolerated than bosentan, it still blocks both ETA and ETB receptors, unlike ambrisentan’s ETA selectivity.

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: A prostacyclin analog, not an endothelin receptor antagonist. Administered via continuous IV infusion for severe PAH. It acts by vasodilation and inhibition of platelet aggregation, not endothelin antagonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ambrisentan selectively antagonizes ETA receptors and is used in WHO Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension. 
  • Its selectivity spares the ETB receptor, minimizing hepatotoxicity risk compared to non-selective ERAs like bosentan.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with long-standing hypertension is being evaluated for mild ankle swelling at the end of the day. On assessment of his capillary dynamics at the arteriolar end of a systemic capillary bed, the following pressures are measured:

 

  • Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 30 mm Hg
  • Capillary oncotic pressure = 28 mm Hg
  • Interstitial hydrostatic pressure = 0 mm Hg
  • Interstitial oncotic pressure = 4 mm Hg

 

Based on the Starling forces, what is the net filtration pressure, and will filtration or absorption occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) +6 mm Hg, net filtration

 

  • The movement of fluid across a capillary wall is governed by the Starling equation, which compares hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in both capillary and interstitial compartments:

 

Net filtration pressure = (Pc – Pi) – (πc - πi)

 

Where:

 

  • Pc= capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • Pi= interstitial hydrostatic pressure
  • πc = capillary oncotic pressure
  • πi = interstitial oncotic pressure

 

Step 1: Substitute the given values

 

(30 - 0) - (28 - 4) = 30 – 24 = + 6 mm Hg

 

  • A positive value indicates filtration, meaning fluid is moving out of the capillary into the interstitial space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • At the arteriolar end of capillaries, hydrostatic pressure exceeds oncotic pressure, resulting in net filtration of fluid into the interstitial space.
  • At the venular end, capillary hydrostatic pressure falls, oncotic pressure dominates, and reabsorption occurs.
  • Formula to remember:

 

Net filtration pressure = (Pc – Pi) – (πc - πi)

 

  • Positive value → filtration, Negative value → absorption

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with acute cholecystitis develops a sudden increase in pain. The Abdomen shows cardboard rigidity on palpation. Imaging reveals free fluid around the liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gallbladder perforation

 

Gallbladder perforation is a complication of acute cholecystitis and presents with peritonitis and free fluid on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstone ileus: Gallstone ileus presents with small bowel obstruction, not peritonitis.

 

Option B. Mirizzi syndrome: Mirizzi syndrome involves obstruction of the bile duct by a gallstone without free fluid, presents with Jaundice. 

 

Option D. Biliary pancreatitis: While it causes abdominal pain, it does not present with peritonitis or free perihepatic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder perforation is a surgical emergency in patients with acute cholecystitis and peritonitis, requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man is admitted with worsening dyspnea and leg swelling. His clinicians want to measure his cardiac output to assess cardiac performance. Which of the following methods can be used for cardiac output calculation?

 

  1. Thermodilution
  2. Fick’s principle
  3. Echocardiography (ECHO)
  4. Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, C

 

  • Cardiac output (CO) is the volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute. Several validated techniques exist for its calculation:
  • A. Thermodilution:
    • Measured using a pulmonary artery catheter (Swan-Ganz catheter).
    • Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature at the pulmonary artery is measured.
    • This is a standard invasive method to calculate CO.

 

  • B. Fick’s principle:
    • Based on oxygen consumption (VO₂) and arteriovenous O₂ difference.
    • Formula:
      • CO=O₂ consumption/ (Arterial O₂ content – Venous O₂ content)
    • Considered a gold standard in physiology.

 

  • C. Echocardiography:
    • Doppler echocardiography can calculate stroke volume by measuring left ventricular outflow tract diameter and velocity-time integral (VTI).
    • Multiplying stroke volume by heart rate gives cardiac output.

  • Thus, the correct methods are A (Thermodilution), B (Fick’s principle), and C (ECHO).

     

Incorrect Option:

 

D. Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan: This is a diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism and does not measure cardiac output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac output can be measured using thermodilution, Fick’s principle, or echocardiography. Ventilation-perfusion scanning is not used to measure cardiac output.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with fluctuating ptosis and diplopia, which worsen by the evening. His symptoms improve transiently after administering an IV medication. The image shows the patient's eye movements before and after drug administration. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test for confirming the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetylcholine receptor antibody test

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction, often presenting with fluctuating ptosis and diplopia. 
  • The edrophonium (Tensilon) test and ice pack test can provide a rapid diagnosis, but the definitive diagnostic test is the detection of acetylcholine receptor antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: A short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that temporarily improves symptoms but has fallen out of favour due to risks of bradycardia.

 

Option B. Ice pack test: Cooling the eyelid improves ptosis in MG, but it is not confirmatory.

 

 

Option D. Orbital MRI with contrast: Useful in cases where a thymoma or compressive lesion is suspected, but not required for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acetylcholine receptor antibody test is the gold standard for diagnosing myasthenia gravis, while the edrophonium test and ice pack test provide rapid but less definitive diagnostic confirmation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly describe non-nutritional environmental factors influencing bacterial growth? 

 

  1. Ultraviolet radiation damages bacterial DNA and inhibits replication.
  2. High osmotic pressure favors the growth of most non-halophilic pathogens.
  3. Moisture is essential for bacterial survival and metabolic activity.
  4. Mechanical stress and desiccation can damage or destroy bacterial cell walls.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Ultraviolet radiation damages bacterial DNA and inhibits replication: Correct. Ultraviolet radiation induces thymine dimers in bacterial DNA, inhibiting replication and transcription, thereby killing or inactivating the bacteria.

 

Statement 3. Moisture is essential for bacterial survival and metabolic activity: Correct. Water is vital for enzyme activity, nutrient transport, and metabolism. Bacteria require adequate moisture to grow.

 

Statement 4. Mechanical stress and desiccation can damage or destroy bacterial cell walls: Correct. Mechanical stress (e.g., ultrasonic vibration) and desiccation (drying) can disrupt bacterial membranes and cell walls, leading to loss of viability.

 

Incorrect Statement:
