Statement 2. High osmotic pressure favors the growth of most non-halophilic pathogens: Incorrect. High osmotic pressure inhibits the growth of non-halophilic (salt-sensitive) pathogens by causing plasmolysis. Only halophilic bacteria thrive in such environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial growth is strongly influenced by non-nutritional environmental factors such as UV radiation, osmotic pressure, moisture, and mechanical stress. Most non-halophilic pathogens require moist, isotonic, dark environments and are inhibited by dryness, high salt concentration, or radiation exposure.

choices.text: It is caused by multiple organisms
Surgical treatment is required in most cases

questions.text: A 60-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He reports a history of a boil in the perianal area that developed two weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the image below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mortality is low

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The condition shown in the image is likely Fournier’s gangrene, a life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum and genital region. 
  • Fournier’s gangrene has a high mortality rate (around 50%), especially in diabetic and immunocompromised patients, due to rapid spread of infection and sepsis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by multiple organisms: Fournier’s gangrene is typically caused by polymicrobial infection, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Common pathogens include E. coli, Klebsiella, Streptococci, and anaerobes like Bacteroides.

 

Option B. The testis remains unaffected: The testis may often remain unaffected because its blood supply comes from the testicular artery, which is separate from the perineal tissues. This anatomical feature can protect the testes from necrosis even when the surrounding tissues are severely affected.

 

Option C. Surgical treatment is required in most cases: Surgical debridement is essential in most cases of Fournier’s gangrene to remove necrotic tissue and control the spread of infection. This treatment, along with broad-spectrum antibiotics, is critical for improving survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier’s gangrene is a rapidly progressing necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital area with high mortality. 
  • It requires urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Delay in treatment can result in a poor prognosis, particularly in diabetic and immunocompromised individuals.

choices.text: Localized Type I reaction with eosinophilic inflammation
Localized Type III reaction due to deposition of immune complexes in alveoli
Systemic Type II reaction with complement-mediated lysis
Type IV delayed-type reaction involving Th1 lymphocytes

questions.text: A 38-year-old bird breeder develops cough, dyspnea, and malaise several hours after cleaning bird cages. Chest imaging reveals diffuse infiltrates. This condition represents which type and mechanism of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Localized Type III reaction due to deposition of immune complexes in alveoli

 

  • This patient’s presentation is characteristic of Bird Fancier’s Lung (Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis), a localized Type III hypersensitivity reaction.
  • The pathogenesis involves inhalation of avian antigens, which combine with preformed IgG antibodies in the alveolar walls.
  • These antigen–antibody complexes trigger complement activation, leading to the recruitment of neutrophils and release of inflammatory mediators.
  • The result is immune complex–mediated alveolitis, manifesting as cough, dyspnea, fever, and diffuse infiltrates on imaging.
  • This condition represents a localized (Arthus-type) Type III reaction, as immune complexes form and deposit directly at the site of antigen exposure (lungs).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Localized Type I reaction with eosinophilic inflammation: Incorrect. Type I hypersensitivity is IgE-mediated and involves mast cell degranulation, producing immediate allergic responses such as asthma, urticaria, or anaphylaxis. Bird Fancier’s lung develops hours after exposure, consistent with immune complex deposition, not IgE-mediated inflammation.

 

Option C. Systemic Type II reaction with complement-mediated lysis: Incorrect. Type II hypersensitivity involves antibody binding to cell-surface antigens and subsequent cell lysis or phagocytosis (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic anemia). Bird Fancier’s lung involves soluble antigen–antibody complexes, not antibody-mediated cytotoxicity.

 

Option D. Type IV delayed-type reaction involving Th1 lymphocytes: Incorrect. Type IV reactions are cell-mediated and typically occur 48–72 hours post-exposure, as seen in tuberculin skin test or contact dermatitis. Bird Fancier’s lung occurs within hours and is mediated by immune complexes, not T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bird Fancier’s Lung (Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis) is a localized Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by deposition of antigen–antibody immune complexes in alveolar walls following inhalation of organic antigens. 
  • This leads to complement activation, neutrophilic inflammation, and subsequent tissue injury.

questions.text: A 32‑year‑old man presents with new‑onset seizures. MRI shows a ring‑enhancing lesion in the parietal lobe. MR spectroscopy reveals a prominent lipid‑lactate peak with reduced N‑acetylaspartate (NAA), as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculoma

 

  • Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (MRS) evaluates brain metabolites before structural changes become apparent.
  • Key metabolites include:
    • N‑acetylaspartate (NAA) → neuronal marker (↓ in neuronal loss)
    • Choline (Cho) → cell membrane turnover (↑ in neoplasms)
    • Creatine (Cr) → energy metabolism (relatively stable)
    • Lipid–lactate peaks → indicate necrosis or anaerobic metabolism
  • In tuberculoma, caseous necrosis produces prominent lipid peaks (due to breakdown of mycobacterial and host lipids), accompanied by decreased NAA (neuronal destruction). 
  • This MRS pattern differentiates tuberculoma from other ring‑enhancing lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis: Lipid peaks are absent in neurocysticercosis since there’s no caseous necrosis; spectroscopy findings are usually normal or nonspecific.

 

Option C. Glioblastoma Multiforme: Shows high choline from active cell proliferation but lacks the prominent lipid-lactate peak seen with necrotic infections like tuberculoma.

 

Option D. Brain Abscess: Displays amino acid and lactate peaks from bacterial metabolism rather than the lipid peaks typical of caseous necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipid peaks on MRS are a hallmark of tuberculoma due to caseous necrosis.
  • NAA decrease = neuronal loss; choline increase = cellular proliferation.
  • MR spectroscopy helps differentiate infective lesions (tuberculoma, abscess) from neoplastic or parasitic causes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer has progressed despite prior tamoxifen therapy. Her oncologist initiates a new IM therapy that acts by downregulation of estrogen receptors. Which drug is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fulvestrant

 

  • Fulvestrant is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD) and the drug of choice in tamoxifen-resistant hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women. 
  • Unlike SERMs, which can have mixed agonist/antagonist actions, fulvestrant is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist.
  • Mechanism of action:
    • Binds estrogen receptors (ER) with >100x affinity than tamoxifen
    • Prevents ER dimerization
    • Promotes receptor degradation
    • Leads to complete suppression of estrogen-driven transcription
  • It is administered as a monthly intramuscular injection, with a relatively favorable safety profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raloxifene: A SERM used for osteoporosis prevention and breast cancer prophylaxis in high-risk women, but not effective for treating metastatic breast cancer, especially after tamoxifen failure.

 

Option B. Tamoxifen: Already failed in this patient. While it is a mainstay SERM for ER+ breast cancer, resistance can develop, making it ineffective in progressive disease.

 

Option D. Tibolone: A Selective Tissue Estrogen Activity Regulator (STEAR) used in menopausal symptom relief and osteoporosis, but has no role in breast cancer therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fulvestrant is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist (SERD) used in postmenopausal women with tamoxifen-resistant, hormone receptor-positive metastatic breast cancer. 
  • It works by downregulating and degrading ERs, offering efficacy where SERMs fail.

choices.text: High protein diet with 4-5 gm/kg/day protein immediately
F-75 formula followed by F-100 formula in stabilization phase
Intravenous albumin infusion to correct hypoproteinemia
Iron and folic acid supplementation as primary intervention

questions.text: A 3-year-old child admitted to Nutrition Rehabilitation Centre with severe acute malnutrition shows bilateral pitting edema, apathy, and growth retardation. What is the most appropriate initial therapeutic approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) F-75 formula followed by F-100 formula in stabilization phase

 

  • According to WHO guidelines for management of severe acute malnutrition, the initial stabilization phase requires careful nutritional rehabilitation using F-75 formula (75 kcal/100ml) which provides controlled energy and protein intake. 
  • This prevents refeeding syndrome and allows gradual metabolic adaptation. 
  • F-100 formula is introduced later in the rehabilitation phase once the child is stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High protein diet with 4-5 gm/kg/day protein immediately: High protein diet immediately can precipitate refeeding syndrome and worsen the condition due to metabolic complications

 

Option C. Intravenous albumin infusion to correct hypoproteinemia: IV albumin is contraindicated in SAM as it can cause fluid overload and heart failure in these vulnerable children

 

Option D. Iron and folic acid supplementation as primary intervention: While micronutrient supplementation is important, it is not the primary initial intervention; nutritional rehabilitation takes precedence

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • F-75 formula is the standard initial treatment for severe acute malnutrition in Nutrition Rehabilitation Centres
  • Gradual nutritional rehabilitation prevents refeeding syndrome complications
  • High protein intake should be avoided initially in severely malnourished children

choices.text: Islands of sparing over the body

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the dermatology outpatient department with gradual thickening of palms and soles and dry scaly plaques over his trunk. Based on these findings, which of the following features is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Islands of sparing over the body

 

  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) is a chronic papulosquamous disorder characterized by:
    • Salmon-red or orange-red scaly plaques, often beginning on the trunk and spreading to involve the extremities.
    • The plaques often coalesce, but patches of normal skin (islands of sparing) remain between affected areas — a hallmark feature of PRP.
    • There is frequently palmoplantar keratoderma (thickening of palms and soles).
  • The disease is due to abnormal keratinization and typically affects adults in an insidious pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nail pitting commonly seen:

 

  • Typical of psoriasis, not PRP.
  • Results from defective keratinization of nail plate matrix.

 

Option B. Pterygium of nails: Seen in lichen planus, due to adhesion between the proximal nail fold and nail bed.

 

Option D. Herald patch: Seen in pityriasis rosea, presenting as a single large “herald” lesion followed by smaller secondary eruptions in a Christmas-tree pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pityriasis rubra pilaris presents with salmon-red scaly plaques, palmoplantar keratoderma, and “islands of sparing” — characteristic areas of normal skin amidst diffuse erythema.

questions.text: A patient presents with painless PR (per rectal) bleed during defecation. The following is seen on proctoscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemorrhoids

 

  • The image shown on proctoscopy displays hemorrhoids, which are enlarged vascular structures in the anal canal.
  •  Hemorrhoids are a common cause of painless rectal bleeding, especially during defecation.
  • Hemorrhoids are typically classified by grade:
    • Grade 1 and 2: These can often be managed with conservative measures such as sclerotherapy or rubber band ligation (banding).
    • Grade 3 and 4: For advanced hemorrhoids, treatment may require stapled hemorrhoidopexy or hemorrhoidectomy (such as the Milligan-Morgan procedure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fissure in ano: Anal fissures usually cause severe pain during defecation and are associated with bright red blood on toilet paper or stool. They are typically seen as a tear in the anoderm and would not present as painless bleeding.

 

Option C. Fistula in ano: Anal fistulas are abnormal connections between the anal canal and the perianal skin, often presenting with discharge or infection rather than painless bleeding.

 

Option D. Anal canal cancer: Anal canal cancer can cause bleeding, but it is usually associated with other symptoms such as pain, a mass, or changes in bowel habits. The appearance on proctoscopy is different from hemorrhoids and would typically require a biopsy for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hemorrhoids are a common cause of painless rectal bleeding during defecation. 
  • They can be managed based on their grade, with lower grades treated by minimally invasive procedures like sclerotherapy or banding, and higher grades requiring surgical options like stapled hemorrhoidopexy or hemorrhoidectomy.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms are most commonly associated with the development of botryomycosis? 

 

  1. Staphylococcus aureus
  2. Staphylococcus albus
  3. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  4. Streptococcus pneumoniae
  5. Streptococcus pyogenes
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3 only

 

  • Botryomycosis is a chronic granulomatous bacterial infection that clinically and histologically mimics actinomycosis, but it is non-fungal and non-actinomycotic in origin.
  • The most common etiologic agent is Staphylococcus aureus (in about 80% of cases).
  • Other bacteria occasionally implicated include Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Proteus, and Streptococcus species.
  • It usually follows local trauma, surgical procedures, or chronic infection and can involve skin, subcutaneous tissue, or viscera (especially lungs and liver).
  • Histologically, it shows granules composed of bacterial colonies surrounded by eosinophilic material (Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon).

 

Incorrect Options: 

 

2. Staphylococcus albus: Older term for Staphylococcus epidermidis; rarely associated.

 

4. Streptococcus pneumonia: Causes lobar pneumonia; not linked to botryomycosis.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes: May cause soft-tissue infections but not chronic granulomatous lesions of botryomycosis type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Botryomycosis is a granulomatous bacterial infection, most frequently due to Staphylococcus aureus, and less commonly Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • It can mimic actinomycosis but is caused by true bacteria, not filamentous organisms.

choices.text: During the susceptibility phase before exposure
During the subclinical disease phase before symptoms appear
During the clinical disease phase after symptom onset
During the outcome phase after disease resolution

questions.text: The image shows the natural history of disease model. At which stage shown in the diagram would secondary prevention measures be most effectively implemented?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) During the subclinical disease phase before symptoms appear

 

  • Secondary prevention aims to detect and treat disease in its early stages before symptoms develop, thereby preventing progression to clinical disease.
  • This is most effectively implemented during the subclinical disease phase when pathological changes have begun but clinical manifestations have not yet appeared. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. During the susceptibility phase before exposure: This represents primary prevention, which aims to prevent disease occurrence before the pathological process begins

 

Option C. During the clinical disease phase after symptom onset: This represents early tertiary prevention or treatment phase, when disease is already clinically manifest

 

Option D. During the outcome phase after disease resolution: This represents tertiary prevention or rehabilitation phase, focusing on preventing complications and disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary prevention targets the subclinical phase of disease when pathological changes exist but symptoms haven't appeared
  • The natural history model helps identify optimal intervention points for different levels of prevention

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with periorbital edema most noticeable in the morning and decreased urine output. Laboratory investigations show frothy urine. His mother mentions that his face appears puffy, especially after waking up. Lab investigations are attached. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (UPCR)

 

  • Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (UPCR) is the most appropriate initial investigation for a child presenting with periorbital edema and decreased urine output, which are classic symptoms of nephrotic syndrome. 
  • UPCR provides a quantitative assessment of proteinuria using a spot urine sample. 
  • In children with suspected nephrotic syndrome, demonstrating significant proteinuria is the first diagnostic step, as it is the primary pathophysiologic abnormality that leads to other manifestations such as hypoalbuminemia, edema. 
  • A UPCR value >2.0 mg/mg indicates nephrotic-range proteinuria, which is sufficient to establish this critical diagnostic criterion without requiring a cumbersome 24-hour urine collection that is difficult to obtain accurately in young children.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Serum albumin level:

 

  • While hypoalbuminemia (<3 g/dL) is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome, it is secondary to urinary protein loss
  • This would typically be ordered after confirming proteinuria
  • It helps confirm the diagnosis but is not the most appropriate initial test
  • Cannot distinguish between nephrotic syndrome and other causes of hypoalbuminemia (like liver disease or malnutrition) without first establishing proteinuria

 

Option C. Serum cholesterol level:

 

  • Hyperlipidemia is a secondary finding in nephrotic syndrome, not the primary abnormality
  • Elevated cholesterol develops as a consequence of hypoalbuminemia and altered lipoprotein metabolism
  • Less specific than proteinuria for the diagnosis
  • Would typically be ordered as part of the comprehensive evaluation after proteinuria is confirmed
  • Can be elevated in many other conditions beyond kidney disease

 

Option D. Documentation of edema:

 

  • This represents a clinical finding rather than a laboratory investigation
  • Edema is already evident in the history (periorbital edema)
  • Cannot distinguish between nephrotic syndrome and other causes of edema
  • While important to document, this does not provide objective evidence of kidney dysfunction
  • May be influenced by position and time of day, making it variable

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In a child with suspected nephrotic syndrome, always begin the diagnostic evaluation with assessment of proteinuria (UPCR) as it is the primary abnormality. 
  • The classic tetrad of nephrotic syndrome includes:

 

 

  • UPCR offers significant advantages over 24-hour urine collection in pediatric patients, providing reliable results with a single spot sample.

choices.text: Collaborating with traditional healers to integrate ORS use alongside their herbal treatments as complementary therapy
Intensively replacing traditional beliefs with scientific explanations about diarrhea causation through health education campaigns
Using local dialect and incorporating familiar cultural metaphors to explain how ORS works in the body
Training community health workers from the same tribe to demonstrate ORS preparation using culturally appropriate teaching methods

questions.text: In a remote tribal area of Jharkhand where the community believes that diarrheal diseases in children are caused by "evil eye" and traditional healers use herbal concoctions a medical officer needs to implement an oral rehydration therapy (ORT) program. All of the following are appropriate health communication strategies that should be employed in this scenario except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensively replacing traditional beliefs with scientific explanations about diarrhea causation through health education campaigns

 

  • Represents a confrontational approach that directly challenges deeply held cultural beliefs, which is counterproductive in health communication. 
  • This approach often leads to resistance, mistrust, and poor program acceptance. 
  • Effective health communication in tribal communities requires cultural competence, collaboration with traditional systems, and gradual integration rather than replacement of beliefs.
  • The incorrect traditional beliefs should be gradually replaced by the correct scientific explanations – should not be replaced intensively/aggressively – the population may not accept it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaborating with traditional healers to integrate ORS use alongside their herbal treatments as complementary therapy: This collaborative approach respects cultural beliefs while introducing modern treatment, leading to better acceptance and compliance.

 

Option C. Using local dialect and incorporating familiar cultural metaphors to explain how ORS works in the body: Using local language and cultural metaphors enhances understanding and makes health messages more relatable and acceptable.

 

Option D. Training community health workers from the same tribe to demonstrate ORS preparation using culturally appropriate teaching methods: Training community members as health workers ensures cultural appropriateness and builds trust within the community.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Health communication in tribal areas requires cultural sensitivity and collaborative approaches rather than confrontational replacement of traditional beliefs
  • Integration of traditional and modern medical systems often yields better health outcomes than complete replacement strategies
  • Community participation and use of local resources are essential for successful health communication programs in remote areas

questions.text: A patient presents with hoarseness following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals that the left vocal cord is in the paramedian position and does not abduct during inspiration. Which muscle's paralysis is responsible for the inability to abduct the vocal cord?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only abductor of the vocal cords and is known as the "safety muscle of the larynx." 
  • It is supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. 
  • When this muscle is paralyzed due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (common during thyroid surgery), the vocal cord cannot abduct and remains in a paramedian position. 
  • This results in hoarseness and potentially respiratory distress if bilateral. 
  • All other intrinsic laryngeal muscles either adduct, tense, or relax the vocal cords.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral cricoarytenoid: This is incorrect. The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is an adductor of the vocal cords, not an abductor. Its paralysis would affect vocal cord adduction, not the abduction that is impaired in this case.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoid: This is incorrect. The thyroarytenoid muscle functions to relax the vocal cords and contributes to adduction. It does not abduct the vocal cords, so its paralysis wouldn't prevent abduction.

 

Option D. Cricothyroid: This is incorrect. The cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords and is the only intrinsic laryngeal muscle supplied by the external laryngeal nerve, not the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It doesn't abduct the vocal cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior cricoarytenoid is the sole abductor of vocal cords ("safety muscle of larynx") and its paralysis from recurrent laryngeal nerve injury causes the vocal cord to remain in paramedian position.

choices.text: Median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel
Combined median and ulnar nerve injury at the wrist
Lower trunk injury at the thoracic outlet
Ulnar nerve compression at Guyon’s canal

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, a pianist, reports progressive weakness and numbness in her right hand for 3 months, with difficulty performing fine finger movements and flattening of the hand. Examination reveals wasting of the hypothenar and interossei muscles, clawing of the ring and little fingers, and sensory loss over the medial one and a half fingers on both palmar and dorsal surfaces, while dorsal hand sensation is preserved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulnar nerve compression at Guyon’s canal

 

  • The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles, interossei, adductor pollicis, and the medial two lumbricals. 
  • It also provides sensation to the medial one and a half fingers on both the palmar and dorsal aspects of the hand.
  • Compression of the ulnar nerve in Guyon’s canal (a fibro-osseous tunnel at the wrist between the pisiform and hook of hamate) leads to:
    • Motor deficits: Weakness or wasting of interossei and hypothenar muscles, causing flattening of the hand and clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers (due to unopposed action of the long finger flexors).
    • Sensory loss: Over the palmar and distal dorsal surfaces of the little finger and medial half of the ring finger.
    • Preserved dorsal hand sensation: Because the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve branches proximal to Guyon’s canal.
  • This constellation of findings is characteristic of ulnar nerve compression at Guyon’s canal (also called ulnar tunnel syndrome).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel: Incorrect. Causes thenar muscle wasting and sensory loss over the lateral 3½ digits, not the medial side.

 

Option B. Combined median and ulnar nerve injury at the wrist: Incorrect. Would cause loss of both thenar and hypothenar functions with global sensory loss, not the selective pattern seen here.

 

Option C. Lower trunk injury at the thoracic outlet: Incorrect. Leads to Klumpke’s palsy involving both median and ulnar nerves, with sensory loss along the medial arm and forearm, not limited to the hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve compression at Guyon’s canal causes claw hand deformity, wasting of hypothenar and interossei muscles, and sensory loss over the medial one and a half fingers, with preserved dorsal sensation because the dorsal cutaneous branch arises proximal to the canal.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with alcohol-induced cirrhosis undergoing routine ultrasound and AFP screening is found to have a new suspicious liver lesion with no change in AFP. What is the next best diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver MRI

 

  • In cirrhotic patients, a new liver lesion detected on surveillance ultrasound should be further evaluated with liver MRI with contrast (or multiphase CT), as this imaging modality is highly sensitive for detecting HCC and is preferred for noninvasive diagnosis.​
  • MRI can identify the arterial enhancement and venous/delayed washout typical of HCC and is diagnostic for most cases without a need for biopsy.
  • AFP levels are neither sensitive nor specific and should not delay definitive imaging work-up when a suspicious lesion is present.
  • PET scan is not standard for initial diagnosis of HCC due to limited sensitivity.
  • Liver biopsy may be reserved for indeterminate imaging findings but is generally not the first step if high-quality MRI or CT can provide a diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Abdominal PET scan: Abdominal PET scan is not recommended for initial diagnosis of HCC.


Option B. Liver biopsy: Liver biopsy is not the initial step; imaging is diagnostic in most cirrhosis cases and avoids biopsy risks.


Option D. Repeat AFP level in 3 months: Repeat AFP is not helpful for immediate decision-making; imaging should proceed promptly.

 

Educational Objective:


For patients with cirrhosis and a newly detected liver lesion on ultrasound, the preferred next investigation is contrast-enhanced MRI, which has the highest sensitivity and specificity for HCC and minimizes the need for invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. Her pulse rate is 80/minute, BP 120/84 mm of Hg, and she is hemodynamically stable. What is the approximate blood loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Less than 15% of blood volume

 

  • This patient’s normal hemodynamics suggests Class I hemorrhage (<15% blood loss), where compensatory mechanisms maintain hemodynamic stability.
  • Hemorrhagic shock is classified into four classes based on blood loss percentage and clinical signs:
    • Class I: <15% blood loss, normal/increased pulse pressure, normal BP.
    • Class II: 15-30% blood loss, mild tachycardia, decreased pulse pressure.
    • Class III: 30-40% blood loss, hypotension, confusion.
    • Class IV: >40% blood loss, severe hypotension, lethargy.
  • Only in Class I hemorrhage are the vital parameters normal, whereas in other classes, they are deranged.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More than 40% blood loss: Would result in severe hypotension, tachycardia >140, confusion, and minimal urine output, which are not present here.

 

Option C. Between 15-30% blood loss & Option D. Between 30-40% blood loss: These would decrease pulse pressure and show signs of tachycardia, anxiety, or hypotension, none of which are seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class I hemorrhage (<15% blood loss) presents with pulse, normal blood pressure, and no significant hemodynamic compromise.
  • In higher classes of hemorrhagic shock, pulse increases, and hypotension develops.

choices.text: Acute otitis media in the presuppuration stage

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with ear pain, fever, and a feeling of ear fullness. Otoscopic examination reveals a congested tympanic membrane with a specific appearance as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute otitis media in the presuppuration stage

 

  • Acute otitis media (AOM) is a common condition in children characterized by bacterial or viral infection of the middle ear. 
  • The presuppuration stage is the second stage of AOM and is identified by:
    • A congested tympanic membrane with dilated radial blood vessels, producing the classic "cartwheel appearance."
    • Symptoms such as fever, ear pain, and a sensation of ear fullness.
  • This stage occurs before the tympanic membrane bulges or pus collects in the middle ear (suppuration stage).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa, also known as swimmer's ear, involves infection of the external auditory canal. It is associated with pain, tenderness on manipulation of the pinna, and canal swelling but does not produce a congested tympanic membrane or the cartwheel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Chronic otitis media: Chronic otitis media typically presents with persistent ear discharge and tympanic membrane perforation. It does not show the acute findings or the cartwheel appearance seen in AOM.

 

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion: Otitis media with effusion involves fluid in the middle ear without signs of infection, such as fever or pain. The tympanic membrane is often dull and retracted, without the congestion or cartwheel appearance seen in AOM.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cartwheel appearance of the tympanic membrane is a hallmark of the presuppuration stage of acute otitis media, which presents with fever, ear pain, and a sensation of ear fullness.

choices.text: Child should be measured in Frankfurt plane with shoes on
Head, shoulders, buttocks, and heels should touch the wall with shoes removed
Child can be measured at any time of the day as height doesn't vary
Measurement can be taken with child looking down at examiner

questions.text: A 5-year-old child needs height measurement as part of a comprehensive growth assessment in a pediatric clinic. The nurse is training a new staff member on proper anthropometric techniques. Which of the following describes the correct technique for measuring standing height?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head, shoulders, buttocks, and heels should touch the wall with shoes removed

 

  • The correct technique for measuring standing height requires that the child stands with shoes and socks removed, with four points of contact against the vertical surface: the occiput (back of head), shoulders, buttocks, and heels.
  • This position ensures proper body alignment for an accurate measurement. Additionally, the child's head should be positioned in the Frankfurt horizontal plane (where the line from the lower margin of the eye orbit to the upper margin of the ear canal is horizontal and parallel to the floor). 
  • The measurement should be taken using a stadiometer, with the horizontal bar lowered to gently touch the crown of the head while maintaining the proper position. 
  • This standardized approach minimizes variation and ensures accurate and reproducible measurements, which are crucial for growth assessment and monitoring.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child should be measured in Frankfurt plane with shoes on:

 

  • While the Frankfurt plane is the correct head position, shoes must be removed
  • Shoes add variable height (1-3 cm) that significantly distorts measurement
  • Different shoe types have different heights, introducing inconsistency
  • Standardized protocols require bare feet to ensure measurement accuracy
  • This violates a fundamental rule of anthropometric measurement

 

Option C. Child can be measured at any time of the day as height doesn't vary:

 

  • This is incorrect because height varies throughout the day
  • Maximum height occurs in the morning after lying supine overnight
  • Height can decrease by 0.5-1 cm by evening due to compression of intervertebral discs
  • For accurate tracking, measurements should ideally be taken at consistent times
  • This diurnal variation is especially important when monitoring growth in children

 

Option D. Measurement can be taken with child looking down at examiner:

 

  • This position violates the Frankfurt horizontal plane requirement
  • Looking down causes flexion of the cervical spine, reducing measured height
  • Proper head position is with eyes looking straight ahead
  • Consistent head positioning is essential for reproducible measurements
  • This error could lead to systematic underestimation of height

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Proper height measurement technique is critical for accurate growth assessment. 
  • The "four-point contact" method (head, shoulders, buttocks, and heels touching the wall) with shoes removed, head in Frankfurt plane, and using a proper stadiometer represents the gold standard. 
  • Consistency in technique is essential when monitoring a child's growth over time, as small measurement errors can lead to significant misinterpretations of growth patterns.
  • The image illustrates proper height measurement technique with:
    1. Child standing straight against wall/stadiometer
    2. Shoes and socks removed
    3. Four points of contact with wall
    4. Head in Frankfurt horizontal plane
    5. Stadiometer headpiece touching crown of head at 90° angle

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with sudden, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, left-sided limb weakness, and a witnessed seizure two days ago. Contrast CT of the head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cortical venous thrombosis

 

  • The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT is a classic finding indicating cerebral venous (sinus) thrombosis, reflecting a filling defect (thrombosed sinus) surrounded by enhancement of collateral veins.​
  • Cortical venous thrombosis (also known as cerebral venous sinus thrombosis) can present with headache, seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and can produce hemorrhagic infarction due to impaired venous drainage.
  • This condition is most commonly seen in young women and often misdiagnosed as arterial stroke or other intracranial hemorrhagic events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Typically involves cranial neuropathies, orbital symptoms (proptosis, ophthalmoplegia), and is not associated with the empty delta sign.

 

Option B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Presents with thunderclap headache but would not show the empty delta sign or large hemorrhagic infarcts in the temporoparietal region. The CT may show star of death appearance or diffuse presence of blood. The patient may also present with hydrocephalus. 

 

Option C. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage: Usually presents in older patients (> 40 years) with long-standing hypertension, involves deep brain structures, and does not lead to the empty delta sign or the pattern described.

 

Educational Objective:


The empty delta sign on CT with clinical features of headache and focal neurologic deficit strongly suggests cortical venous (sinus) thrombosis, a diagnosis that should be suspected in young patients presenting with atypical stroke-like syndromes and seizures.

questions.text: Which source provides the most reliable data for calculating age-specific fertility rates in India, considering the inherent limitations of routine data collection systems?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SRS

 

  • The Sample Registration System (SRS) provides the most reliable data for calculating age-specific fertility rates in India. 
  • While CRS theoretically should be the gold standard, it suffers from significant under-registration (estimated 70-80% coverage for births). 
  • SRS uses a dual recording system with built-in verification mechanisms, making it more reliable for demographic parameters. 
  • NFHS provides periodic data but not continuous monitoring, and AHS has been discontinued.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CRS: Civil Registration System (CRS) has massive under-registration issues, particularly in rural areas, making fertility rate calculations unreliable. This is a distractor option as it is more likely to be picked if the word “inherent limitations’ is missed.

 

Option C. NFHS: National Family Health Survey (NFHS) provides cross-sectional data every 4-5 years, not continuous vital statistics needed for annual fertility rates

 

Option D. AHS: Annual Health Survey (AHS) was discontinued after 2014 and covered only high-focus states, limiting its utility for national estimates 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SRS uses dual recording system ensuring better data quality than single-source systems
  • CRS under-registration remains a major challenge for vital statistics in India
  • Sample-based systems often provide more reliable estimates than universal registration systems with poor coverage

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
Ectopic ACTH production leading to Cushing’s syndrome

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and new-onset muscle weakness in his lower limbs. He also reports occasional dizziness and episodes of flushing. On examination, he has a plethoric face and mild proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal: Hematocrit: 60%, Serum sodium: 124 mEq/L (↓), Serum potassium: 3.2 mEq/L (↓) and Serum calcium: 9.2 mg/dL (normal). Chest X-ray shows a central hilar mass. Biopsy image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for chromogranin A and synaptophysin. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is not associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypercalcemia due to PTHrP secretion

 

  • The clinical, radiological, and histopathological features are consistent with Small Cell Carcinoma of the Lung (SCLC) - a highly malignant neuroendocrine tumor.
  • Hypercalcemia due to PTHrP - PTHrP (parathyroid hormone–related peptide) secretion causes hypercalcemia in malignancy.
  • Seen in: Squamous cell carcinoma of lung, breast, renal, and head/neck carcinomas.
  • Not typically seen in SCLC, which tends to cause hyponatremia or Cushing’s, not hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH): 

 

  • SCLC often secretes ADH ectopically, leading to SIADH. 
  • Manifestations: hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and confusion or seizures. 
  • Mechanism: inappropriate water retention without volume expansion.

 

Option B. Ectopic ACTH production leading to Cushing’s syndrome: 

 

  • SCLC may produce ACTH, leading to paraneoplastic Cushing’s syndrome. Lab findings: high cortisol, hypokalemic alkalosis, hyperglycemia.
  • Mechanism: ectopic ACTH → bilateral adrenal hyperplasia→ Explains this patient’s low potassium and weakness.

 

Option C. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome: 

 

  • Caused by autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. Presents with proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity (unlike myasthenia gravis). Strongly associated with SCLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paraneoplastic syndrome in SCLC:

questions.text: A 10‑year‑old child presents with progressively worsening headaches and vomiting. MRI of the brain, as shown in the image, demonstrates a cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule in the cerebellum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pilocytic Astrocytoma

 

  • Pilocytic Astrocytoma is a WHO Grade I tumor, commonly seen in children and young adults.
  • Classic MRI findings: A cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule (as seen in the image). Importantly, the cyst wall does not enhance, distinguishing it from other tumors.
  • Commonly found in the cerebellum and often associated with NF-1 when optic pathway gliomas are seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medulloblastoma: Typically appears as a midline cerebellar mass in children, but is solid, not cystic with mural nodules. Often shows restricted diffusion.

 

Option B. Ependymoma: Arises from the fourth ventricle, often shows calcification and extension through foramina of Luschka and Magendie.

 

Option D. Hemangioblastoma: Also cystic with mural nodule but typically occurs in adults, often in the cerebellum, and may be associated with von Hippel–Lindau disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pilocytic Astrocytoma should be suspected in pediatric posterior fossa cystic lesions with enhancing mural nodules and non-enhancing cyst walls. 
  • The appearance is pathognomonic on MRI and helps in distinguishing from other posterior fossa tumors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and dyspareunia for the past 3 years. On examination, her vaginal mucosa appears pale and dry. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her urogenital symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal estrogen cream

 

  • This woman’s symptoms — recurrent UTIs, vaginal dryness, dyspareunia, and pale mucosa — are classic for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM), previously termed atrophic vaginitis.
  • After menopause, estrogen levels fall, leading to:
    • Thinning of vaginal and urethral epithelium
    • Decreased glycogen content → loss of protective lactobacilli
    • Increased vaginal pH → predisposition to infection
    • Vaginal dryness, irritation, and dyspareunia

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line: Local vaginal estrogen therapy (cream, tablet, or ring).
    • Restores local estrogen levels.
    • Improves vaginal epithelium, blood flow, and pH balance.
    • Reduces recurrent UTIs by restoring the normal flora and mucosal barrier.
  • Systemic absorption is minimal, so it is safe for most women unless contraindicated (e.g., history of estrogen-dependent cancer).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral bisphosphonates: Incorrect. Used for osteoporosis, not for urogenital atrophy.

 

Option B. Systemic hormone replacement therapy: Incorrect. Effective but not first-line for localized urogenital symptoms; higher systemic risks.

 

Option D. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation: Incorrect. Prevent osteoporosis but do not relieve vaginal or urinary symptoms of menopause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genitourinary syndrome of menopause results from estrogen deficiency causing vaginal and urinary tract atrophy.
  • The treatment of choice is local vaginal estrogen therapy, which directly relieves dryness, dyspareunia, and recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old G3P2 woman, 10 days postpartum, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding. She had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Her temperature is 38.2°C, and examination reveals a subinvoluted, tender uterus with a patulous cervical os. Ultrasound demonstrates echogenic material in the uterine cavity. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and uterine evacuation

 

  • This presentation is typical of secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) — defined as excessive vaginal bleeding occurring 24 hours to 12 weeks after delivery.

 

Likely Cause:

 

  • The patient has retained products of conception (RPOC) complicated by endometritis, as evidenced by:
    • Fever (38.2°C)
    • Tender, sub involuted uterus
    • Echogenic material on ultrasound
  • These findings indicate infected retained tissue inside the uterus.

 

Management Steps:

 

  1. Start broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin + metronidazole ± gentamicin) to treat endometritis.
  2. After adequate antibiotic coverage, perform uterine evacuation (suction curettage) to remove retained tissue and stop bleeding.
  3. Continue uterotonics (like oxytocin) as adjuncts to improve uterine tone.
  • This combined approach addresses both infection and mechanical cause of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin infusion alone: Incorrect. Useful only for uterine atony, not when retained products or infection are present.

 

Option B. Immediate hysterectomy: Incorrect. Reserved for cases of uncontrolled hemorrhage unresponsive to conservative management or severe uterine sepsis.

 

Option C. Oral methylergonovine only: Incorrect. Appropriate for subinvolution of the uterus without infection, but inadequate here due to infection and retained tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In secondary postpartum hemorrhage, if ultrasound shows retained products with signs of infection, the correct management is broad-spectrum antibiotics followed by uterine evacuation to control infection and stop bleeding.

questions.text: When should the final switch from warfarin to heparin be made to minimize the risk of fetal complications and maternal bleeding during delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 36 weeks

 

  • Warfarin is a teratogenic medication that can cross the placenta and cause fetal hemorrhage, warfarin embryopathy, and fetal anomalies. 
  • However, it is often used in pregnant women with high thromboembolic risk due to mechanical heart valves, as it is more effective than heparin in preventing clot formation. 
  • The recommendation is to switch from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation to reduce the risk of maternal bleeding during delivery and prevent fetal complications.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin) does not cross the placenta and is safe for both the mother and the fetus. 
  • Switching at 36 weeks provides time for stabilization on heparin before labor or cesarean delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For pregnant women on warfarin due to cardiac disease or thromboembolic risk, the final switch to heparin is made at 36 weeks gestation to reduce the risk of bleeding during labor while maintaining effective anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea for 8 months following a severe postpartum hemorrhage. She also reports failure of lactation and loss of pubic hair. Laboratory evaluation would most likely show which of the following finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low gonadotropin and cortisol levels

 

  • This clinical scenario is characteristic of Sheehan’s syndrome (postpartum pituitary necrosis) — a condition caused by ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary gland following massive postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • During pregnancy, the pituitary gland enlarges due to lactotroph hyperplasia, increasing its oxygen demand.
  • Severe hypovolemic shock from PPH causes ischemic damage to the pituitary.
  • The result is panhypopituitarism, leading to deficiency of anterior pituitary hormones, including:
    • Gonadotropins (FSH, LH) → Amenorrhea, loss of libido, pubic/axillary hair loss
    • Prolactin → Failure of lactation
    • ACTH → Secondary adrenal insufficiency → Low cortisol
    • TSH → Secondary hypothyroidism (fatigue, cold intolerance)

 

Key Clinical Features:

 

  • History of severe postpartum hemorrhage
  • Failure to lactate postpartum (due to ↓ prolactin)
  • Amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea (due to ↓ FSH, LH)
  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair (due to ↓ androgens from low LH/ACTH)
  • Symptoms of adrenal insufficiency: fatigue, hypotension, weight loss

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated FSH and LH levels: Incorrect.

 

  • This occurs in primary ovarian failure (premature menopause), not in pituitary failure.
  • In Sheehan’s, FSH and LH are low due to pituitary necrosis.

 

Option B. Elevated prolactin levels: Incorrect.

 

  • In Sheehan’s syndrome, prolactin levels are low due to loss of lactotrophs, leading to failure of lactation.
  • Elevated prolactin is seen in prolactinoma or dopamine antagonist use.

 

Option D. Elevated testosterone levels: Incorrect.

 

  • Androgens are reduced due to low LH and ACTH.
  • Elevated testosterone is seen in PCOS or androgen-secreting tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sheehan’s syndrome results from ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • It presents with failure of lactation, secondary amenorrhea, and loss of pubic hair, with laboratory findings showing low gonadotropins and cortisol levels due to anterior pituitary hormone deficiency.

choices.text: Cervical priming and Induction of labor

questions.text: A 42-week pregnant woman presents for evaluation. Ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm, and a non-stress test (NST) shows decreased variability with variable decelerations. The cervix is unfavorable. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate cesarean section

 

This is a case of post-term pregnancy (42 weeks) with fetal distress features.


Let’s analyze the findings:

 

  1. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) = 4 cm:
    • This indicates oligohydramnios (AFI < 5 cm).
    • Oligohydramnios in post-term pregnancy suggests placental insufficiency and a compromised fetus.
  2. Non-Stress Test (NST):
    • Shows decreased variability and variable decelerations → both are signs of fetal hypoxia or distress.
  3. Unfavorable cervix:
    • Cervical priming and induction would take time, which is unsafe in the presence of fetal distress.

 

Hence, immediate delivery is needed, and since the cervix is unfavorable, the safest and quickest method is cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management with daily NST: Contraindicated in fetal distress and post-term pregnancy with oligohydramnios — delaying delivery may worsen hypoxia.

 

Option C. Cervical priming and induction of labor: Not advisable because induction in the setting of fetal distress and poor Bishop’s score may lead to fetal compromise or stillbirth.

 

Option D. Amnioinfusion followed by expectant management: Amnioinfusion is useful in intrapartum variable decelerations during labor, not in a post-term, antepartum setting with an unfavorable cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a post-term pregnancy (≥42 weeks) with oligohydramnios (AFI ≤ 5 cm) and abnormal NST (decreased variability, decelerations), the presence of an unfavorable cervix makes immediate cesarean section the most appropriate and life-saving management for the fetus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was given a single dose of Thiopentone for induction of anesthesia. After 20 minutes he regains consciousness again and is aware of his surroundings. Which property of Thiopentone is responsible for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rapid Redistribution

 

  • "Rapid Redistribution," accurately describes the process by which thiopentone, after inducing anesthesia, is redistributed from the brain to other, less well-perfused tissues like muscle and fat. 
  • This redistribution results in a decrease in the drug's plasma concentration and its effect on the brain, allowing the patient to regain consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rapid Elimination: Refers to the speed at which a drug is removed from the body, which typically involves processes such as renal excretion or hepatic metabolism. Thiopentone has a long elimination half-life, so this is not the reason for the rapid recovery of consciousness.

 

Option B. Rapid Reabsorption: Is not a term commonly associated with the pharmacokinetics of anesthesia recovery. Reabsorption typically refers to the process by which substances are transported back into the bloodstream from the renal tubules. This does not apply to thiopentone and anesthesia recovery.

 

Option C. Rapid Metabolism: Refers to how quickly a drug is chemically altered by the body's metabolic processes. While thiopentone is metabolized by the liver, its rapid recovery is not due to its metabolism, as the metabolic breakdown of thiopentone is relatively slow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone induces rapid anesthesia but also allows for quick recovery due to its rapid redistribution from the brain to less perfused tissues, which reduces its concentration in the central nervous system and restores consciousness.

questions.text: In a lymph node, which region contains high endothelial venules lined by cuboidal endothelium that facilitates lymphocyte migration from blood into lymphoid tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracortex (deep cortex)

 

  • The paracortex (also called deep cortex or thymus-dependent cortex) is the region between the nodular cortex and medulla. 
  • It contains postcapillary venules that are unusual in being lined by cuboidal endothelium rather than the typical squamous endothelium - hence called high endothelial venules (HEVs).
  • This "high" endothelium bears receptors recognized by circulating lymphocytes and readily allows passage of lymphocytes between the bloodstream and surrounding tissue. 
  • The paracortex is mainly populated by T-lymphocytes, which is why it's also called the thymus-dependent zone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germinal centers of lymphoid follicles: These are sites of B-lymphocyte proliferation within lymphoid follicles, containing actively dividing lymphoblasts. They would be correct if asking about antibody production sites.

 

Option B. Subcapsular sinus: This is the space just beneath the capsule where afferent lymph enters. It's lined by endothelium but not the specialized high endothelial type.

 

Option D. Medullary sinuses: These are lymphatic channels in the medulla that collect lymph for drainage through efferent vessels. They have regular endothelial lining, not high endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High endothelial venules in the paracortex of lymph nodes are the specialized sites for lymphocyte trafficking between blood and lymphoid tissue.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with fatigue and dyspnea. He has severe hypotension (SBP - 60 mmHg), cool extremities, and bedside ultrasound shows biventricular failure. His troponin T is markedly elevated (2320 ng/L), and a rapid flu test is positive. He remains in shock despite maximal inotropes and vasopressors. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) V-A ECMO

 

  • This patient has fulminant viral myocarditis with severe, refractory cardiogenic shock and biventricular failure.
  • V-A ECMO (Venoarterial Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation) provides both cardiac and respiratory support, maintaining systemic perfusion, reducing myocardial work, and allowing time for potential myocardial recovery, which is especially important in acute viral myocarditis.
  • V-A ECMO can serve as a bridge to recovery, further intervention, or transplantation in cases of profound cardiogenic shock unresponsive to medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency coronary arteriography: Is not indicated because there are no features of acute coronary syndrome; the global myocardial dysfunction is most consistent with viral myocarditis.

 

Option C. Percutaneous LV assist devices: Provide only left-sided support, which is inadequate in a patient with biventricular (RV and LV) failure.

 

Option D. Insertion of an IABP: Intra-aortic balloon pump support is insufficient in cases of severe biventricular dysfunction and does not provide adequate circulatory support for severe shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In biventricular failure and refractory shock, V-A ECMO is the most appropriate intervention to provide temporary full cardiopulmonary support, allowing for myocardial recovery and protecting end-organ function

questions.text: What is the name of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triangle of doom

 

  • The Triangle of Doom is an important anatomical area in inguinal and laparoscopic hernia repair.
  • It is bounded by:
    • Medially: Ductus deferens (vas deferens)
    • Laterally: Gonadal vessels
    • Posteriorly: Peritoneal edge
  • It contains vital vascular structures, including the external iliac artery and vein, and manipulation in this area poses a high risk of major vascular injury, hence the name "Triangle of Doom."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triangle of pain: This is a separate region lateral to the gonadal vessels, containing cutaneous nerves (e.g., femoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves). Injury here results in neuropathy and pain, not vascular injury.

 

Option C. Triangle of Calot: This is encountered in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Corona mortis: The corona mortis refers to an anastomotic vascular connection between the obturator artery and the external iliac artery. It is at risk during hernia surgery or pelvic procedures but is not the region shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Triangle of Doom is an area in inguinal hernia repair containing major vessels (external iliac artery and vein). 
  • Injury in this region can lead to catastrophic hemorrhage, making careful surgical dissection essential.

questions.text: A woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage but survives after receiving 6 units of blood transfusion and an emergency hysterectomy. This situation best represents which maternal health indicator?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maternal near miss

 

  • A maternal near miss (MNM) refers to a woman who nearly dies but survives a life-threatening complication during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy.
  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) definition:
  • “A maternal near miss is a woman who survives life-threatening conditions (such as severe hemorrhage, sepsis, or eclampsia) that occur during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy.”
  • Key Features of a Maternal Near Miss:
    • The woman survives the complication.
    • The event involves organ dysfunction or intervention to prevent death (e.g., massive transfusion, hysterectomy, ICU care).
    • The condition is potentially fatal — here, massive postpartum hemorrhage requiring 6 units of blood and hysterectomy clearly qualifies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal mortality ratio: Incorrect.

 

  • Refers to the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given period.
  • This patient survived; hence, it’s not maternal mortality.

 

Option C. Maternal morbidity: Incorrect.

 

  • Refers to any illness or complication during pregnancy or childbirth, whether mild or severe.
  • “Near miss” is a specific severe form of maternal morbidity, where the woman nearly dies.

 

Option D. Lifetime risk: Incorrect.

 

  • Represents the probability that a 15-year-old girl will eventually die of maternal causes during her reproductive years.
  • Not applicable to this individual event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A maternal near miss occurs when a woman survives a life-threatening obstetric complication, such as severe postpartum hemorrhage requiring massive transfusion or hysterectomy.
  • It is an important indicator of the quality of obstetric care and helps identify gaps in emergency maternal health services.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man sustains a fracture at the junction of middle and lateral thirds of his clavicle. Which ligament primarily maintains the weight transmission from the upper limb to the axial skeleton despite this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The coracoclavicular ligament, consisting of conoid and trapezoid parts, is the primary structure transmitting weight from the scapula to the clavicle. 
  • The clavicle usually fractures between the attachments of the coracoclavicular ligament (laterally) and the costoclavicular ligament (medially), which corresponds to the junction of the lateral and middle thirds. 
  • Even with a clavicular fracture, the coracoclavicular ligament maintains the connection between the scapula and the lateral fragment of the clavicle, allowing continued weight transmission from the upper limb through this ligament to the clavicle and then to the sternum via the sternoclavicular joint.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternoclavicular ligament: Stabilizes the sternoclavicular joint but doesn't directly connect the scapula to the clavicle.

 

Option C. Acromioclavicular ligament: Stabilizes the acromioclavicular joint but is weaker than the coracoclavicular ligament for weight transmission.

 

Option D. Coracoacromial ligament: Forms an arch over the shoulder joint but doesn't participate in weight transmission from the upper limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoclavicular ligament is crucial for weight transmission from the scapula to the clavicle, explaining why the clavicle commonly fractures between this ligament and the costoclavicular ligament.

choices.text: COPD is more common in females than males globally
The leading risk factor for COPD worldwide is outdoor air pollution
COPD prevalence increases with age and peaks in the 6th-7th decade of life
Biomass fuel exposure accounts for less than 10% of COPD cases globally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the epidemiology of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) COPD prevalence increases with age and peaks in the 6th-7th decade of life

 

  • COPD prevalence demonstrates a clear age-related pattern, with incidence and prevalence rates increasing significantly with advancing age. 
  • The disease typically peaks in the 6th-7th decade of life (50-70 years), which corresponds to the cumulative effects of prolonged exposure to risk factors, particularly tobacco smoke. 
  • This age distribution reflects the chronic progressive nature of the disease and the time required for significant lung function deterioration to manifest clinically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. COPD is more common in females than males globally: COPD has traditionally been more common in males due to higher smoking rates, though the gender gap is narrowing in developed countries as female smoking rates have increased.

 

Option B. The leading risk factor for COPD worldwide is outdoor air pollution: Tobacco smoking remains the leading risk factor for COPD worldwide, accounting for approximately 80-90% of cases in developed countries.

 

Option D. Biomass fuel exposure accounts for less than 10% of COPD cases globally: Biomass fuel exposure is a significant risk factor, particularly in developing countries, accounting for approximately 25-30% of COPD cases globally, especially among women and children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • COPD prevalence increases significantly with age, peaking in the 6th-7th decade
  • Tobacco smoking remains the most important risk factor globally
  • Biomass fuel exposure is a major contributor to COPD burden in developing countries

choices.text: Hepatic metabolism leading to rapid clearance
Redistribution from the brain to peripheral tissues
Rapid renal excretion of the unchanged drug
High lipid solubility preventing sustained CNS concentrations

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy is induced with thiopentone. The anesthesiologist selects this agent due to its rapid onset and ultra-short duration of action. The patient is then maintained on inhalational anesthetics for the rest of the procedure. Based on the pharmacokinetics of this anesthetic, which of the following is the primary reason for its ultra-short duration of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Redistribution from the brain to peripheral tissues

 

  • Thiopental, a barbiturate, has an ultra-short duration of action due to its high lipid solubility. 
  • After intravenous administration, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier, inducing anesthesia within seconds. 
  • However, its effect wanes quickly, not due to metabolism or excretion, but because of redistribution from the brain (a high-perfusion organ) to other tissues like muscle and fat, which act as reservoirs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic metabolism leading to rapid clearance: Incorrect. While thiopental undergoes hepatic metabolism, this process does not account for its ultra-short duration of action; redistribution is the primary factor.

 

Option C. Rapid renal excretion of the unchanged drug: Incorrect. Thiopental is metabolized in the liver; it is not excreted unchanged by the kidneys.

 

Option D. High lipid solubility preventing sustained CNS concentrations: Incorrect. Although thiopental is highly lipid-soluble, its rapid redistribution, not sustained lipid solubility, is responsible for its short duration of CNS effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ultra-short duration of action of thiopental is primarily due to its rapid redistribution from the brain to less vascularized peripheral tissues, not hepatic metabolism or renal excretion. 
  • Redistribution is a key pharmacokinetic property of highly lipid-soluble drugs used for anesthesia induction.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Tedizolid are correct? 

 

  1. Tedizolid binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit to inhibit protein synthesis.
  2. It is active against gram‑positive organisms, including vancomycin‑resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA).
  3. Tedizolid is primarily excreted unchanged in the urine.
  4. It exhibits excellent oral bioavailability.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 2. It is active against gram‑positive organisms, including vancomycin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA): Tedizolid is a next‑generation oxazolidinone effective against gram‑positive pathogens, including MRSA and VRSA. It is particularly valuable when resistance to vancomycin is present.

 

Statement 4. It exhibits excellent oral bioavailability: Tedizolid has excellent oral bioavailability (~90%), allowing convenient once‑daily oral dosing comparable in efficacy to IV administration.

 

Incorrect statements: 

 

Statement 1. Tedizolid binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit to inhibit protein synthesis: Tedizolid, like linezolid, binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit—not the 30S—blocking the formation of the initiation complex and thereby inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Statement 3. Tedizolid is primarily excreted unchanged in the urine: Tedizolid is metabolized in the liver, not excreted unchanged. Its hepatic biotransformation reduces the risk of accumulation in renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tedizolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that binds the 50S ribosomal subunit, inhibiting protein synthesis.
  • It demonstrates excellent oral absorption and broad gram‑positive coverage, including MRSA and VRSA, and undergoes hepatic metabolism rather than renal excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the most accurate information for reporting the 'T stage' of esophageal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endoscopic USG

 

  • Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the most accurate modality for determining the T stage (depth of tumor invasion) in esophageal carcinoma. 
  • EUS provides highly detailed images of the layers of the esophageal wall, allowing precise determination of tumor depth invasion through visualization of the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT: Incorrect. CT scan is useful for colon cancer, identifying haematogenous metastases and is primarily used to identify distant metastasis (M stage). CT has limited axial resolution which precludes reliable assessment of both depth of wall penetration and early lymph node involvement.

 

Option B. PET: Incorrect. PET scanning is valuable for detecting distant metastatic disease not seen on CT alone, focused on identifying metabolically active tumor sites, but lacks the resolution to accurately determine depth of tumor penetration through the esophageal wall layers.

 

Option C. MRI: Incorrect. MRI doesn't expose the patient to ionizing radiation but is primarily used for rectal cancer, metastasis detection rather than precise T-staging. It lacks the resolution needed for accurate T-staging compared to EUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For precise T-staging of esophageal carcinoma, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is superior as it visualizes the multi-layered structure of the esophageal wall, allowing accurate determination of tumor depth penetration.

choices.text: Strengthening tertiary care facilities in urban areas
Health and Wellness Centers (HWCs) as the foundation of healthcare delivery
Expansion of private healthcare partnerships exclusively
Focus on curative and rehabilitative services

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary healthcare approach adopted by India under the National Health Policy 2017 to achieve Universal Health Coverage (UHC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health and Wellness Centers (HWCs) as the foundation of healthcare delivery

 

  • The National Health Policy 2017 emphasizes transforming existing Sub Health Centers and Primary Health Centers into Health and Wellness Centers (HWCs) to provide comprehensive primary healthcare services. 
  • This approach focuses on preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care closer to the community, forming the foundation for achieving Universal Health Coverage through the Ayushman Bharat initiative.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strengthening tertiary care facilities in urban areas: While tertiary care is important, the primary focus is on strengthening primary healthcare infrastructure, not tertiary care facilities

 

Option C. Expansion of private healthcare partnerships exclusively: The policy emphasizes public healthcare strengthening as the primary approach, though public-private partnerships are considered complementary

 

Option D. Focus on curative and rehabilitative services: The policy specifically emphasizes preventive and promotive care as key components of the comprehensive healthcare approach

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • National Health Policy 2017 prioritizes primary healthcare through Health and Wellness Centers
  • The policy aims to achieve Universal Health Coverage with focus on comprehensive care
  • Preventive and promotive care are emphasized alongside curative services in the new healthcare model

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following is not included in upper GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meckel’s diverticulitis

 

  • Meckel’s diverticulum arises from the distal ileum, making it part of the lower GI tract.
  • While it can cause painless bleeding, especially in children, it's anatomically not part of the upper GI (which ends at the ligament of Treitz).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GAVE: GAVE (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia) is a vascular lesion in the antrum of the stomach, sometimes called "watermelon stomach." It can cause chronic or acute upper GI bleeding, often leading to iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Duodenal Adenocarcinoma: The duodenum is part of the upper GI tract, and tumors here may ulcerate or erode vessels, causing bleeding. Although rare, duodenal cancers can present with melena or anemia due to occult or overt bleeding.

 

Option D. Mallory-Weiss Tear: A mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction, often caused by forceful vomiting. It leads to hematemesis and is a classic cause of acute upper GI bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Upper GI bleeding sources lie proximal to the ligament of Treitz — includes esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.

questions.text: A patient from a selenium-deficient region in China presents with cardiomyopathy and muscle weakness. This same mineral deficiency would also impair which of the following antioxidant defense mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase activity

 

  • Selenium is an essential trace mineral that serves as a cofactor for several enzymes, most importantly glutathione peroxidase (GPx) — a key enzyme in the body’s antioxidant defense system.

 

Role of Glutathione Peroxidase:

 

  • GPx protects cells from oxidative damage by reducing hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and lipid peroxides to water and corresponding alcohols.
  • The reaction catalyzed is:

 

2 GSH + H2 O2 → GSSG + 2 H2 O

 

(Where GSH = reduced glutathione, GSSG = oxidized glutathione)

  • This reaction prevents accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can damage cellular membranes, lipids, and proteins.

 

Selenium Deficiency:

 

  • Decreases glutathione peroxidase activity → accumulation of ROS → oxidative tissue injury.
  • Associated with Keshan disease, an endemic cardiomyopathy seen in selenium-deficient regions (especially in parts of China).
  • Also causes skeletal muscle weakness due to increased oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superoxide dismutase in mitochondria:

 

  • Converts superoxide radicals (O₂⁻) to hydrogen peroxide.
  • Requires manganese (Mn) in mitochondria and copper/zinc (Cu/Zn) in the cytosol, not selenium.

 

Option C. Catalase function:

 

  • Converts hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) to water and oxygen.
  • Located mainly in peroxisomes and requires heme (iron) as a cofactor: not selenium.

 

Option D. Vitamin E regeneration:

 

  • Vitamin E acts as a lipid-soluble antioxidant that prevents lipid peroxidation.
  • Selenium deficiency does not directly affect its regeneration, though both have synergistic roles in preventing oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenium is an essential cofactor for glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that detoxifies hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxides, thereby protecting cells from oxidative injury. 
  • Selenium deficiency impairs this antioxidant defense, leading to Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and muscle weakness.

choices.text: The pyloric region is supplied by the right gastric artery from the common hepatic artery
The left gastric artery provides the dominant blood supply to the pylorus
The gastroduodenal artery directly supplies the pyloric sphincter
The short gastric arteries are the primary supply to this region

questions.text: A 6-week-old male infant presents with persistent projectile vomiting after feeding, weight loss, and dehydration. Physical examination reveals a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium. Ultrasound confirms hypertrophic pyloric stenosis with a thickened pyloric muscle measuring 5mm. During pyloromyotomy, the surgeon must carefully divide the hypertrophied muscle while preserving the underlying mucosa. Understanding the anatomy of this region, which statement correctly describes the blood supply that must be preserved during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The pyloric region is supplied by the right gastric artery from the common hepatic artery

 

  • The pylorus, located at the distal end of the stomach, receives its main blood supply from branches of the hepatic artery.
  • The right gastric artery, arising from the common hepatic artery, supplies the lesser curvature and pyloric region.
  • It anastomoses with the left gastric artery along the lesser curvature, maintaining collateral flow.
  • During Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy, it is crucial to preserve the mucosa and maintain the integrity of the right gastric artery to ensure adequate perfusion and prevent postoperative complications.4

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left gastric artery provides the dominant blood supply to the pylorus: Incorrect. Supplies the upper part of the lesser curvature, not the pyloric region.

 

Option C. The gastroduodenal artery directly supplies the pyloric sphincter: Incorrect. Supplies the duodenum and head of the pancreas, not directly the pylorus.

 

Option D. The short gastric arteries are the primary supply to this region: Incorrect. Arise from the splenic artery and supply the fundus, not the pylorus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pylorus is primarily supplied by the right gastric artery (from the common hepatic artery).
  • Preserving this vessel during pyloromyotomy is essential to avoid ischemia and ensure proper healing of the pyloric region.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the new-generation drugs? 

 

  1. Semaglutide is a GLP-1 agonist used orally for type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  2. Siponimod modulates sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors and is used in multiple sclerosis.
