  3. Solriamfetol is a dopamine and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor used in narcolepsy and OSA-related sleepiness.
  4. Selinexor is a VEGF receptor inhibitor used in renal cell carcinoma.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Statement 4. Selinexor is a VEGF receptor inhibitor used in renal cell carcinoma: Selinexor is not a VEGF receptor inhibitor and is not used for renal cell carcinoma. It is a selective inhibitor of nuclear export (SINE) that blocks exportin 1 (XPO1), a nuclear export protein. By preventing the export of tumor suppressor proteins from the nucleus, Selinexor promotes apoptosis in malignant cells. It is primarily used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Semaglutide is a GLP-1 agonist used orally for type 2 diabetes mellitus: Correct. Semaglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that enhances glucose-dependent insulin secretion, suppresses glucagon release, slows gastric emptying, and promotes weight loss. It is available both as a once-weekly subcutaneous injection and as an oral formulation (Rybelsus®) for type 2 diabetes mellitus.

 

Statement 2. Siponimod modulates sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors and is used in multiple sclerosis: Correct. Siponimod selectively modulates sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) receptors (subtypes 1 and 5), leading to sequestration of lymphocytes in lymph nodes and reducing neuroinflammation. It is indicated for secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).

 

Statement 3. Solriamfetol is a dopamine and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor used in narcolepsy and OSA-related sleepiness: Correct. Solriamfetol is a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that promotes wakefulness and is approved for excessive daytime sleepiness associated with narcolepsy and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). It is not an amphetamine, and its mechanism differs from modafinil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Semaglutide is an oral and injectable GLP-1 agonist used for type 2 diabetes.
  • Siponimod is an S1P receptor modulator approved for secondary progressive MS.
  • Solriamfetol is a DNRI used to treat excessive sleepiness in narcolepsy and OSA.
  • Selinexor is an XPO1 inhibitor for multiple myeloma & DLBCL, not used in renal cancer.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding genomic imprinting are correct? 

 

  1. Genomic imprinting refers to epigenetic silencing of one parental allele through DNA methylation.
  2. Prader–Willi syndrome results from loss of maternal gene expression on chromosome 15q11–q13.
  3. Angelman syndrome is associated with deletion or inactivation of the maternal UBE3A gene.
  4. Uniparental disomy can cause imprinting disorders by duplicating the inactive allele and deleting the active one.
  5. Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome is associated with altered imprinting at 11p15, involving IGF-2 overexpression.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1, 3, 4 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. Genomic imprinting refers to epigenetic silencing of one parental allele through DNA methylation: Correct. Genomic imprinting = parent-of-origin–specific expression due to methylation of one allele.

 

Statement 3. Angelman syndrome is associated with deletion or inactivation of the maternal UBE3A gene: Correct. Maternal UBE3A is active; paternal allele is imprinted → loss → AS.

 

Statement 4. Uniparental disomy can cause imprinting disorders by duplicating the inactive allele and deleting the active one: Correct. UPD can cause imprinting diseases by duplicating the imprinted (silent) allele → no active gene left.

 

Statement 5. Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome is associated with altered imprinting at 11p15, involving IGF-2 overexpression: Correct.
Characterized by:

 

  • IGF-2 overexpression,
  • macrosomia
  • organomegaly
  • predisposition to Wilms tumor

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Prader–Willi syndrome results from loss of maternal gene expression on chromosome 15q11–q13: Incorrect.
PWS occurs due to:

 

  • Paternal deletion, or
  • maternal uniparental disomy
    Maternal allele of this region is normally imprinted (silent).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic mechanism where one parental allele is silenced by DNA methylation. 
  • Disorders such as Prader–Willi, Angelman, and Beckwith–Wiedemann syndromes arise from deletions, mutations, or uniparental disomy affecting imprinted genes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about drugs used in CHF are correct?

 

  1. Nesiritide has a short half-life due to breakdown by neprilysin.
  2. Sacubitril may increase risk of angioedema when combined with ACE inhibitors.
  3. Nesiritide is used orally for chronic heart failure.
  4. Sacubitril improves cardiac function by inhibiting β-receptors.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2 only

 

Statement 1. Nesiritide has a short half-life due to breakdown by neprilysin: Correct.Nesiritide, a recombinant BNP, is rapidly degraded by the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase, NEP), limiting its duration of action. This breakdown accounts for its short half-life, which restricts its use to acute settings only.

 

Statement 2. Sacubitril may increase the risk of angioedema when combined with ACE inhibitors: Correct. Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, which degrades bradykinin. When combined with ACE inhibitors (which also increase bradykinin), this raises the risk of angioedema. Therefore, sacubitril is used with ARBs (e.g., valsartan), not ACE inhibitors.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

 Statement 3. Nesiritide is used orally for chronic heart failure: Incorrect. Nesiritide is administered intravenously and is indicated for acute decompensated heart failure, not chronic therapy. Its short half-life and rapid degradation make it unsuitable for oral or long-term use.

 

Statement 4. Sacubitril improves cardiac function by inhibiting β-receptors: Incorrect. Sacubitril has no action on β-receptors. Its mechanism is neprilysin inhibition, leading to increased levels of natriuretic peptides (e.g., BNP, ANP), which improve heart failure symptoms by promoting vasodilation and natriuresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nesiritide has a short half-life due to neprilysin-mediated degradation and is used only IV for acute CHF.
  • Sacubitril must not be used with ACE inhibitors due to increased risk of angioedema, and acts by neprilysin inhibition, not via β-blockade.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is started on chloramphenicol therapy for treatment of Salmonella typhi infection. After starting the drug, the patient develops bone-marrow suppression. Chloramphenicol acts by inhibiting the enzyme responsible for peptide bond formation during translation. Which RNA component of the ribosome contains peptidyl transferase activity in prokaryotes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 23S rRNA

 

  • Protein synthesis in prokaryotes occurs on the 70S ribosome, which is made of:
    • 50S large subunit → contains 23S rRNA + 5S rRNA
    • 30S small subunit → contains 16S rRNA
  • The enzyme responsible for peptide bond formation during translation is called peptidyl transferase.
  • This activity is not a protein enzyme, but is carried out by rRNA itself, making the ribosome a ribozyme.
  • Thus, 23S rRNA is the site of peptidyl transferase activity in prokaryotes
  • 23S rRNA, located in the 50S subunit, contains the peptidyl transferase center (PTC).
  • It catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds between amino acids, allowing the growing polypeptide chain to elongate.
  • Drugs such as chloramphenicol work by binding to the 50S subunit and inhibiting this peptidyl transferase activity, stopping protein synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 16S rRNA: Part of the 30S small subunit; involved in mRNA binding and initiation, not peptide bond formation.

 

Option C. 28S rRNA: Found in eukaryotic 60S ribosomal subunit, not in prokaryotes.

 

Option D. 5S rRNA: Part of the 50S subunit but does not have peptidyl transferase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In prokaryotes, the 23S rRNA component of the 50S ribosomal subunit possesses peptidyl transferase activity, which catalyzes peptide bond formation during protein synthesis. 
  • Chloramphenicol inhibits this enzyme, leading to inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis and possible bone marrow suppression as an adverse effect.

choices.text: To neutralize the charge on the protein
To reduce and break disulfide bonds
To coat the protein with negative charges
To denature the protein's secondary structure

questions.text: During SDS-PAGE analysis, a protein sample is treated with SDS and β-mercaptoethanol before electrophoresis. What is the primary purpose of β-mercaptoethanol in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To reduce and break disulfide bonds

 

  • β-Mercaptoethanol (or dithiothreitol) is used in SDS-PAGE (Sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis) to reduce and break disulfide bonds between cysteine residues. 
  • This is essential for complete denaturation and separation of multimeric proteins into individual polypeptide chains. 
  • The reducing agent contains sulfhydryl groups that cleave disulfide bonds through reduction, converting cystines back to cysteines. 
  • This ensures that proteins are fully linearized and can be separated based solely on molecular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To neutralize the charge on the protein: SDS, not β-mercaptoethanol, overwhelms the protein's intrinsic charges by coating it with negative charges.

 

Option C. To coat the protein with negative charges: This is the function of SDS, which binds at approximately one molecule per two peptide bonds, providing uniform negative charge density.

 

Option D. To denature the protein's secondary structure: While β-mercaptoethanol helps complete denaturation by breaking disulfide bonds, SDS is primarily responsible for disrupting non-covalent interactions and denaturing secondary structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-Mercaptoethanol specifically reduces disulfide bonds in SDS-PAGE, enabling complete separation of polypeptide chains for accurate molecular weight determination.

questions.text:
Which of the following fungi are classified as endemic (systemic dimorphic) fungal pathogens? 

 

  1. Coccidioides immitis
  2. Cryptococcus neoformans
  3. Histoplasma capsulatum
  4. Aspergillus fumigatus
  5. Blastomyces dermatitidis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 only

 

1. Coccidioides immitis:

 

  • Type: Dimorphic fungus
  • Endemic area: Southwestern United States (California, Arizona), Central & South America
  • Disease: Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever)
  • Pathology: Produces spherules with endospores in tissue (instead of yeast).

 

3. Histoplasma capsulatum:

 

  • Type: Dimorphic fungus
  • Endemic area: Ohio and Mississippi River valleys; some parts of India
  • Reservoir: Soil contaminated with bat or bird droppings
  • Disease: Histoplasmosis – pulmonary and disseminated forms
  • Pathology: Intracellular yeast seen in macrophages.

 

5. Blastomyces dermatitidis:

 

  • Type: Dimorphic fungus
  • Endemic area: Eastern and Central USA; Great Lakes region
  • Disease: Blastomycosis – involves lungs, skin, and bone
  • Pathology: Broad-based budding yeast on microscopy.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Non-Endemic / Opportunistic Fungi:

 

2. Cryptococcus neoformans:

 

  • Type: Encapsulated yeast (not dimorphic)
  • Epidemiology: Worldwide; opportunistic (esp. in HIV/AIDS)
  • Source: Pigeon droppings
  • Disease: Cryptococcal meningitis

 

4. Aspergillus fumigates:

 

  • Type: Filamentous mold (not dimorphic)
  • Epidemiology: Ubiquitous environmental fungus
  • Disease: Aspergillosis (allergic, invasive, or colonizing types)

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Endemic mycoses — including Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, and Coccidioides immitis — are dimorphic fungi capable of infecting healthy individuals in specific geographic regions.
  • In contrast, Aspergillus and Cryptococcus are opportunistic fungi, typically affecting immunocompromised patients and not geographically restricted.

choices.text: It is associated with TP53 and BRCA1 mutations
It has the best overall prognosis among invasive breast cancers
It is also called as basal type of cancer
It is most likely to respond to trastuzumab therapy

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a painless lump in her left breast for 4 months. She has no family history of breast cancer. On examination, the lump is firm, irregular, and fixed to the surrounding tissue. No nipple discharge or skin dimpling is noted. A mammogram reveals a speculated mass with microcalcifications. Core needle biopsy shows infiltrating malignant epithelial cells forming duct-like structures surrounded by desmoplastic stroma. Immunohistochemistry profile is as follows. Which of the following statements regarding this tumor is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has the best overall prognosis among invasive breast cancers

 

The description fits Invasive Ductal Carcinoma – Luminal A subtype, based on IHC profile:

  • ER/PR positive, HER2 negative, low Ki-67 → Luminal A molecular subtype.
  • It has the best overall prognosis among invasive breast cancers 
  • Luminal A subtype = ER+, PR+, HER2–, low Ki-67
  • Best prognosis due to: Slow growth
  • Hormone receptor positivity → responsive to tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors
  • Fewer p53 mutations
  • Metastasis tends to occur late, often to bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is associated with TP53 and BRCA1 mutations: TP53 and BRCA1 mutations are typically linked with Basal-like (Triple-negative) carcinomas. Those tumors are ER-, PR-, HER2- and often high-grade, aggressive, and common in younger women. The patient here has ER+, PR+, HER2– → not basal-like.

 

Option C. It is also called the basal type of cancer: The basal type refers to triple-negative breast cancer (ER–, PR–, HER2–), which is aggressive, has a high Ki-67 index, and poor prognosis.

 

Option D. It is most likely to respond to trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab (Herceptin) targets HER2/neu-positive cancers. HER2-positive subtype = ER–, PR–, HER2+, showing high proliferation. This tumor is HER2-negative, hence won’t respond.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old G3P2 woman at 40 weeks gestation undergoes oxytocin augmentation for slow labor. Shortly after placental delivery, she suddenly develops severe dyspnea, hypotension, and seizure-like activity, followed by massive vaginal bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • This presentation is classic for amniotic fluid embolism (AFE), a catastrophic obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiovascular collapse, respiratory distress, seizure-like activity, and coagulopathy (DIC) occurring during or shortly after delivery.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Amniotic fluid (containing fetal cells, debris, or trophoblastic tissue) enters the maternal circulation through uterine veins during:
    • Labor (especially with strong contractions or oxytocin use)
    • Delivery (vaginal or cesarean)
    • Immediately after placental separation
  • This triggers a massive anaphylactoid reaction → pulmonary vasospasm, right heart failure, hypoxia, and DIC.

 

Clinical Features of Amniotic Fluid Embolism:

 

  • Respiratory distress: Sudden dyspnea, cyanosis
  • Cardiovascular collapse: Hypotension, shock, cardiac arrest
  • Seizure-like activity or coma
  • Coagulopathy/DIC: Massive bleeding from the uterus, IV sites, or wounds
  • Timing: Typically during labor, immediately after delivery, or after placental separation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine atony: Incorrect.

 

  • Causes postpartum hemorrhage but not respiratory distress, hypotension, or seizures.
  • The uterus is soft and boggy, but systemic collapse is absent.

 

Option C. Eclamptic seizure: Incorrect.

 

  • Occurs before delivery or during pregnancy, not immediately after placental expulsion.
  • Associated with hypertension and proteinuria, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Pulmonary thromboembolism: Incorrect.

 

  • May cause dyspnea and hypotension, but DIC and massive vaginal bleeding are not characteristic.
  • Onset is typically gradual rather than immediate post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) presents suddenly during or after delivery with hypotension, respiratory distress, seizure-like activity, and DIC-related bleeding.
  • It is caused by amniotic fluid entering maternal circulation, leading to an anaphylactoid reaction.
  • Immediate supportive care with oxygenation, hemodynamic stabilization, and correction of coagulopathy is critical.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) are correct? 

 

  1. Papillary carcinoma commonly shows Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and intranuclear pseudoinclusions.
  2. It frequently spreads via the bloodstream to lungs and bones
  3. The presence of psammoma bodies is a rare microscopic feature of this tumor.
  4. RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF V600E mutations are commonly associated with papillary carcinoma.
  5. Cervical lymph node metastasis is common but generally does not worsen long-term prognosis significantly.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 1, 4 and 5 are correct

 

  • Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy (≈80% of cases) and has an excellent prognosis. 
  • It typically affects younger women and is associated with exposure to ionizing radiation and certain genetic mutations.

 

Statement 1. Papillary carcinoma commonly shows Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and intranuclear pseudoinclusions: 

Characteristic nuclei — PTC is identified microscopically by:

  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei (cleared nuclei due to dispersed chromatin)
  • Nuclear grooves
  • Intranuclear pseudoinclusions
    These are hallmark diagnostic features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Statement 4. RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF V600E mutations are commonly associated with papillary carcinoma: 

Molecular associations — The most common genetic alterations include:

  • RET/PTC rearrangements (especially in radiation-induced cases)
  • BRAF V600E mutation (associated with aggressive variants)

 

Statement 5. Cervical lymph node metastasis is common but generally does not worsen long-term prognosis significantly: 

  • Lymphatic spread — PTC typically spreads via lymphatics to cervical lymph nodes.
  • However, despite frequent nodal involvement, long-term survival remains excellent, as nodal metastases do not significantly worsen prognosis.

 

Incorrect Statements: 

 

Statement 2. It frequently spreads via the bloodstream to lungs and bones: Blood-borne spread: PTC spreads via lymphatics, not bloodstream. Hematogenous spread (to lungs or bones) is characteristic of Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma, not papillary.

 

Statement 3. The presence of psammoma bodies is a rare microscopic feature of this tumor: Psammoma bodies are common, not rare, in PTC. They represent concentric calcifications seen in about 50% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma is characterized by Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, psammoma bodies, and RET/PTC or BRAF mutations. 
  • It spreads lymphatically, not hematogenously, and despite frequent cervical lymph node metastasis, prognosis remains excellent.

choices.text: It is associated with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern
It shows temporal heterogeneity on histology
It responds dramatically to corticosteroid therapy
Fibroblast foci are a characteristic feature

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 1 year. Chest X-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities, and lung biopsy shows honeycomb fibrosis with fibroblast foci. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It responds dramatically to corticosteroid therapy

 

  • The patient’s presentation—chronic progressive dyspnea, dry cough, honeycomb fibrosis, and fibroblast foci—is characteristic of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF), which shows a Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) pattern on histology.
  • IPF does NOT respond dramatically — or even reliably — to corticosteroids, because the disease is driven by irreversible fibrosis rather than inflammation. Instead, antifibrotic agents such as pirfenidone and nintedanib are the mainstay of treatment, functioning to slow the progression of fibrosis. 

 

Key Features of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (UIP pattern):

 

  • Gross findings: Shrunken, firm lungs with subpleural and basal predominance.
  • Microscopy:
    • Patchy interstitial fibrosis (areas of normal lung alternating with fibrotic areas).
    • Temporal heterogeneity: coexistence of early fibroblast foci and late-stage honeycombing.
    • Fibroblast foci — hallmark of ongoing injury and repair.
  • Clinical course: Progressive respiratory failure with poor response to corticosteroids or immunosuppressants.
  • Prognosis: Poor; median survival 3–5 years.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is associated with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern: True.Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis shows the UIP pattern, which is the defining histopathologic feature characterized by patchy interstitial fibrosis, fibroblast foci, and honeycombing.

 

Option B. It shows temporal heterogeneity on histology: True. UIP is marked by temporal heterogeneity, meaning areas of fibrosis at different stages of evolution — some early (fibroblast foci) and some late (dense collagen fibrosis and honeycombing).

 

Option D. Fibroblast foci are a characteristic feature: True. Fibroblast foci represent actively proliferating fibroblasts and are a classic finding in UIP/IPF, indicating ongoing epithelial injury and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is characterized by a Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) pattern with temporal heterogeneity, fibroblast foci, and honeycomb fibrosis.
  • Unlike inflammatory interstitial lung diseases, IPF does not respond well to corticosteroid therapy and has a progressive, irreversible course.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male concert violinist presents with a 6-month history of insidious onset numbness and tingling in his left hand. He reports his symptoms worsen after long practice sessions, especially when his elbow is held in a flexed position. On physical examination, atrophy of the hypothenar eminence and a prominent hollowing of the first dorsal interosseous space is noticed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulnar Nerve Neuropathy

 

  • The ulnar nerve supplies sensation to the little finger and the ulnar half of the ring finger. 
  • While the exact sensory distribution isn't specified, the location of the motor atrophy strongly supports an ulnar nerve issue.
  • The ulnar nerve is the primary motor supply to the intrinsic muscles of the hand, including the:
    • Hypothenar muscles
    • Interossei muscles 
    • Adductor Pollicis 
  • The physical exam findings align perfectly:
    • Indicates weakness/wasting of the hypothenar muscles (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
    • The first dorsal interosseous muscle is a strong ulnar nerve-supplied muscle. Its atrophy causes hollowing between the thumb and index finger metacarpals. 
    • This sign is a strong indicator of chronic ulnar nerve palsy.
  • The patient is a violinist and reports symptoms worsening when the elbow is held in a flexed position for long practice sessions.
  • The ulnar nerve passes through the cubital tunnel at the medial aspect of the elbow. 
  • Prolonged elbow flexion significantly increases tension and pressure on the ulnar nerve in this area, making it the most common site of compression neuropathy after the wrist (carpal tunnel).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome:

 

  • Causes numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, and middle fingers. 
  • Motor atrophy, when present, affects the thenar eminence (median nerve supplied muscles), not the hypothenar eminence or interossei.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve Palsy:

 

  • Causes wrist drop and finger drop (loss of wrist and finger extension). Sensory loss is typically over the dorsum of the hand. 
  • It does not cause hypothenar or interosseous atrophy.

 

Option C. Median Nerve Palsy:

 

  • The symptoms are primarily the same as Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, involving the thumb/index/middle fingers and thenar atrophy. 
  • The atrophy seen in this case (hypothenar and interosseous) is not consistent with median nerve involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To differentiate between common compressive neuropathies of the upper extremity by correlating specific symptoms (insidious onset, worsening with elbow flexion) and key motor atrophy patterns (hypothenar eminence and first dorsal interosseous muscle) with the correct anatomical nerve distribution (Ulnar Nerve Neuropathy).
  • This skill is essential for diagnosing the correct site of nerve entrapment (most commonly the cubital tunnel at the elbow) and initiating appropriate treatment.

choices.text: Excessive progesterone secretion from persistent corpus luteum

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding following 3–4 months of amenorrhea. On examination, the uterus is symmetrically enlarged, soft, and boggy, consistent with an endometrial disorder. Endometrial biopsy reveals cystic glandular hyperplasia with a “Swiss cheese” appearance. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unopposed estrogen stimulation with anovulation

 

  • This patient has endometrial hyperplasia, which typically presents as prolonged amenorrhea followed by heavy uterine bleeding (termed “breakthrough bleeding”).
  • The Swiss cheese pattern on biopsy is classic for cystic glandular hyperplasia, an early manifestation of unopposed estrogen effect on the endometrium.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • In women around perimenopause, anovulatory cycles become common due to irregular gonadotropin secretion.
  • Without ovulation, no corpus luteum forms, leading to absence of progesterone production.
  • As a result, the endometrium is exposed to continuous estrogen stimulation, causing proliferation of glands without secretory maturation.
  • Eventually, the unstable endometrium outgrows its blood supply, resulting in irregular heavy bleeding.

 

Histopathology:

 

  • Cystically dilated glands with irregular outlines (“Swiss cheese” pattern).
  • Proliferative stroma without cytologic atypia.
  • No secretory changes, confirming anovulatory cycles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased prostaglandin F₂α production: 

 

  • Incorrect. PGF₂α causes uterine contractions and dysmenorrhea, not endometrial hyperplasia.
  • It does not explain the amenorrhea followed by heavy bleeding pattern or the histologic findings.

 

Option B. Inadequate luteal phase progesterone production: 

 

  • Incorrect. Seen in luteal phase defects, where insufficient progesterone leads to shortened cycles, not prolonged amenorrhea.
  • Endometrial histology would show poorly developed secretory changes, not cystic glandular hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Excessive progesterone secretion from persistent corpus luteum: 

 

  • Incorrect. Progesterone dominance causes secretory endometrium and scant bleeding, not hyperplasia.
  • The biopsy would show secretory glands, not the proliferative “Swiss cheese” pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia with cystic glandular proliferation results from unopposed estrogen stimulation due to anovulatory cycles, commonly seen in perimenopausal women.
  • The absence of progesterone leads to continuous endometrial proliferation, creating the characteristic “Swiss cheese” histologic pattern and causing irregular heavy bleeding.

choices.text: Weekly progesterone injections starting at 16 weeks
Serial cervical length measurements starting at 16 weeks

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman (G4P0) with a history of three painless second-trimester pregnancy losses at 16, 18, and 20 weeks presents for preconception counseling. Each loss was preceded by spontaneous rupture of membranes without contractions. In her last pregnancy, a transvaginal ultrasound at 14 weeks showed a cervical length of 22 mm with funneling. What is the most appropriate management in her next pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prophylactic cerclage at 12–14 weeks

 

  • This woman’s history and imaging findings are consistent with cervical insufficiency (incompetent cervix) — a condition characterized by painless cervical dilation leading to recurrent, mid-trimester pregnancy losses or preterm births.
  • Key Diagnostic Clues:
    • Recurrent painless second-trimester losses (16–20 weeks)
    • Spontaneous rupture of membranes without labor
    • Short cervix with funneling on ultrasound (≤25 mm before 24 weeks)

 

Management:

 

  • The best preventive measure in such cases is prophylactic (history-indicated) cervical cerclage, typically performed at 12–14 weeks gestation, after confirming a viable intrauterine pregnancy and absence of infection or bleeding.

 

Procedure:

 

  • The most common approach is the McDonald cerclage (purse-string suture at the cervico-vaginal junction).
  • The suture is usually removed at 36–37 weeks or earlier if labor begins.

 

Adjunctive care:

 

  • Progesterone supplementation may also be considered, but cerclage remains the mainstay for classical cervical insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weekly progesterone injections starting at 16 weeks: Incorrect. Progesterone is used for prevention of preterm labor due to spontaneous preterm birth, not for classic cervical incompetence with recurrent mid-trimester losses.

 

Option C. Bed rest from 14 weeks onwards: Incorrect. Bed rest alone does not prevent pregnancy loss and is not recommended as a substitute for cerclage.

 

Option D. Serial cervical length measurements starting at 16 weeks: Incorrect. Useful for surveillance in women without a strong history, but not adequate in those with recurrent losses and proven cervical shortening — they require prophylactic cerclage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with a history of recurrent, painless second-trimester pregnancy losses and short cervix on ultrasound, the most effective preventive measure is prophylactic cervical cerclage, ideally performed at 12–14 weeks of gestation in the next pregnancy.

choices.text: One district judge and one social worker
One first-class judicial magistrate and two social workers, one of whom must be a woman
Two first-class judicial magistrates and one social worker
Three social workers, including at least two with legal experience

questions.text: A Juvenile Justice Board is reviewing a case involving a 15-year-old offender. What is the required composition of the board to ensure the case is reviewed appropriately according to the Juvenile Justice Act?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) One first-class judicial magistrate and two social workers, one of whom must be a woman

 

  • The Juvenile Justice Board is designed to include one first-class judicial magistrate and two social workers, where at least one of the social workers must be a woman. 
  • This composition ensures a balanced approach, combining legal oversight with insights from experienced individuals in health, education, law, psychology, or psychiatry, which are critical for addressing the needs of juvenile offenders.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with vomiting, lethargy, and sweating after drinking fruit juice. His parents report similar symptoms after he consumes sweets. Laboratory tests show hypoglycemia and hepatic dysfunction. A metabolic disorder involving the inability to cleave fructose metabolites is suspected. The defective enzyme, which functions as a lyase, normally acts on which of the following substrates?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fructose-1-phosphate

 

  • Aldolase, particularly aldolase B, acts as a lyase enzyme for fructose-1-phosphate during fructose metabolism. It catalyzes the cleavage of fructose 1 phosphate into two products:
    • Dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP)
    • Glyceraldehyde
  • This reaction is essential in the liver for the proper metabolism of dietary fructose. 
  • The enzyme performs its function without the addition of water or the involvement of oxidation-reduction reactions, which is characteristic of lyase activity. 
  • Deficiency of aldolase B leads to hereditary fructose intolerance, a metabolic condition characterized by the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate, causing hypoglycemia, vomiting, and liver dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate: This compound is an intermediate in glycolysis and the Calvin cycle, but aldolase does not act on it. Instead, enzymes like glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase process this substrate.

 

Option C. Glucose: Aldolase does not cleave glucose. Glucose is phosphorylated by hexokinase or glucokinase in glycolysis and follows a separate pathway.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphate: This substrate is involved in glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway but is not acted upon by aldolase. Glucose-6-phosphate is processed by enzymes like glucose-6-phosphatase or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aldolase B acts as a lyase for fructose-1-phosphate, cleaving it into DHAP and glyceraldehyde during fructose metabolism. 
  • This reaction is critical for energy production from dietary fructose, and defects in aldolase B result in hereditary fructose intolerance.

choices.text: A person with borderline personality disorder who exhibits emotional dysregulation but can still reason through a decision is not compos mentis.
A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.
A person diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder can never be considered compos mentis because they have multiple, distinct identities.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of compos mentis in the context of mental health?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.

 

A person with OCD might engage in compulsive behaviours, but if they understand the broader implications of their actions (such as knowing the behaviour is irrational), they can still be considered compos mentis, meaning they are mentally competent to make decisions, even if their actions are influenced by compulsions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person with borderline personality disorder who exhibits emotional dysregulation but can still reason through a decision is not compos mentis: Emotional dysregulation alone (as in borderline personality disorder) does not necessarily impair a person’s decision-making capacity. Many such individuals can still think rationally and are legally considered compos mentis.

 

Option C. A person diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder can never be considered compos mentis because they have multiple, distinct identities: Dissociative identity disorder (DID) involves the presence of distinct identities, but it does not mean a person with DID cannot be compos mentis. In many cases, individuals with DID may still demonstrate decision-making capacity, depending on which identity is dominant at the time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Compos mentis is not about the presence or absence of a mental illness but rather about cognitive clarity and decision-making capacity. 
  • Many individuals with psychiatric conditions like OCD or even borderline personality disorder can still be considered mentally competent in legal and clinical settings.

questions.text: Respiratory distress is noticed in a newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

  • The clinical picture of a cyanotic newborn with respiratory distress and auscultation revealing bowel sounds in the left hemithorax, combined with chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels, is suggestive of a congenital anomaly that allows abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 
  • CDH is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development and causing respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth. 
  • The presence of bowel sounds in the thorax and air-fluid levels on X-ray are indicative of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a congenital heart defect that includes four abnormalities: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It leads to cyanotic congenital heart disease but does not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great vessels: This is another congenital heart defect where the major vessels (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) are switched. It results in cyanosis but would not cause bowel sounds in the chest or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory distress due to aspiration, but it would not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or the radiographic appearance of air-fluid levels as seen with CDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

choices.text: Rigidity, hyperthermia, and increased CPK levels
Rigidity, restlessness, and increased CPK levels
Tremors, restlessness, and increased CPK levels

questions.text: The following symptoms are classically seen in patients with Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS):
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rigidity, hyperthermia, and increased CPK levels

 

  • Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is a rare but potentially fatal reaction to antipsychotic medications, particularly dopamine-blocking agents. 
  • It is characterized by the classic tetrad of:
    1. Severe muscle rigidity (lead-pipe type)
    2. Hyperthermia (high fever)
    3. Autonomic instability (fluctuating BP, tachycardia, diaphoresis)
    4. Altered mental status
  • Laboratory findings include elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) due to muscle breakdown and myoglobinuria, which may lead to renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rigidity, restlessness, and increased CPK levels: Incorrect. Restlessness suggests akathisia, not NMS.

 

Option C. Fever, restlessness, and myoglobinuria: Incorrect. Myoglobinuria may occur, but restlessness is not a defining feature.

 

Option D. Tremors, restlessness, and increased CPK levels: Incorrect. Tremors may occur in drug-induced parkinsonism, but NMS shows rigidity, not tremor or restlessness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome presents with rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability, altered mental status, and elevated CPK levels following dopamine blockade—requiring prompt recognition and management with drug withdrawal, supportive care, and dantrolene or bromocriptine.

choices.text: It commonly occurs in adults and is associated with Auer rods
It arises from myeloid progenitor cells
It has a better prognosis in children and is associated with B-cell lineage
It shows TRAP-positive cells with cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, fatigue, and bone pain. Examination shows pallor and generalized lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear shows atypical cells. Bone marrow biopsy reveals PAS-positive, TdT-positive blasts. Cytogenetic analysis demonstrates t(12;21) translocation. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has a good prognosis in children and is associated with B-cell lineage

 

  • The described case is Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) — specifically B-cell ALL.

 

Key Diagnostic Features:

 

  • Age group: Commonly affects children (2–10 years).
  • Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, bone pain, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and pallor.
  • Peripheral smear and bone marrow:
    • PAS-positive (Periodic Acid–Schiff stain) — indicates lymphoid lineage.
    • TdT-positive (Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase) — marker of immature lymphoid cells (pre-B or pre-T cells).
  • Cytogenetic finding:
    • t(12;21) translocation is characteristic of B-cell ALL and is associated with a favorable prognosis in children.

 

Prognostic factors:

 

  • Good prognosis:
    • Age 1–10 years
    • Low WBC count (<50,000/μL)
    • B-cell phenotype
    • t(12;21) translocation
  • Poor prognosis:
    • <1 year or >10 years
    • T-cell phenotype
    • High leukocyte count
    • t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It commonly occurs in adults and is associated with Auer rods: Incorrect. This describes Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), not ALL. Auer rods are seen in myeloblasts, not lymphoblasts.AML is more common in adults, whereas ALL is more common in children.

 

Option B. It arises from myeloid progenitor cells: Incorrect. ALL arises from lymphoid progenitor cells, not myeloid. Myeloid progenitors give rise to AML, which is TdT-negative and MPO-positive.

 

Option D. It shows TRAP-positive cells with cytoplasmic projections: Incorrect. This finding is characteristic of Hairy Cell Leukemia, not ALL.TRAP stands for Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase, which stains positive in hairy cells (a mature B-cell neoplasm).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is a TdT-positive, PAS-positive malignancy of lymphoid progenitor cells, most often seen in children.
  • The t(12;21) translocation is associated with B-cell ALL and confers a favorable prognosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and light-headedness. The ECG report is shown below. Which of the following drug is least likely to be associated with the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lidocaine

 

  • Lidocaine, a class IB antiarrhythmic agent (K+ channel opener and sodium channel blocker), is primarily used for the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias, particularly in the setting of ischemia.  
  • It works by blocking sodium channels in their inactivated state and shortening the action potential duration. 
  • Unlike class IA agents, it does not prolong the QT interval or predispose to torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quinidine: Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic that blocks sodium and potassium channels. It prolongs the QT interval, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes.

 

Option B. Ibutilide: This class III agent also prolongs the QT interval and is associated with the risk of torsades de pointes.

 

Option C. Procainamide: Another class IA antiarrhythmic, procainamide can prolong the QT interval, increasing the likelihood of torsades de pointes.

 

Educational Objective:


Class IB agents, such as lidocaine, do not prolong the QT interval and are less likely to cause arrhythmias like torsades de pointes compared to class IA agents.

choices.text: Autoantibodies are directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb
Splenic macrophages play a key role in platelet destruction
Platelet transfusion is the mainstay of long-term treatment
Corticosteroids and IV immunoglobulin are effective initial therapies

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of easy bruising, petechiae over both lower limbs, and gum bleeding for the past 3 months. She had a mild viral upper respiratory infection 2 weeks before the first episode. There is no history of joint pain, splenomegaly, or use of any new drugs. On examination, she is afebrile and has no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory findings: Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL, WBC count: 6,800 /mm³ Platelet count: 18,000 /mm³ (↓) Bleeding time: prolonged with normal PT and normal aPTT. Bone marrow aspiration: increased megakaryocytes. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platelet transfusion is the mainstay of long-term treatment

 

  • All features (isolated thrombocytopenia, increased marrow megakaryocytes, normal coagulation profile, no splenomegaly) are consistent with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).
  • Platelet transfusion is the mainstay of long-term treatment Transfused platelets are rapidly destroyed by circulating antibodies — so platelet transfusion is not useful except in life-threatening bleeding.
  • Mainstay therapy:
    • Corticosteroids (prednisolone)
    • IVIg (blocks Fc receptors on macrophages)
    • Rituximab or splenectomy for chronic/refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoantibodies are directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins GpIIb/IIIa or GpIb:  ITP is an autoimmune disorder where IgG antibodies are formed against platelet surface glycoproteins (GpIIb/IIIa, GpIb). These antibody-coated platelets are destroyed in the spleen by macrophages. Autoantibodies may also impair megakaryocyte platelet production.

 

Option B. Splenic macrophages play a key role in platelet destruction:  The spleen is central to ITP pathogenesis. Site of antibody production (B cells). Site of platelet destruction (macrophages). Hence splenectomy is beneficial in chronic cases.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids and IV immunoglobulin are effective initial therapies: Corticosteroids ↓ autoantibody production and macrophage activity. IVIg competes for Fc receptors on splenic macrophages, temporarily increasing platelet count. Response typically within days.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing loss. This mother complains that the child's dentition is not appropriate according to his age. Examination revealed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis and its associated triad?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Late congenital syphilis - Hutchinson's triad

 

  • The presentation in this case represents the classic Hutchinson's triad seen in late congenital syphilis, which includes:
    1. Interstitial keratitis - inflammation of the corneal stroma without involvement of the epithelium or endothelium
    2. Hutchinson's teeth - notched upper central incisors (screwdriver-shaped incisors)
    3. Sensorineural hearing loss (VIII nerve deafness)
  • Additional include frontal bossing and saddle nose deformity, which are characteristic skeletal manifestations of late congenital syphilis. 
  • Late congenital syphilis typically manifests after 2 years of age and represents the chronic sequelae of untreated maternal syphilis transmitted to the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acquired syphilis - Argyll Robertson pupil: This is a feature of acquired neurosyphilis in adults, not congenital syphilis. The Argyll Robertson pupil is characterized by small pupils that accommodate but do not react to light (light-near dissociation). This finding would not be expected in a 10-year-old with congenital infection.

 

Option B. Early congenital syphilis - Snuffles: Early congenital syphilis presents in infancy (typically under 2 years of age) with manifestations like "snuffles" (syphilitic rhinitis with mucopurulent discharge), maculopapular rash, and hepatosplenomegaly. This is inconsistent with the age and presentation of this patient.

 

Option D. Congenital rubella - Gregg's triad: Gregg's triad consists of cataracts, congenital heart defects (particularly patent ductus arteriosus and pulmonary stenosis), and sensorineural deafness. The absence of ocular and cardiac findings, along with the presence of notched teeth and skeletal deformities, makes congenital rubella unlikely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Hutchinson's triad (interstitial keratitis, notched incisors, and sensorineural hearing loss) is pathognomonic for late congenital syphilis, which typically manifests after 2 years of age. 
  • Recognition of this classic triad is crucial for proper diagnosis and management of this preventable infectious disease.

choices.text: Stimulation of central medullary chemoreceptors by hypoxemia
Activation of peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies by decreased PaO₂
Increased activity of J receptors in response to elevated PaCO₂
Direct excitation of the phrenic nerve by elevated H⁺ concentration

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with progressive shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals PaO₂ = 55 mm Hg, PaCO₂ = 60 mm Hg, and pH = 7.32. Which of the following best describes the mechanism responsible for the increased respiratory drive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activation of peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies by decreased PaO₂

 

  • Hypoxemia stimulates ventilation via the peripheral chemoreceptors located in the carotid bodies (mainly) and aortic bodies. 
  • These receptors respond directly to decreases in arterial oxygen tension (PaO₂), typically when it falls below 60 mm Hg.
  • When activated, they send excitatory signals to the respiratory centers in the medulla, increasing the rate and depth of breathing.
  • In contrast, the central (medullary) chemoreceptors are primarily sensitive to changes in arterial CO₂ (and the corresponding H⁺ concentration in cerebrospinal fluid).
  • In chronic hypercapnia (as in COPD), these central chemoreceptors become desensitized, making hypoxemia the dominant respiratory drive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of central medullary chemoreceptors by hypoxemia: Central chemoreceptors respond to CO₂ or H⁺, not low O₂. They are located near the ventral surface of the medulla and detect changes in CSF pH.

 

Option C. Increased activity of J receptors in response to elevated PaCO₂: J (juxtacapillary) receptors respond to pulmonary interstitial edema or increased capillary pressure, not to CO₂ levels. They contribute to rapid, shallow breathing seen in pulmonary congestion.

 

Option D. Direct excitation of the phrenic nerve by elevated H⁺ concentration: The phrenic nerve is an efferent motor nerve supplying the diaphragm; it does not act as a chemoreceptor or sensory detector of H⁺. Its activity is controlled by the medullary respiratory centers, not by direct chemical stimuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) detect hypoxemia (↓PaO₂) → stimulate ventilation.
  • Central chemoreceptors (medulla) detect ↑PaCO₂ or ↑H⁺ → stimulate ventilation.
  • J receptors respond to pulmonary congestion, not gases.
  • Stretch receptors inhibit overinflation (Hering–Breuer reflex).
  • The phrenic nerve executes diaphragmatic movement under brainstem control.

questions.text: Identify the surgical device shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transobturator tape (TOT)

 

The image shows a U-shaped polypropylene mesh tape with curved introducers, which is characteristic of a Transobturator Tape (TOT) used for the surgical management of stress urinary incontinence (SUI) in women.

 

Mechanism & Purpose:

 

  • TOT is a mid-urethral sling procedure designed to provide support to the urethra and prevent leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing).
  • The tape passes through the obturator foramen (either from outside-in or inside-out) and lies beneath the mid-urethra.
  • It creates a "hammock-like" support, restoring the normal urethral closure mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McDonald suture: Used for cervical cerclage in cases of cervical incompetence, not for urinary incontinence.

 

Option C. Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT): Similar material, but passed retropubically, not through the obturator foramen.

 

Option D. Shirodkar sling: Another cerclage technique used to reinforce the cervix, unrelated to urinary incontinence surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transobturator Tape (TOT) is a mid-urethral sling procedure for treating stress urinary incontinence (SUI) in women, offering effective urethral support with fewer complications than retropubic TVT.

questions.text: A patient is receiving a continuous intravenous infusion of a medication at a rate of 250 mg/hour. The drug’s clearance (CL) is known to be 5 L/hour. What is the expected steady-state plasma concentration (Css) for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mg/L

 

  • To calculate the steady-state plasma concentration (Css) during continuous IV infusion, use the formula:
  • Maintenance Dosing rate (infusion rate) = Clearance x Target plasma concentration (Steady state plasma concentration; Css)
  • So, Css = Infusion rate/Clearance

 

Here:

  • Infusion rate = 200 mg/hour
  • Clearance = 5 L/hour

So, 

  • Css = 250/5 = 50 mg/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

During constant IV infusion, the steady-state plasma concentration is directly proportional to the infusion rate and inversely proportional to the drug’s clearance:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be treated using Gamma knife stereotactic radiosurgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glioblastoma multiforme

 

  • Glioblastoma multiforme is a diffuse, infiltrative tumor requiring broader radiotherapy techniques and systemic treatment. 
  • Gamma knife is designed for highly localized lesions, such as AVMs, pituitary adenomas, and trigeminal neuralgia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arteriovenous malformation: AVMs are one of the primary indications for Gamma knife radiosurgery.

 

Option C. Pituitary adenoma: These localized tumors are effectively treated with Gamma knife.

 

Option D. Trigeminal neuralgia: Gamma knife is widely used for this condition to target the nerve root without damaging adjacent structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma knife radiosurgery is most effective for localized lesions and conditions such as AVMs, pituitary adenomas, and trigeminal neuralgia, but is not suitable for diffuse tumors like glioblastoma.

questions.text: Pin index of 7 is of which gas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entonox

 

  • Entonox, also known as gas and air, is a premixed gas consisting of 50% Oxygen and 50% Nitrous Oxide. It's often used for analgesia, such as in labor. 
  • The pin index of Entonox is 7.
  • Entonox is a mixture of Nitrous Oxide and Oxygen in the ratio of 50: 50.
  • The pin index system is a safety system used on medical gas cylinders and their corresponding yokes, which are the connectors that attach to anesthesia machines or other medical gas delivery systems. 
  • Each gas has a unique pin index number to prevent accidental misconnection of gas cylinders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pin index system ensures the safe and correct connection of medical gas cylinders to their corresponding equipment. 
  • Each medical gas has a unique pin index to prevent the accidental administration of the wrong gas. 
  • Entonox, a 50:50 mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen, has a pin index number of 7.

choices.text: No pneumonia, only cough and cold

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the primary health center with a cough and fast breathing for 2 days. On examination, the respiratory rate is 58 breaths/minute, there is no chest indrawing, and the infant is feeding well. Temperature is 38.5°C. The child appears alert and there are no other signs of distress. According to IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) guidelines, how would you classify this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumonia

 

  • The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) provides standardized guidelines for classifying and managing common childhood illnesses. 
  • For respiratory infections, classification is based primarily on age-specific respiratory rate thresholds, presence of chest indrawing, and danger signs.
  • In this case:
    • The child is 9 months old, so falls in the 3-12 month age category where fast breathing is defined as RR > 50/min
    • This child has RR 58/min (above the cutoff)
    • There is no chest indrawing reported
    • There are no danger signs mentioned (the child is feeding well and has no reported lethargy, unconsciousness, convulsions, inability to drink, or persistent vomiting)
  • Based on these findings, this child meets the criteria for "Pneumonia" according to the IMNCI classification. 
  • This represents a significant but not severe respiratory infection requiring appropriate antibiotic therapy (typically oral amoxicillin for 5 days) along with supportive care and home management.

 

IMNCI Classification of Respiratory Illness:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Severe pneumonia: This classification requires danger signs, which is not present in this child.

 

Option C. No pneumonia, only cough and cold: The child has a respiratory rate of 58/min, which exceeds the threshold of 50/min for the 3-12 month age group, making this classification incorrect.

 

Option D. Very severe pneumonia: This term is not used currently.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age-specific respiratory rate cut offs are crucial in IMNCI classification:

 

  • 0-2 months: >60/min
  • 2-12 months: >50/min
  • 1-5 years: >40/min

choices.text: The p53 gene normally arrests the cell cycle at the G1/S checkpoint to allow DNA repair.
Loss of heterozygosity at 17p leads to loss of normal p53 function.
Overexpression of mutated p53 protein leads to increased degradation of abnormal cells.
HPV infection can lead to p53 degradation via E6 protein-mediated ubiquitination.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker presents with a non-healing ulcer on the lateral border of the tongue for 6 months. The lesion is indurated with rolled margins. A biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma, and immunohistochemistry shows overexpression of p53 protein. Further workup reveals multiple metastases to cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following statements regarding the molecular mechanisms of this neoplasm is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Overexpression of mutated p53 protein leads to increased degradation of abnormal cells.

 

  • Mutated p53 overexpression increases degradation - Mutated (nonfunctional) p53 protein often accumulates in cells because it is not degraded properly, and hence IHC shows overexpression. 
  • However, this does not lead to degradation of abnormal cells - instead, it fails to arrest the cell cycle or induce apoptosis, promoting tumorigenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The p53 gene normally arrests the cell cycle at the G1/S checkpoint to allow DNA repair: p53 acts as a tumor suppressor. When DNA damage occurs, it halts the cycle at G1/S via p21 activation, allowing DNA repair. If repair fails, it induces apoptosis through BAX upregulation.

 

Option B. Loss of heterozygosity at 17p leads to loss of normal p53 function: The p53 gene is located on chromosome 17p13.1. Loss of heterozygosity (second hit) results in loss of the functional tumor suppressor, allowing uncontrolled proliferation.

 

Option D. HPV infection can lead to p53 degradation via E6 protein-mediated ubiquitination: In HPV-related squamous cell carcinomas, viral E6 protein binds to p53 and promotes its ubiquitin-mediated degradation, effectively mimicking p53 loss. This is a classic viral oncogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • E6 protein → binds p53 → ubiquitin-mediated degradation.
  • E7 protein → binds Rb → releases E2F → uncontrolled S-phase entry.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is not known to cause arthritis as a clinical manifestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) primarily inhabits the large intestine (cecum and colon), where it causes localized mucosal inflammation, tenesmus, and rectal prolapse in heavy infections.
  • It does not invade extraintestinal tissues and hence has no association with joint involvement or arthritis.
  • The infection is confined to the gastrointestinal tract and is not linked to systemic immunologic or migratory manifestations that could affect joints.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: 

 

  • The filarial worms can occasionally induce immune complex–mediated arthritis or synovitis, especially after treatment or due to antigen release from dying microfilariae.
  • Such immune responses can trigger periarticular inflammation and pain.

 

Option C. Dracunculus medinensis:

 

  • The adult worm often migrates through subcutaneous tissues and may localize near joints, causing painful arthritis-like swelling, particularly in the knee or ankle region.
  • This is due to inflammatory reaction and secondary bacterial infection around the emerging worm.

 

Option D. Echinococcus granulosus: 

 

  • The hydatid cysts of Echinococcus may involve bone and joint structures, leading to secondary arthritis due to pressure effects and erosion of adjacent bone.
  • Although rare, joint involvement can occur, particularly in hip and knee regions when bone cysts expand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Among parasitic infections, arthritis can occur due to immune complex deposition, local tissue migration, or compression from cystic lesions.
  • However, Trichuris trichiura infection remains confined to the intestinal lumen and does not cause arthritis or any extraintestinal manifestations.

choices.text: Sensitivity represents the ability of a test to correctly identify diseased individuals
Specificity represents the ability of a test to correctly identify non-diseased individuals
Positive predictive value increases as disease prevalence increases in the population
Likelihood ratio positive is calculated as sensitivity divided by (specificity-1)

questions.text: During an outbreak investigation, a rapid diagnostic test is being evaluated for disease screening. All of the following statements about test performance characteristics are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Likelihood ratio positive is calculated as sensitivity divided by (specificity-1)

 

The likelihood ratio positive (LR+) is calculated as sensitivity divided by (1-specificity), and not (specificity-1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity represents the ability of a test to correctly identify diseased individuals: This correctly defines sensitivity (true positive rate).

 

Option B. Specificity represents the ability of a test to correctly identify non-diseased individuals: This correctly defines specificity (true negative rate).

 

Option C. Positive predictive value increases as disease prevalence increases in the population: This correctly states that PPV increases with increasing disease prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic test characteristics that remain constant regardless of disease prevalence
  • Predictive values (PPV and NPV) vary with disease prevalence in the population
  • Likelihood ratios help interpret test results and incorporate both sensitivity and specificity

choices.text: RNA primer removal during lagging-strand synthesis
Ability to extend DNA from a 3'-OH end

questions.text: A researcher is studying DNA repair mechanisms in E. coli. During an experiment, she treats DNA polymerase I with a specific protease that removes its N-terminal portion, producing a fragment commonly used in molecular biology for synthesizing complementary DNA strands in vitro. This modified enzyme, known as the Klenow fragment lacks which of the following activities?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RNA primer removal during lagging-strand synthesis

 

  • The Klenow fragment is generated by proteolytic cleavage of E. coli DNA polymerase I.
  • It retains:
    • 5' → 3' DNA polymerase activity (extends DNA)
    • 3' → 5' exonuclease activity (proofreading)
  • It lacks:
    • 5' → 3' exonuclease activity, which is normally responsible for RNA primer removal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 3' → 5' proofreading activity: Incorrect. Klenow fragment retains proofreading, which allows it to correct mismatched bases.

 

Option C. Ability to extend DNA from a 3'-OH end: Incorrect. It keeps the 5' → 3' polymerase activity, so it can extend the DNA strand.

 

Option D. Template-dependent DNA synthesis: Incorrect. Klenow fragment still synthesizes DNA using a template. This function remains intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of E. Coli DNA polymerase I retains polymerase (5′ → 3′) and proofreading (3′ → 5′ exonuclease) activities but lacks the 5′ → 3′ exonuclease activity responsible for RNA primer removal.

questions.text: You want to give a brachial plexus block for open reduction internal fixation of fracture of distal end radius. In order to improve the speed of onset and depth of blockade, which of these additives should be added to the local anesthetic solution?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium Bicarbonate

 

  • Sodium bicarbonate is added to local anesthetic solutions to increase the pH of the solution, making it more alkaline.
  • Alkalization of the solution enhances the fraction of lipid-soluble local anesthetic that is available, aiding in the diffusion of the drug across the lipid membranes of the nerves.
  • This results in a faster onset of anesthesia and a deeper level of blockade.
  • It also reduces the required dosage of local anesthetic, lowering the risk of systemic toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline:

 

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) is often added to local anesthetic solutions to prolong the duration of the block by vasoconstriction, which reduces the systemic absorption of the local anesthetic.
  • While adrenaline is valuable for prolonging the block, it does not enhance the speed of onset or depth of blockade.

 

Option B. Fentanyl:

 

  • Fentanyl is an opioid analgesic and is not typically added to local anesthetic solutions for regional blocks.
  • It can provide pain relief but does not affect the onset or depth of the block.

 

Option C. Sodium Carbonate: Sodium carbonate is not commonly used as an additive to local anesthetic solutions for regional blocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The addition of sodium bicarbonate to a local anesthetic solution for a brachial plexus block is a valuable technique to improve the speed of onset and depth of blockade. 
  • Alkalizing the solution enhances the availability of lipid-soluble local anesthetic, facilitating its diffusion across nerve membranes. 
  • This not only results in a more effective blockade but also reduces the required dose of local anesthetic, decreasing the risk of systemic toxicity.

choices.text: Direct maternal death, to be included in maternal mortality ratio calculation
Indirect maternal death, to be included in maternal mortality ratio calculation
Late maternal death, to be excluded from maternal mortality ratio calculation
Pregnancy-related death to be reported separately from maternal mortality ratio

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman dies after 6 weeks following a cesarean delivery due to pulmonary embolism that developed 35 days postpartum. According to WHO's definition of maternal death, how should this death be classified for maternal mortality statistics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Late maternal death, to be excluded from maternal mortality ratio calculation

 

  • Maternal death is death of mother anytime in pregnancy, labour or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes. Deaths occurring between 42 days and 1 year after termination of pregnancy are classified as "late maternal deaths" and are excluded from the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) calculation. 
  • The MMR only includes deaths within 42 days of termination of pregnancy.
  • Although this death was pregnancy-related (pulmonary embolism is a known complication of pregnancy and cesarean delivery), it occurred after 6 weeks (42 days) postpartum, making it a late maternal death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct maternal death, to be included in maternal mortality ratio calculation: Incorrect because deaths after 42 days postpartum are not included in direct maternal death statistics for MMR calculation.

 

Option B. Indirect maternal death, to be included in maternal mortality ratio calculation: Incorrect because deaths after 42 days postpartum are not included in indirect maternal death statistics for MMR calculation. This is a distractor option, if you miss the term “after 6 weeks”, you are likely to choose this option since the other duration “35 days” postpartum might seem that the death occurred within the period defined for maternal mortality.

 

Option D. Pregnancy-related death to be reported separately from maternal mortality ratio: Incorrect terminology; "pregnancy-related death" is not the official WHO classification for deaths occurring after 42 days postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maternal mortality ratio includes only deaths within 42 days of termination of pregnancy
  • Deaths between 42 days to 1 year are classified as late maternal deaths and reported separately

questions.text: Which class of enzymes catalyzes structural or geometric rearrangements within a molecule, without adding or removing atoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mutases

 

  • Mutases are a subclass of isomerases that catalyze intramolecular rearrangements.
  • They change the position of functional groups within the same molecule without altering its molecular formula.
  • Examples:
    • Phosphoglycerate mutase (glycolysis)
    • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (propionate metabolism)
  • Thus, they are the enzymes responsible for geometric/structural changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligases: Incorrect. Ligases join two molecules together using ATP (e.g., DNA ligase).They do not rearrange structures internally.

 

Option C. Hydrolases: Incorrect. Hydrolases break bonds by adding water (e.g., proteases, lipases).These reactions change the molecule rather than rearranging it.

 

Option D. Lyases: Incorrect. Lyases add or remove groups to form double bonds (e.g., aldolase).They do not simply rearrange the molecule internally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases (including mutases) catalyze structural or geometric rearrangements within a molecule without adding or removing atoms, allowing the molecule to be converted into one of its isomers.

choices.text: The underlying mutation involves the APC tumor suppressor gene.
Patients have nearly a 100% lifetime risk of colorectal carcinoma if untreated.
The “second hit” in the remaining allele occurs through loss of heterozygosity.
The same gene maybe involved in hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with intermittent rectal bleeding and a family history of colectomy at a young age. Colonoscopy and microscopic picture are shown below. Genetic testing reveals a germline mutation on chromosome 5q21. All of the following statements regarding this condition are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The same gene maybe involved in hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer 

 

  • The patient is a 22-year-old man with intermittent rectal bleeding and a family history of colectomy at a young age. 
  • The colonoscopy and microscopic picture show numerous polyps consistent with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). 
  • The stem states a germline mutation on chromosome 5q21, which is the location of the APC tumor suppressor gene.
  • FAP follows the two-hit hypothesis, meaning the inherited APC mutation requires a “second hit” via loss of heterozygosity. 
  • If untreated, patients have nearly a 100% lifetime risk of colorectal carcinoma, explaining the family history of colectomy. 
  • Is false because hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) does not involve the same gene. HNPCC is due to DNA mismatch repair gene mutations, not APC. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The underlying mutation involves the APC tumor suppressor gene: Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) is caused by germline mutations in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21. APC is a tumor suppressor that regulates β-catenin degradation and WNT signaling. Loss of APC → accumulation of β-catenin → increased transcription of growth-promoting genes (MYC, cyclin D1).

 

Option B. Patients have nearly a 100% lifetime risk of colorectal carcinoma if untreated: Virtually all patients with untreated FAP will develop colorectal carcinoma by age 40 due to the adenoma–carcinoma sequence (accumulation of APC → KRAS → p53 mutations). Thus, prophylactic colectomy is strongly recommended.

 

Option C. The “second hit” in the remaining allele occurs through loss of heterozygosity: According to Knudson’s two-hit hypothesis, patients inherit one mutant APC allele (germline) and lose the other allele (somatic loss of heterozygosity) during life, leading to complete functional loss and adenoma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Turcot syndrome: FAP + medulloblastoma (sometimes glioblastoma).
  • Attenuated FAP: <100 polyps, later onset of cancer.
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) → characteristic ocular finding.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding skeletal muscle excitation–contraction (EC) coupling are correct? 

 

  1. Skeletal muscle contraction does not require extracellular calcium influx.
  2. The primary source of calcium during contraction is the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  3. Dihydropyridine (L-type) Ca²⁺ channels in the T-tubules function mainly as voltage sensors rather than as calcium conduits.
  4. Mitochondrial calcium release plays a dominant role in triggering skeletal muscle contraction.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

Statement 1. Skeletal muscle contraction does not require extracellular calcium influx:

 

  • Skeletal muscle fibers rely on calcium stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Unlike cardiac myocytes, skeletal muscle contraction is not dependent on extracellular calcium entering through L-type calcium channels.

 

Statement 2. The primary source of calcium during contraction is the sarcoplasmic reticulum:

 

  • The sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) is the primary source of calcium during skeletal muscle contraction. 
  • The depolarization of the muscle membrane triggers SR calcium release via ryanodine receptors (RyR1).

 

Statement 3. Dihydropyridine (L-type) Ca²⁺ channels in the T-tubules function mainly as voltage sensors rather than as calcium conduits:

 

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine receptors (DHPRs) in the T-tubule membrane detect depolarization.
  • They are mechanically coupled to ryanodine receptors (RyR1) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, triggering calcium release without the need for calcium influx.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Mitochondrial calcium release plays a dominant role in triggering skeletal muscle contraction:

 

  • This is incorrect. Mitochondria can buffer calcium but do not release calcium to initiate contraction.
  • The dominant source of calcium in skeletal muscle contraction is the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In skeletal muscle, extracellular calcium influx is not required for contraction. 
  • Dihydropyridine receptors act as voltage sensors that mechanically open ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, releasing calcium to initiate contraction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of unilateral uveitis, headache, and episodic increased intraocular pressure (IOP) without signs of significant inflammation. Slit-lamp examination shows few aqueous cells, corneal epithelial edema, and open angles on gonioscopy. His symptoms resolve within a few days with topical steroids and intraocular pressure-lowering agents. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posner-Schlossman syndrome

 

  • Posner-Schlossman syndrome, also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis, is a rare form of hypertensive uveitis. 
  • It is characterized by recurrent episodes of mild anterior uveitis with transient intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation.

 

Key Clinical Features:

 

  • Unilateral attacks of mild anterior uveitis.
  • Transient but significant IOP spikes that can reach 40-60 mmHg.
  • Mild inflammation: Few aqueous cells are seen, but keratic precipitates may be present.
  • Corneal epithelial edema due to elevated IOP.
  • Open angles on gonioscopy, differentiating it from angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Symptoms include mild discomfort, blurred vision, and seeing halos around lights.
  • Attacks last for hours to days and can recur over time.
  • Between attacks, the eye appears normal.

 

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • The exact cause is unknown, but inflammatory cytokines and viral infections (e.g., CMV, HSV) are implicated.
  • There is episodic trabeculitis, leading to poor aqueous humor drainage and acute IOP spikes.

 

Management:

 

  • Topical steroids (to reduce inflammation).
  • IOP-lowering agents (beta-blockers, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, alpha agonists).
  • Avoid prostaglandin analogs (they may worsen inflammation).
  • Antiviral therapy if CMV is suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis:

 

  • Presents with chronic low-grade anterior uveitis.
  • Unilateral iris heterochromia (affected eye is lighter in color).
  • Fine stellate keratic precipitates (KPs) across the entire cornea.
  • PSC cataracts are common.
  • No posterior synechiae formation, unlike other types of uveitis.
  • Increased IOP but less episodic compared to Posner-Schlossman syndrome.

 

Option C. Sympathetic Ophthalmia:

 

  • Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating ocular trauma.
  • The "exciting eye" (injured eye) triggers an autoimmune reaction that affects the "sympathizing eye".
  • Mutton-fat KPs, Dalen-Fuchs nodules, and serous retinal detachment.
  • Not associated with episodic IOP spikes.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis-Associated Uveitis

 

  • Granulomatous uveitis with mutton-fat keratic precipitates.
  • Multiple systemic features: bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, and skin nodules.
  • Periphlebitis ("candle wax drippings") seen in fundoscopic exam.
  • Chronic course, not self-limited episodes like in Posner-Schlossman syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
