  • Posner-Schlossman syndrome (glaucomatocyclitic crisis) is a rare, recurrent hypertensive uveitis that presents with mild inflammation and episodic IOP spikes. 
  • It is crucial to differentiate it from chronic conditions like Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, granulomatous uveitis (sarcoidosis), and post-traumatic causes like sympathetic ophthalmia. 
  • Management focuses on controlling IOP and inflammation while ruling out infectious triggers like CMV or HSV.

questions.text: A 40-year-old welder presents to the emergency department with fever, headache, chills, cough, and myalgia. He reports these symptoms began 6 hours after working in a poorly ventilated brass foundry. His symptoms resolve within 36 hours, only to return each Monday after resuming work. Which of the following metals is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc

 

  • Brass is combination of copper and zinc
  • Metal fume fever (MFF) is a self-limiting febrile illness caused by inhalation of metal oxide fumes, primarily zinc oxide, leading to flu-like symptoms within 4–8 hours of exposure. 
  • The symptoms improve within 24–36 hours but recur on repeated exposure, such as after a weekend break (Monday morning fever).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead: Toxicity presents with chronic neurological and hematological manifestations rather than an acute flu-like illness.

 

Option C. Mercury: Exposure leads to neurotoxicity, renal dysfunction, and tremors but not MFF.

 

Option D. Silver: Exposure (argyria) causes bluish-gray skin discoloration but does not cause flu-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metal fume fever is also known as brass shakes, zinc shakes, metal dust fever, or Monday morning fever,
  •  It is an illness primarily caused by exposure to chemicals such as zinc (most common), aluminum, or magnesium which are produced as byproducts in the fumes that result when certain metals are heated.
  • Welders are commonly exposed to the substances that cause metal fume fever from the base metal, plating, or filler.
  • The signs and symptoms are generally flu-like or malaria like. They include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, joint pains, shortness of breath, pneumonia, chest pain etc. Flu-like symptoms normally disappear within 24 to 48 hours. 

 

Mnemonic: ZAM causes metal fume fever (Z for Zinc, A for aluminium, M for magnesium)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old carpenter presents to the clinic after 48 hours sustaining a small puncture wound from a wood splinter to the palmar aspect of his right index finger. The patient reports escalating, throbbing pain in the finger. On examination, the right index finger exhibits:

 

  • Fusiform swelling
  • Slight flexion
  • Tenderness along tendon sheath
  • Pain on extension

 

Based on these four physical exam findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyogenic Flexor Tenosynovitis

 

  • PFT is an emergent infection caused by bacteria (usually Staphylococcus aureus) introduced into the closed space of the flexor tendon sheath. 
  • The infection causes rapid inflammation, pus accumulation, and increased pressure, which can impede blood flow to the tendon, leading to necrosis (tendon death) and permanent loss of function if not treated immediately.
  • The four Kanavel's Signs are:
    • Fusiform swelling of the affected digit (uniform, sausage-like swelling).
    • The digit is held in slight flexion.
    • Tenderness along the course of the flexor tendon sheath.
    • Disproportionate pain with passive extension of the finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic Arthritis:

 

  • Infection within the joint space (usually the proximal or distal interphalangeal joint).
  • Pain and tenderness are primarily localized over the joint lines, and pain is elicited with any movement of the joint (both flexion and extension), not specifically along the tendon sheath. 
  • The swelling is generally centered on the joint, not fusiform along the whole digit.

 

Option B. Herpetic Whitlow:

 

  • A viral infection of the fingertip, caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).
  • While painful, it is characterized by the presence of clear, clustered vesicles (blisters) on an erythematous (red) base, usually confined to the fingertip. 
  • It does not present with Kanavel's signs and is not primarily an infection of the tendon sheath.

 

Option D. Cellulitis:

 

  • A superficial soft tissue bacterial infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Presents with diffuse erythema, warmth, and tenderness, but lacks the four specific Kanavel's signs. 
  • The infection is not confined to the tendon sheath, so passive extension does not cause the severe, specific pain characteristic of PFT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To recognize Pyogenic Flexor Tenosynovitis (PFT) as a surgical emergency of the hand based on the presence of the classic Kanavel's Signs (fusiform swelling, slight flexion, tenderness along the tendon sheath, and pain on passive extension). 
  • This differentiation is critical because PFT requires urgent surgical incision and drainage to prevent irreversible tendon ischemia and permanent disability.

questions.text: Following a wedding feast, several people develop bloody diarrhea without fever. Lab findings show E. coli that does not ferment sorbitol. Which serious complication may occur in affected children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic uremic syndrome

 

  • The scenario describes an outbreak due to Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) infection, commonly associated with serotype O157:H7.
  • EHEC produces verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin), which:
    • Inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosomal subunit of host cells.
    • Damages vascular endothelium, especially in the renal glomeruli and cerebral microvasculature, causing capillary microangiopathy.
  • This leads to Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) — a triad of:
    1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
    2. Thrombocytopenia
    3. Acute renal failure
  • Children are particularly susceptible. 
  • The infection often follows ingestion of undercooked beef or contaminated food during community events or feasts.
  • On Sorbitol MacConkey agar, E. coli O157:H7 colonies are colorless (non-sorbitol fermenting) — a key differentiating feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain–Barré syndrome: Associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection, not E. coli. It results from molecular mimicry between bacterial lipooligosaccharides and peripheral nerve gangliosides.

 

Option C. Reactive arthritis: May follow Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia or Campylobacter infection. Not typically linked to EHEC infection.

 

Option D. Toxic megacolon: A severe complication of Clostridioides difficile colitis or ulcerative colitis, not of E. coli O157:H7 infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (O157:H7) infection causes bloody diarrhea without fever and may progress to Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) due to Shiga-like toxin–induced endothelial injury.
  • Non-sorbitol-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar are diagnostic clues.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding microangiopathic hemolytic anemia are correct? 

 

  1. MAHA is characterized by fragmentation of RBCs due to mechanical injury within the microcirculation, producing schistocytes on peripheral smear.
  2. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) are classic causes of MAHA.
  3. Low haptoglobin levels, elevated LDH, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are typical laboratory findings.
  4. MAHA commonly presents with isolated hemolysis without thrombocytopenia.
  5. DIC can produce MAHA due to widespread fibrin deposition in small vessels.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 1, 2, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Statement 1. MAHA is characterized by fragmentation of RBCs due to mechanical injury within the microcirculation, producing schistocytes on peripheral smear: MAHA occurs due to mechanical fragmentation of RBCs in small vessels, resulting in schistocytes (helmet cells) on peripheral smear.

 

Statement 2. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) are classic causes of MAHA: TTP and HUS are classic causes of MAHA, both involving microvascular thrombosis leading to RBC destruction and thrombocytopenia.

 

Statement 3. Low haptoglobin levels, elevated LDH, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are typical laboratory findings: Hemolysis in MAHA causes low haptoglobin, high LDH, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia due to intravascular RBC destruction.

 

Statement 5. DIC can produce MAHA due to widespread fibrin deposition in small vessels: DIC can produce MAHA because fibrin deposition in small vessels leads to RBC shearing, schistocytes, and consumptive thrombocytopenia.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. MAHA commonly presents with isolated hemolysis without thrombocytopenia: Incorrect. MAHA does not present with isolated hemolysis — it is always associated with thrombocytopenia due to platelet consumption in the microthrombi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (MAHA) is characterized by RBC fragmentation and schistocyte formation due to microvascular injury, seen in conditions like TTP, HUS, and DIC. 
  • It presents with hemolysis and thrombocytopenia, along with low haptoglobin and elevated LDH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with long-standing epigastric pain and occasional hematemesis. The pain typically occurs a few hours after meals and is relieved by food or antacids. He has a history of chronic Helicobacter pylori infection. Endoscopy reveals a single round ulcer with a clean base on the lesser curvature of the antrum. Biopsy from the ulcer edge shows active chronic gastritis with neutrophils infiltrating glandular epithelium, presence of spiral-shaped bacteria, and intestinal metaplasia in adjacent mucosa. Which of the following complications is this patient most at risk for if the condition persists?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MALT lymphoma

 

  • This is a case of chronic H. pylori-associated gastritis, most likely chronic antral gastritis, which can lead to several complications.
  • Chronic stimulation of mucosal lymphoid tissue by H. pylori infection can result in the development of extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALT lymphoma).
  • H. pylori infection induces chronic inflammation → formation of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) → polyclonal B-cell proliferation → may evolve into monoclonal neoplastic proliferation (lymphoma).
  • Early MALT lymphomas can regress after H. pylori eradication with antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST): 

 

  • Mesenchymal tumor of interstitial cells of Cajal, usually seen in stomach or small intestine.
  • Associated with c-KIT (CD117) mutation, not H. pylori.
  • Presents as submucosal mass, not ulceration.

 

Option C. Menetrier’s disease: 

 

  • Characterized by massive foveolar hyperplasia of gastric mucosa → giant rugal folds, protein loss, and hypoproteinemia.
  • Caused by TGF-α overexpression, not infection.
  • Not associated with H. pylori or ulcers.

 

Option D. Carcinoid tumor: 

 

  • Arises from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in chronic autoimmune gastritis (Type A), where there is achlorhydria and hypergastrinemia, not H. pylori.
  • Usually seen in the body/fundus, not the antrum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

H. pylori related conditions:

choices.text: Open Reduction Internal Fixation (ORIF) with plating
Closed Reduction Internal Fixation with a Proximal Femoral Nail
Non-operative management with traction and bed rest

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with a history of osteoporosis slips on a rug at home and presents to the emergency with severe right hip pain and inability to bear weight. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical intervention for this specific fracture pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed Reduction Internal Fixation with a Proximal Femoral Nail

 

  • The patient's age, history of osteoporosis, mechanism of injury, and clinical findings (severe hip pain, inability to bear weight, shortened and externally rotated leg) are all classic for a Proximal Femur Fracture.
  • Given the context of common geriatric fractures, the X-ray is highly likely to show an Intertrochanteric Fracture.
  • Intertrochanteric fractures (ITFs) are extracapsular fractures that heal well with fixation because the blood supply to the femoral head is usually preserved. 
  • They do not typically require joint replacement.
  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN), or another intramedullary nail system (like the Gamma Nail or Trochanteric Fixation Nail - TFN), is the preferred device, especially for unstable or comminuted ITFs and subtrochanteric fractures.
  • The nail acts as a load-sharing implant, placed in the central axis of the femur. 
  • This provides a biomechanically superior construct compared to plates, offering excellent stability against bending and rotational forces.
  • Closed reduction (manipulating the fragments without a large surgical incision) minimizes soft tissue damage, reducing blood loss and infection risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open Reduction Internal Fixation (ORIF) with plating:

 

  • While a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is an alternative for stable ITFs, plates (like the DHS) are load-bearing implants placed on the lateral side of the femur, making them prone to mechanical failure in unstable fractures or poor quality (osteoporotic) bone. 
  • Modern intramedullary nailing is generally superior for unstable patterns.

 

Option B. Hemiarthroplasty:

 

  • This is the treatment of choice for a displaced Femoral Neck Fracture (intracapsular fracture) in an elderly patient, as the blood supply to the femoral head is often compromised, leading to a high risk of avascular necrosis. 
  • Since the fracture is most likely intertrochanteric (extracapsular), fixation is preferred over replacement.

 

Option D. Non-operative management with traction and bed rest:

 

  • This is almost never appropriate for geriatric hip fractures due to the high risk of severe complications, including pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, pressure ulcers, and rapid functional decline.
  • Early surgical fixation and mobilization are the standards of care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To identify that the Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is the standard of care for stabilizing intertrochanteric fractures in the elderly, particularly those with unstable or comminuted patterns and underlying osteoporosis, due to its load-sharing biomechanical advantage and minimally invasive surgical technique.

choices.text: Lowest FSH receptor density, highest androgen: estrogen ratio, largest antral volume
Highest antral estrogen concentration, lowest androgen: estrogen ratio, maximum FSH receptors
Highest progesterone production, moderate FSH receptors, smallest follicular fluid volume
Maximum LH receptors, highest androgen production, intermediate estrogen levels

questions.text: Which combination of factors most accurately characterizes the dominant follicle selected around days 5–7 of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Highest antral estrogen concentration, lowest androgen: estrogen ratio, maximum FSH receptors

 

  • During the early to mid-follicular phase (days 1–7), multiple follicles begin to grow under the influence of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). 
  • However, by days 5–7, only one follicle — the dominant follicle — continues to mature, while the others undergo atresia.
  • Key Characteristics of the Dominant Follicle:
    1. Highest FSH receptor expression: The dominant follicle has the greatest sensitivity to FSH, allowing it to continue growing even as FSH levels begin to decline due to negative feedback from rising estrogen.
    2. Highest intrafollicular estrogen concentration:
      • Granulosa cells in the dominant follicle express aromatase, converting androgens from theca cells into estradiol.
      • High estrogen levels promote granulosa cell proliferation and further increase FSH receptor expression.
    3. Lowest androgen: estrogen ratio:
      • Efficient conversion of androgens to estrogens results in a low androgen: estrogen ratio, which favors dominance and maturation.
      • Non-dominant follicles have relatively higher androgen levels, leading to atresia.

    4. Autocrine and paracrine advantage: Elevated estradiol and FSH receptor expression maintain follicular growth despite decreasing circulating FSH levels.

       

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lowest FSH receptor density, highest androgen: estrogen ratio, largest antral volume: Incorrect. The dominant follicle has high FSH receptor density and low androgen: estrogen ratio; this option describes atretic follicles instead.

 

Option C. Highest progesterone production, moderate FSH receptors, smallest follicular fluid volume: Incorrect. Significant progesterone production occurs after ovulation in the luteal phase, not in the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Maximum LH receptors, highest androgen production, intermediate estrogen levels: Incorrect.

 

  • LH receptor acquisition on granulosa cells occurs later (pre-ovulatory phase).
  • Dominant follicle has high estrogen, not androgen, levels at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dominant follicle is characterized by maximum FSH receptor density, highest estrogen levels, and a low androgen: estrogen ratio, enabling it to continue growth and prepare for ovulation despite falling FSH levels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with hypertension, diabetes, and stage 4 CKD is admitted with chest pain. After initially normal ECGs, subsequent tracings reveal ischemic ST changes suggestive of an evolving MI. Cardiac catheterization is planned. Medications include lisinopril, torsemide, aspirin, carvedilol, and insulin. BP is 110/66 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, no edema is noted, and lungs are clear. What is the best intervention to reduce the risk of contrast-associated acute kidney injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV normal saline

 

  • The most effective preventive measure for contrast-induced AKI in high-risk patients (such as those with CKD) is IV hydration with isotonic saline, which preserves renal perfusion and limits renal tubular exposure to contrast media.
  • IV fluids started before the procedure and continued for a short time after significantly lower AKI risk compared to oral fluids, which are inadequate for high-risk patients.
  • N-acetylcysteine has not been shown to offer clear benefit for AKI prevention in large studies.
  • Hemodialysis is not indicated for prophylaxis; it is reserved only if severe AKI develops unresponsive to conservative therapy.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hemodialysis immediately after the procedure: Hemodialysis after the procedure is unnecessary and offers no proven preventive benefit for contrast nephropathy.


Option B. IV N-acetylcysteine: IV N-acetylcysteine is not supported by consistent evidence for AKI prevention.


Option D. Oral fluids: Oral fluids alone are insufficient for AKI prophylaxis in high-risk patients like this one.

 

Educational Objective:


IV isotonic saline hydration, administered before and after contrast exposure, is the preferred strategy to minimize the risk of contrast-associated AKI in patients with CKD or other risk factors.

choices.text: Color of colony and vesicle shape

questions.text: Which combination of features differentiates Aspergillus fumigatus from Aspergillus flavus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color of colony and vesicle shape

 

  • Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus flavus are both common pathogenic species of Aspergillus, but they can be differentiated by their macroscopic colony color and microscopic vesicle morphology.
  • Color of colony:
    • A. fumigatus produces smoky green, velvety colonies with a white reverse.
    • A. flavus shows yellow-green, velvety colonies, also with a white reverse.
  • Vesicle shape:
    • In A. fumigatus, the vesicle is conical, and the phialides are arranged in a single row (uniseriate) arising from the upper one-third of the vesicle.
    • In A. flavus, the vesicle is globular, and phialides occur in one or two rows, covering the entire vesicle.
  • These two key differences—colony pigmentation and vesicle architecture—are the classical distinguishing features between these species on culture and LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presence of conidiophores: Both A. fumigatus and A. flavus do not possess conidiophores, so this does not differentiate them.

 

Option C. Arrangement of hyphae: Both species exhibit septate, hyaline hyphae with acute-angle branching (45°), so their hyphal arrangement is identical.

 

Option D. Presence of septate hyphae: Again, both species are septate molds; the septation is not species-specific and therefore not a differentiating feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most reliable laboratory distinction between Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus flavus lies in their colony color and microscopic vesicle morphology.
  • A. fumigatus → Smoky green colony, conical vesicle, uniseriate phialides.
  • A. flavus → Yellow-green colony, globular vesicle, uniseriate or biseriate phialides.

choices.text: Anti-tubercular therapy for 6–9 months with DOTS

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 5 years of primary infertility undergoes diagnostic laparoscopy. Findings show bilateral cornual tubal block, beaded fallopian tubes with alternating constrictions and dilatations, and perihepatic adhesions (violin-string adhesions). Endometrial biopsy demonstrates caseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-tubercular therapy for 6–9 months with DOTS

 

  • This patient has genital tuberculosis (GTB), a well-recognized cause of tubal infertility in developing countries such as India.

 

Diagnostic features:

 

  • Laparoscopic findings:
    • Beaded tubes with alternating constrictions and dilatations (representing fibrosis and scarring).
    • Bilateral cornual block due to endosalpingitis.
    • Perihepatic adhesions (violin-string appearance) — seen in Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome.
  • Histopathology: Caseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells — pathognomonic of tuberculous endometritis.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • The infection commonly spreads hematogenously from a pulmonary focus.
  • It primarily affects the fallopian tubes, leading to fibrosis, obstruction, and hydrosalpinx, causing infertility.
  • The endometrium may also be affected, reducing implantation potential.

 

Initial Management:

 

  • The first-line treatment is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) for 6–9 months under the DOTS regimen:
    • Intensive phase (2 months): Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol.
    • Continuation phase (4–7 months): Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ethambutol.
  • Treatment aims to eradicate infection, reduce inflammation, and prevent further damage.
  • Fertility interventions (like IVF) are considered only after completion of ATT and disease quiescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-dose corticosteroids for 3 months: Incorrect.

 

  • Steroids have no role in treating genital TB.
  • They may worsen infection by suppressing immunity.

 

Option C. Bilateral salpingectomy followed by IVF: Incorrect.

 

  • Surgery and IVF are secondary measures after completion of ATT if tubal damage is irreversible.
  • Immediate surgery is not appropriate before treating the infection.

 

Option D. In vitro fertilization immediately: Incorrect.

 

  • IVF before ATT risks disease flare-up and poor endometrial receptivity.
  • Fertility treatment should begin only after infection control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In genital tuberculosis, the initial management is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) for 6–9 months under DOTS, aimed at eradicating infection and preventing further tubal and endometrial damage. 
  • Fertility interventions such as IVF are considered only after completion of ATT and confirmation of disease inactivity.

questions.text: A public health officer is distributing STI treatment kits under the National STD Control Programme. Match the sexually transmitted disease with the correct color-coded STI treatment kit.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a


The National STD Control Programme (India) uses color-coded kits for the syndromic management of STIs.

 

  • 1-b. Urethritis — Grey kit: contains antibiotics covering gonococcal and chlamydial causes.
  • 2-c. Non-herpetic genital ulcers — White/Blue kit: provides treatment for chancroid and syphilis.
  • 3-a. Vaginal discharge — Green kit: covers bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, and candidiasis.

 

Educational Objective:


Color-coded STI kits ensure easy and rapid syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections under the National STD Control Programme, enabling primary healthcare providers to deliver standardized treatment.

questions.text: What procedure is this instrument most commonly used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open myomectomy

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp, which is primarily used in open myomectomy procedures. 
  • This clamp is designed to provide hemostasis by occluding blood vessels in the uterine tissue during the removal of fibroids (myomas). 
  • Myomectomy is a surgical procedure used to excise uterine fibroids while preserving the uterus, often performed in women who desire future fertility or want to avoid hysterectomy.
  • The Bonney clamp allows the surgeon to control bleeding during the excision of fibroids, which is critical due to the high vascularity of the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic hysterectomy: While laparoscopic instruments are used in hysterectomy, the Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is specifically designed for open procedures, not for use in laparoscopic surgeries.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is a minimally invasive procedure used to remove or destroy the lining of the uterus to treat heavy menstrual bleeding. This procedure does not involve the use of a Bonney’s clamp, as it focuses on the endometrium rather than uterine fibroids.

 

Option D. Cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsies are small tissue samples taken from the cervix, typically during a colposcopy. A Bonney’s clamp is not needed for this procedure, which involves much smaller instruments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is commonly used during an open myomectomy to control bleeding while removing uterine fibroids.

questions.text: Which of these is not a property of volatile anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain Relief 

 

  • This is generally not considered a primary property of volatile anaesthetic agents. 
  • While they can contribute to overall anesthesia, they do not provide significant analgesia.
  • The main analgesic inhalational agents are nitrous oxide and xenon.

 

Properties of volatile anaesthetic agents:

 

  • Amnesia
  • Muscle relaxation
  • Loss of reflexes 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness: Volatile anaesthetic agents are known to induce a reversible loss of consciousness, making them essential for general anesthesia.

 

Option C. Loss of Reflexes: Volatile anaesthetics can diminish or abolish reflexes, which is important during surgical procedures to prevent spontaneous movements and potential injury.

 

Option D. Muscle Relaxation: These agents also contribute to muscle relaxation, which is necessary for some types of surgical procedures, though often, additional muscle relaxants are used to achieve adequate relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Volatile anaesthetic agents are used in general anesthesia for their ability to induce unconsciousness, muscle relaxation, and suppression of reflexes. 
  • They do not provide significant pain relief, which is why additional analgesic agents, such as opioids, are often administered concurrently during surgery. 
  • Nitrous oxide and xenon are unique among inhalational agents in that they also have analgesic properties.

choices.text: Measurement of angle of deviation and sensory status

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a history of intermittent esotropia is undergoing orthoptic evaluation. The ophthalmologist uses the slides shown in the image below in an instrument for assessment. What is the primary purpose of this device in strabismus management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measurement of angle of deviation and sensory status

 

  • The Synoptophore slides seen in the image are used for diagnosing and treating binocular vision anomalies, particularly in strabismus. 
  • This device is used to measure:
    • Objective and subjective angle of deviation
    • Binocular sensory functions (simultaneous perception, fusion, stereopsis)
    • Treatment of suppression and anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Detection of amblyopia severity: Amblyopia is evaluated using visual acuity charts and contrast sensitivity tests.

 

Option C. Evaluation of intraocular pressure differences: This is assessed using tonometry, not the Synoptophore.

 

Option D. Measurement of accommodation-convergence ratio: Determined by heterophoria testing, not the Synoptophore.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Synoptophore is used in strabismus evaluation to measure ocular deviation, assess binocular vision, and provide orthoptic treatment for fusion and suppression anomalies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes for evaluation of persistent fatigue and mild shortness of breath. His pulmonary examination and chest X-ray are unremarkable. ABG analysis reveals a PaCO₂ of 45 mm Hg, and his expired air sample shows PECO₂ of 35 mm Hg. His tidal volume (VT) is measured as 0.5 L, and his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. Which of the following represents his alveolar ventilation (VA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5.4 L/min

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alveolar ventilation can be calculated from minute ventilation and the ratio of expired to arterial CO₂ pressures.
  • It provides a direct measure of effective ventilation in the alveoli where gas exchange occurs.

choices.text: Activation of Golgi tendon organs via group Ib afferent fibers leading to muscle relaxation
Activation of group Ia afferent fibers from muscle spindles leading to α-motor neuron stimulation of the same muscle
Activation of cutaneous mechanoreceptors via Aβ fibers leading to contraction of the antagonist muscle
Activation of γ-motor neurons increasing tension in extrafusal fibers and inhibiting reflex contraction

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker is struck on the patellar tendon by a falling object. The impact rapidly stretches the quadriceps muscle, triggering an immediate contraction that prevents his knee from buckling. Which of the following neural pathways is primarily responsible for this rapid compensatory response?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activation of group Ia afferent fibers from muscle spindles leading to α-motor neuron stimulation of the same muscle

 

  • The muscle spindle is a stretch receptor embedded within skeletal muscle. 
  • It detects changes in muscle length and mediates the myotatic (stretch) reflex, which resists excessive stretch to maintain posture and tone.
  • When the muscle is stretched, the intrafusal fibers of the spindle also stretch.
  • This activates group Ia afferent fibers, which send signals to the spinal cord.
  • In the spinal cord, these Ia afferents directly synapse with α-motor neurons that innervate the same (homonymous) muscle, causing reflex contraction.
  • Simultaneously, inhibitory interneurons suppress the α-motor neurons of the antagonistic muscle — a process known as reciprocal inhibition.
  • This allows the stretched muscle to return to its resting length, stabilizing body position — as seen in the patellar reflex (L2–L4).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of Golgi tendon organs via group Ib afferent fibers leading to muscle relaxation: Golgi tendon organs monitor tension, not length. Group Ib fibers cause autogenic inhibition, leading to relaxation, not contraction.

 

Option C. Activation of cutaneous mechanoreceptors via Aβ fibers leading to contraction of the antagonist muscle: Aβ fibers mediate touch and pressure, not muscle stretch. They are not part of the stretch reflex.

 

Option D. Activation of γ-motor neurons increasing tension in extrafusal fibers and inhibiting reflex contraction: γ-motor neurons adjust the sensitivity of intrafusal fibers, not extrafusal contraction directly. Their activation enhances, not inhibits, reflex sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Group Ia afferent fibers from muscle spindles detect muscle stretch.
  • They activate α-motor neurons, causing reflex contraction of the same muscle and relaxation of the antagonist.
  • This stretch reflex helps maintain muscle tone and posture.

 

Key concept:

 

Stretch → Muscle spindle → Group Ia afferents → α-motor neurons → Reflex contraction (stretch reflex)

choices.text: Observation with repeat labs and clinical examination every 3 months
Stem cell collection in preparation for autologous stem cell transplant

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with CAD presents with anemia, fatigue, neuropathic pain in the feet, and mobility issues. Lab studies show an IgM monoclonal spike (7 g/dL), thrombocytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy with 65% involvement by monoclonal plasmacytoid lymphocytes. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start bendamustine + rituximab

 

  • The patient meets diagnostic criteria for Waldenström macroglobulinemia: symptomatic anemia, neuropathy, high serum IgM, monoclonal spike, and bone marrow involvement by lymphoplasmacytic cells.
  • Symptomatic cases require therapy; the preferred first-line regimen is a combination of bendamustine (an alkylating agent) and rituximab (anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody), which is highly effective for initial treatment and symptom improvement.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Observation with repeat labs and clinical examination every 3 months: Observation is reserved for asymptomatic or smoldering WM, not those with severe neuropathy and fatigue.


Option C. Start bortezomib + dexamethasone + lenalidomide: Bortezomib-based regimens are standard for multiple myeloma, not for first-line treatment of WM.


Option D. Stem cell collection in preparation for autologous stem cell transplant: Stem cell transplant is not first-line for WM and is reserved for relapsed or refractory cases after initial chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For symptomatic Waldenström macroglobulinemia, immediate initiation of chemotherapy with bendamustine plus rituximab is standard. 
  • Observation is reserved for asymptomatic patients, and transplant approaches are used in refractory or relapsed cases.

choices.text: Score 8; repeat testing at weekly interval
Score 4; deliver regardless of gestational age

questions.text: A 35-year-old G3P2 at 38 weeks presents with decreased fetal movements. Biophysical profile (BPP) is performed showing: reactive NST, one episode of fetal breathing >30 seconds, two discrete body movements, good fetal tone, and AFI of 4 cm. What is the BPP score and recommended management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Score 6; repeat test in 4–6 hours

 

Step 1: Biophysical Profile (BPP) Parameters

 

BPP assesses five parameters, each given 2 points if normal, and 0 if abnormal/absent, for a maximum total of 10 points:

 

  1. NST (Non-stress test) – 2 points if reactive
  2. Fetal breathing movements – 2 points if ≥1 episode lasting >30 seconds
  3. Fetal body movements – 2 points if ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
  4. Fetal tone – 2 points if ≥1 episode of extension with return to flexion
  5. Amniotic fluid index (AFI) – 2 points if ≥5 cm (normal); 0 if ≤5 cm (oligohydramnios)

 

Step 2: Scoring in this Case

 

 

Step 3: Interpretation of BPP

 

 

Thus, this patient has a BPP score of 6, which is equivocal, so the test should be repeated in 4–6 hours to reassess fetal well-being.

 

Here, as the patient is 38 weeks gestation, so best is to plan for the delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In biophysical profile (BPP):

 

  • A score of 6/10 is equivocal and warrants retesting in 4–6 hours.
  • AFI <5 cm indicates oligohydramnios, a sign of placental insufficiency.
  • Persistent low BPP requires delivery to prevent fetal hypoxia and stillbirth.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis B infection presents with right upper quadrant discomfort, early satiety, and unintentional weight loss over 3 months. On examination, there is hepatomegaly with a firm, nodular liver edge. Laboratory investigations show: Serum bilirubin: 1.5 mg/dL, ALT: 80 U/L AST: 90 U/L Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP): 2200 ng/mL (↑), Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): positive and Ultrasound abdomen: single mass lesion in the right lobe of liver. CT scan: arterial phase enhancement with rapid washout in venous phase. A liver biopsy is performed. Histology shows trabecular arrangement of polygonal cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, and bile pigment within tumor cells. Reticulin stain shows loss of normal hepatic plate architecture. Which of the following is the most likely precursor lesion for this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysplastic nodule in cirrhotic liver

 

  • Elevated AFP, chronic HBV infection, arterial enhancement with venous washout, and bile-containing tumor cells → Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC).
  • Dysplastic nodule in cirrhotic liver: Dysplastic nodules (especially high-grade) are the direct precursors to HCC in cirrhosis.
  • Occur in the background of chronic HBV/HCV, alcohol, or NAFLD.
  • Show atypical hepatocytes with loss of reticulin framework, increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and unpaired arteries. → Stepwise progression: Regenerative nodule → Low-grade dysplastic nodule → High-grade dysplastic nodule → HCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic adenoma: Benign tumor of hepatocytes, seen in young women on oral contraceptives. May rupture and bleed but rarely transforms into HCC (only β-catenin mutated subtype has risk). Histologically lacks bile production and portal tracts. → Not the usual precursor for HCC in a cirrhotic HBV liver.

 

Option C. Focal nodular hyperplasia: Benign, non-neoplastic lesion caused by localized vascular abnormality. Has central stellate scar and normal hepatocytes. No risk of malignant transformation. → Not related to HBV or HCC.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Most common benign liver tumor, composed of blood-filled vascular channels. Usually incidental, never undergoes malignant change. → No link with HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is not typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated urinary VMA

 

  • Pheochromocytoma is not typically associated with MEN 1 syndrome.
  • Instead, it is commonly seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2). 
  • MEN 1 primarily involves tumors in the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland, but pheochromocytomas are not a feature of this syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated PTH levels: Parathyroid hyperplasia is one of the primary manifestations of MEN 1. Most patients with MEN 1 will develop parathyroid gland hyperplasia or adenomas, leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Elevated Serum Gastrin: Pancreatic endocrine tumors, such as gastrinomas and insulinomas, are commonly seen in MEN 1 and are a defining feature of this syndrome.

 

Option D. Pituitary prolactinoma: Pituitary tumors, especially prolactinomas, are another common feature of MEN 1. Pituitary tumors in MEN 1 can secrete various hormones, with prolactin being one of the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by a combination of tumors in the parathyroid glands, pancreatic endocrine glands, and pituitary gland. 
  • Pheochromocytoma, however, is not associated with MEN 1 and is instead a feature of MEN 2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida. Which of the following anatomical areas is most likely involved in the formation of a cholesteatoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prussak space

 

  • A cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear, typically arising from retraction pockets in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. 
  • The Prussak space, located between the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus, is the most common site for the initiation of cholesteatomas.
  • Retraction pockets in the pars flaccida extend into the Prussak space, allowing for accumulation of keratin debris and subsequent infection, leading to the formation of a cholesteatoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promontory: The promontory is part of the medial wall of the middle ear and houses the cochlear basal turn. While it is an important anatomical landmark, it is not involved in the formation of cholesteatomas.

 

Option C. Oval window: The oval window is an opening in the medial wall of the middle ear that connects to the stapes footplate and the inner ear. It plays a role in sound conduction but is not involved in the early formation of cholesteatomas.

 

Option D. Facial recess: The facial recess is a surgical landmark located lateral to the facial nerve and medial to the chorda tympani in the posterior tympanum. It is not related to cholesteatoma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussak space is the primary site involved in the formation of cholesteatomas, particularly those arising from retraction pockets in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.

choices.text: Decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by renal vasoconstriction
Promotes sodium and water retention via aldosterone release
Increases renal perfusion and natriuresis via selective D1 activation

questions.text: Which of the following is a unique renal effect of fenoldopam that distinguishes it from other intravenous antihypertensives?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases renal perfusion and natriuresis via selective D1 activation

 

  • Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine-1 (D1) receptor agonist used intravenously for short-term management of hypertensive emergencies, especially in patients with renal dysfunction.
  • Its mechanism involves:
    • D1 receptor stimulation → vasodilation of renal arterioles, especially the afferent arteriole
    • This increases renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and promotes natriuresis and diuresis
    • Unlike other vasodilators (e.g., nitroprusside), fenoldopam preserves or improves renal function, making it useful in patients with concurrent acute kidney injury (AKI) or at risk for renal ischemia
  • This renoprotective profile makes fenoldopam unique among IV antihypertensives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by renal vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Fenoldopam causes renal vasodilation, not constriction.

 

Option B. Promotes sodium and water retention via aldosterone release: Incorrect. Fenoldopam inhibits sodium reabsorption by increasing renal perfusion and natriuresis. It has no direct mineralocorticoid effect.

 

Option D. Causes nephrotoxicity with prolonged infusion: Incorrect. Fenoldopam is not nephrotoxic. In contrast, sodium nitroprusside may be harmful in renal failure due to cyanide accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fenoldopam, a selective dopamine-1 receptor agonist, is a unique IV antihypertensive that increases renal perfusion, GFR, and natriuresis, making it especially beneficial in hypertensive emergencies with renal impairment.

choices.text: 2 U fresh frozen plasma and 10 mg IV vitamin K
2 U fresh frozen plasma and platelet transfusion
No blood products necessary. Proceed with surgery

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with hepatitis C and compensated cirrhosis needs urgent surgery for a femoral fracture after a car accident. She has a stable platelet count of 40,000/µL and stable hemoglobin, INR 1.3, and normal differential. What blood products should she receive before surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Platelet transfusion alone

 

  • Platelet transfusion is necessary before surgery in patients with thrombocytopenia to increase the platelet count above 50,000/µL, which is the generally accepted minimum for most surgical procedures.
  • This patient’s mild INR elevation is chronic and related to liver dysfunction, reflecting reduced synthesis of both procoagulant and anticoagulant factors, and does not constitute a true bleeding risk requiring FFP or vitamin K unless the INR is > 1.5 or active bleeding is present.
  • FFP and vitamin K are reserved for cases of significant coagulopathy or vitamin K deficiency, neither of which is supported by this patient’s labs or clinical context.
  • Proceeding without platelet transfusion would place the patient at high risk for perioperative bleeding.

 

Other Options:


Option A. 2 U fresh frozen plasma and 10 mg IV vitamin K: FFP and vitamin K are not necessary for mild INR elevation due to chronic liver disease.


Option B. 2 U fresh frozen plasma and platelet transfusion: FFP is only used if there is a significant, clinically relevant coagulopathy.


Option C. No blood products necessary. Proceed with surgery: Surgery should not proceed without increasing the platelet count, as her baseline is too low for a safe procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Platelet transfusion is required to raise the platelet count above 50,000/µL in surgical patients with thrombocytopenia due to liver disease. 
  • Fresh frozen plasma and vitamin K are not indicated unless there is a major coagulopathy.

choices.text: Decreased food intake via stimulation of the anorexigenic pathway
Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite
Activation of the satiety center in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with recent weight gain and increased appetite is found to have elevated Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) levels in the hypothalamus. Which of the following best explains the physiological effect of increased AgRP activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite

 

  • Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) is produced in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.
  • It is an orexigenic neuropeptide → it promotes food intake.
  • Mechanism:
    • AgRP acts as an antagonist at melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R).
    • Normally, α-MSH (from POMC neurons) activates MC4R, stimulating the anorexigenic pathway (↓ appetite).
    • AgRP blocks this receptor, thereby reducing satiety signals and increasing appetite.
  • Elevated AgRP → hyperphagia, weight gain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased leptin sensitivity:

 

  • Incorrect. Leptin reduces appetite by inhibiting AgRP/NPY neurons and stimulating POMC neurons.
  • AgRP activity increases with leptin resistance, not increased leptin sensitivity.

 

Option B. Decreased food intake via stimulation of the anorexigenic pathway:

 

  • Incorrect. The anorexigenic pathway involves POMC neurons releasing α-MSH, which activates MC4R.
  • AgRP does the opposite by blocking MC4R.

 

Option D. Activation of the satiety center in the hypothalamus:

 

  • Incorrect. The ventromedial hypothalamus (satiety center) decreases food intake when activated.
  • AgRP stimulates appetite rather than activating satiety pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Agouti-related peptide (AgRP) is an orexigenic neuropeptide from the arcuate nucleus that increases appetite by inhibiting melanocortin-4 receptors, antagonizing the satiety effect of α-MSH.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is most suitable to suppress the swarming motility seen in the image below, allowing isolation of discrete colonies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MacConkey agar

 

  • The image depicts the swarming motility of Proteus species on blood agar, characterized by concentric waves of spreading growth.
  • This occurs due to flagella-mediated motility, making it difficult to isolate single colonies on routine solid media.
  • To inhibit this motility and obtain pure colonies, culture is done on:
    • MacConkey agar or
    • CLED (Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient) agar
  • These media contain bile salts and a higher agar concentration, which suppress swarming behavior.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blood agar: Allows active swarming (as shown in the image).

 

Option B. Nutrient agar: Also supports extensive swarming due to smooth surface moisture.

 

Option D. Chocolate agar: Supports growth but does not inhibit motility; not preferred for isolation of Proteus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

MacConkey agar inhibits the swarming motility of Proteus species through bile salts and higher agar content, allowing the formation of discrete, non-lactose fermenting colonies for accurate identification.

choices.text: Decreased dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway; administer lorazepam
Overstimulation of GABAergic pathways; administer propranolol
Dopamine receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway; decrease dose of haloperidol
Acetylcholine receptor overactivation in the basal ganglia; administer benztropine or diphenhydramine

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with schizophrenia is started on haloperidol for acute psychosis. The following day, she returns to the emergency department with the condition, as shown in the image. She also exhibits agitation and discomfort. Which of the following pathophysiological mechanisms is most likely responsible for her presentation, and what is the best immediate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine receptor overactivation in the basal ganglia; administer benztropine or diphenhydramine

 

  • The patient is experiencing acute dystonia, a severe extrapyramidal side effect caused by dopamine receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway, leading to relative overactivity of cholinergic neurons. 
  • This imbalance between dopamine and acetylcholine causes painful, sustained muscle contractions, such as retrocollis, trismus, and oculogyric crisis. 
  • The condition is commonly seen within hours to days of starting high-potency antipsychotics such as haloperidol.
  • The most effective immediate treatment is the administration of anticholinergic agents like benztropine or antihistamines like diphenhydramine, which restore the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the basal ganglia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway; administer lorazepam: Incorrect. The mechanism is indeed dopamine blockade in the nigrostriatal tract, but lorazepam is not the treatment for acute dystonia. Benzodiazepines are second-line if anticholinergics fail.

 

Option B. Overstimulation of GABAergic pathways; administer propranolol: Incorrect. This describes neither the mechanism of dystonia nor the treatment. Propranolol is used for akathisia, not dystonia.

 

Option C. Dopamine receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway; decrease dose of haloperidol: Partially correct mechanism, incorrect treatment. The underlying cause is dopamine D₂ blockade, but simply reducing the dose does not acutely relieve dystonia. You must treat emergently with anticholinergics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute dystonia is a painful and distressing extrapyramidal side effect caused by dopamine receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway, leading to cholinergic overactivity. 
  • The first-line treatment is anticholinergic agents (e.g., benztropine) or antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine).

choices.text: No further evaluation required given the benign nature
24hr urine fractionated metanephrines, ODST and ARR
24hr urine fractionated metanephrines and ARR

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with hypertension and obesity is found to have a 4.2 × 3.5 cm left adrenal mass with smooth borders on CT abdomen. He presented with dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and his blood pressure is elevated. What is the next best step in management? (Key – ODST: Overnight Dexamethasone Suppression Test, ARR: Aldosterone Renin Ratio)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24hr urine fractionated metanephrines, ODST and ARR

 

  • This patient is diagnosed to have adrenal incidentaloma.
  • All patients with an incidental adrenal mass require biochemical evaluation for hormone excess, regardless of imaging features or size.​
  • The recommended tests are:
    • Screening for pheochromocytoma (24-hour urine or plasma fractionated metanephrines) – it is a must
    • Assessment of cortisol excess (overnight dexamethasone suppression test, ODST) – must be done in obese patients
    • Evaluation for primary aldosteronism (aldosterone-renin ratio, ARR) in hypertensive patients and/or patients with hypokalemia
  • This comprehensive workup is essential because functional adrenal tumors (pheochromocytoma, cortisol excess, or aldosterone-secreting tumors) may be clinically silent. 
  • Appropriate further imaging or intervention depends on the results.
  • Features of a benign tumour: Size < 4cm, Density < 10HU, contrast washout > 50% @ 10mins and rounded/homogenous with smooth borders. 
  • Features of a malignant tumour: Size ≥ 4cm, Density > 20HU, contrast washout < 50% @ 10mins and lobulated/in-homogenous with irregular borders.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Abdominal MRI with adrenal protocol: MRI with adrenal protocol is not initially needed if the lesion appears benign and smooth on CT; biochemical workup takes precedence.


Option B. No further evaluation required given the benign nature: No further evaluation is incorrect since all adrenal masses >1 cm require at least a biochemical evaluation for hormone secretion.


Option D. 24hr urine fractionated metanephrines and ARR: 24hr urine fractionated metanephrines and ARR omits ODST, which is necessary screen for mild autonomous cortisol secretion.

 

Educational Objective:


All adrenal masses ≥1 cm should be evaluated for hormonal hyperfunction—including pheochromocytoma, subclinical Cushing's syndrome, and primary aldosteronism—to guide further management and avoid missing potentially curable but serious endocrine diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotics is classically associated with the side effect of agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clozapine

 

  • Clozapine is the atypical antipsychotic most classically associated with agranulocytosis, a potentially fatal reduction in neutrophil count. 
  • Because of this, strict blood monitoring protocols are mandatory—weekly during the first 6 months, every 2 weeks for the next 6 months, and monthly thereafter.
  • Other key adverse effects include weight gain, hypersalivation (sialorrhea), sedation (MC side effect), constipation, seizures (dose-dependent), and myocarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Commonly causes weight gain and metabolic syndrome, but not agranulocytosis.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Can cause hyperprolactinemia and extrapyramidal symptoms at higher doses.

 

Option D. Quetiapine: Known for sedation and metabolic effects, not agranulocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clozapine is uniquely associated with agranulocytosis, requiring routine blood monitoring and reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia or patients with high suicide risk.

choices.text: L1 level, with the second part of duodenum anterior
L2 level, with the neck of pancreas anterior
L3 level, with the body of pancreas anterior
T12 level, with the head of pancreas anterior

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the portal vein form, and which anatomical structure lies immediately anterior to its site of formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L2 level, with the neck of pancreas anterior

 

  • The portal vein is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and the splenic vein.
  • Site of Formation: The confluence occurs behind the neck of the pancreas, at approximately the level of the L2 vertebra.
  • Anatomical Relations:
    • Anterior to the formation: Neck of pancreas
    • Posterior to the formation: Inferior vena cava (IVC)
  • From this point, the portal vein ascends posterior to the first part of the duodenum and then enters the lesser omentum, running toward the porta hepatis of the liver.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L1 level, second part of duodenum anterior: Incorrect. The second part of the duodenum lies lateral (to the right), not anterior, to the portal vein formation.

 

Option C. L3 level, body of pancreas anterior: Incorrect. The body of the pancreas lies above this level; the neck (not body) overlies the portal vein confluence.

 

Option D. T12 level, head of pancreas anterior: Incorrect. The head of the pancreas lies below T12, and the portal vein does not form at this level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The portal vein forms behind the neck of the pancreas at the level of L2 by the union of the splenic vein and superior mesenteric vein.
  • Understanding this relation is crucial in pancreatic surgery and portal hypertension management, as injury to this region can lead to massive hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency after falling directly onto his left shoulder while playing football. He reports a sudden, sharp pain and says he heard a crackling sound at the time of injury.He is holding his left arm adducted and supported by his right hand. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clavicle Fracture

 

  • The patient fell directly onto his shoulder while playing football. 
  • This is the most common mechanism for fracturing the clavicle, often by transmitting force from the fall up the arm to the collarbone.
  • Reporting a sudden, sharp pain and hearing a "crackling sound" (crepitus) are classic signs that indicate a break in the bone's continuity.
  • The patient is holding his arm adducted (close to the body) and supported by the uninjured hand. 
  • This posturing, often called the "sling sign," is a protective mechanism to reduce movement and tension on the fracture fragments.
  • The X-ray would typically show a fracture line, most commonly in the middle third (midshaft) of the clavicle, often with displacement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acromioclavicular Joint Separation: While caused by a similar mechanism, it presents with a localized prominence and tenderness over the lateral end of the clavicle (the AC joint), and the clavicle bone itself is usually intact.

 

Option B. Glenohumeral Dislocation: Presents with the arm held in slight abduction and external rotation (often anterior dislocation) and a noticeable "squared off" appearance of the shoulder, not typically a deformity over the clavicle.

 

Option C. Rotator Cuff Tear: Usually presents with weakness and difficulty initiating or sustaining arm movement (active range of motion), often without the immediate history of a "crackling sound" or the clear fracture mechanism seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the classic presentation of a clavicle fracture, including the high-energy direct-impact mechanism, the reported crepitus ("crackling sound"), and the characteristic protective posturing (sling sign or supporting the arm adducted), allowing for prompt and accurate diagnosis in the emergency setting.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in their correct sequence from anterior to posterior as they attach to the intercondylar area of the upper surface of tibia:

 

  1. Anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Posterior horn of medial meniscus
  3. Anterior horn of medial meniscus
  4. Posterior cruciate ligament
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 → 1 → 2 → 4

 

  • The intercondylar area of the upper surface of tibia has a specific sequence of attachments from anterior to posterior. 
  • The anterior horn of the medial meniscus (3) attaches just in front of the medial articular surface.
  • Immediately behind this, the anterior cruciate ligament (1) attaches to a smooth area.
  •  Moving posteriorly, the anterior horn of the lateral meniscus attaches to the front of the intercondylar eminence. 
  • The posterior horn of the medial meniscus (2) then attaches to the depression behind the base of the medial intercondylar tubercle. 
  • Finally, at the posteriormost position, the posterior cruciate ligament (4) attaches to the posterior smooth area. 
  • This anatomical arrangement is crucial for knee joint stability and function.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

On the intercondylar area of the upper tibia, structures attach from anterior to posterior in this sequence: anterior horn of medial meniscus → anterior cruciate ligament → posterior horn of medial meniscus → posterior cruciate ligament.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with known IgG kappa light chain multiple myeloma presents with an acute rise in creatinine (3.5 mg/dL from baseline 1.3 mg/dL). His urinalysis is bland, urine protein/creatinine ratio is 5.6 g/g, and urine albumin/creatinine ratio is 0.8 g/g. What is the most likely etiology of his proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Overflow proteinuria

 

  • This patient with multiple myeloma likely has overflow proteinuria from excessive monoclonal light chains (Bence Jones proteins) overwhelming the proximal tubule’s reabsorption capacity. 
  • In these cases, urine protein is primarily composed of non-albumin proteins (light chains), so total protein/creatinine is much higher than the albumin/creatinine ratio, and urinalysis is often bland.
  • Overflow proteinuria occurs when abnormal low-molecular-weight proteins (such as immunoglobulin light chains in multiple myeloma) surpass the kidneys’ ability to reabsorb them, resulting in large amounts of non-albumin protein excretion.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Glomerular proteinuria: Predominantly presents with high albumin excretion and would result in a urine albumin/creatinine ratio closer to the protein/creatinine ratio.


Option B. Tubulointerstitial proteinuria: Seen with tubular injury, but rarely produces excessive proteinuria and is not typical in multiple myeloma.


Option D. Isolated proteinuria: Refers to proteinuria without other clinical findings and does not fit the pattern of high non-albumin protein seen here due to light chain disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Overflow proteinuria in multiple myeloma is due to excessive filtered monoclonal light chains, which exceed tubular handling capacity. 
  • This produces high total proteinuria with a disproportionately low albumin fraction and a bland urine sediment.
